The PCI was assessed against a set of NIST controls (800-79-1). These controls are implemented at the enterprise level as described in the DHS PCI Operations Plan, the PIV Card Issuers (PCIs) governing document for all PCIF operations.  A report is generated, documenting assessment findings, assessor recommendations, and corrective action plans to mitigate or reduce the risk associated with each deficiency found.  The final report is pending assessor recommendations and corrective action plan development.  Upon report completion and submission to the Designated Accreditation Authority (DAO), a renewed Authority to Operate (ATO) will be issued for front-end operations.
 
Strategic and Business Results:  Deficiencies discovered during an assessment, strategic and business recommendations are made to improve operations. Recommendations include changes in the areas of policy, communication, and training.  The final report is pending assessor recommendations and corrective action plan development.  Upon report completion and submission to DAA, a renewed Authority to Operate (ATO) will be issued for front-end operations.
 
Financial Performance: For the purposes of the PCI assessment, the financial performance is not considered a NIST control to determine the financial soundness of the HSPD-12 investment.  Rather the PCI assessment in itself shows the effectiveness of the project to promote and establish an enterprise HSPD-12 solution that is in compliance with FIPS 201.

Innovation:  In some instances, deficiencies cannot be corrected by changes in policy, communication, or training.  In these cases, change requests(CRs)are submitted for a change to the information systems’ back-end infrastructure.  The final report is pending assessor recommendations and corrective action plan development.  Upon report completion and submission to DAA, a renewed Authority to Operate (ATO) will be issued for front-end operations.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Department Homeland Security (DHS) – Homeland Security Presidential Directive-12 (HSPD-12) program is in the Support life cycle phase. HSPD-12 continues to operate within acceptable OMB ranges for cost and schedule variance. However, historical project data continues to negatively impact its cost variance.  Since the last assessment, HSPD-12 completed the system security authorization process required to obtain a new Authorization to Operate (ATO). The program continues working on the connection of its Identification Management system with The Office of Personnel Management's Federal Investigative Services (OPM FIS) - Fingerprint Transaction System (FTS) to submit DHS new hire employee’s fingerprints for background investigations. This effort is scheduled to be completed by 4QFY17. Additionally, HSPD-12 continues working to implement, automate and enforce segregation of duties in its Identification Management system as required by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)-800-79-1 and 800-53-4. The purpose of this, is to make sure that no single individual has the capability to issue a Personal Identity Verification (PIV) card without the cooperation of another authorized person. HSPD-12 is also working on the second phase of it Identification Management System Infrastructure upgrade, which will establish a pre-production environment, hosting a second data center, and an automatic failover to the backup facility in the event of a loss of service at the production facility. HSPD-12 is a program that continuously meets or exceeds its performance metrics, such as availability of its systems, and the number of DHS PIV cards issued.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the DHS HSPD-12 program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The St. E’s TIP is an information technology (IT) program that must be integrated into a construction project currently underway at the St. E’s Campus located in Southeast Washington, DC.  The purpose of the DHS TIP Program is to design, build and operate an IT and telecommunications infrastructure to deliver essential business services to meet the DHS OCIO’s mission, goals and objectives.  The business services will be delivered over an optical platform.  The benefits of the optical platform is an extremely-reliable network that will produce dramatic savings in total cost of ownership, both in terms of capital and operating expenditures.  The platform consists of fewer active devices and connections.  Using significantly fewer network elements than traditional networks will logically lead to fewer points of failure.  To support fewer devices translates to ease of implementation, ease of management, and ease of scalability and upgrades.  Also the use of the optical platforms multi-degree capabilities, services can be kept up in spite of multiple network faults.  The optical platform is also carrier class which translates into an extremely reliable network, promising 99.999 percent uptime. The platform will deliver a more secured network.  
The consolidation will include the following DHS Components (Stakeholders/customers): DHS Headquarters, Mission Support Components, and Liaisons; Domestic Nuclear Detection Office (DNDO); Science and Technology Directorate (S&T); U.S. Coast Guard Headquarters (USCG); U.S. Customs and Border Patrol Headquarters (CBP); Federal Emergency Management Agency Headquarters (FEMA); Immigration and Customs Enforcement Headquarters (ICE); Transportation Security Administration Headquarters (TSA) (TBD); U.S. Secret Service (USSS);  Citizenship and Immigration Service (USCIS).
 Stakeholders and beneficiaries of the St. E’s infrastructure built by the TIP contractor are: (1) End Users at St. E’s – less down time of network due to reliability of Optical technology, more efficient network due to greater bandwidth and bandwidth efficiency, greater security; (2) OCIO – less operating costs as well as greater ease in implementing new services.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3241 - M&S Goal 6.1: Integrate Intelligence, Information Sharing, and Operations
ROI Description:
The TIP program supports the development of the St Elizabeth’s  network infrastructure for IT and Physical Security (PS). The TIP benefits the government through deployment of GPON Technology and Blade Servers which enables lower network Total Cost of Ownership. Additional benefits include the following:  
  
v  Significantly less Physical Space Requirements. 
v  Reduced Power Consumption and Improved Power Management. 
v  Lower Management Costs. 
v  Meet the intent of Executive Order 13423: Strengthening Federal Environmental Energy and Transportation Management. 
v  Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007, Energy Policy Act (EPACT) 2005, Renewable Energy Requirement Guidance for EPACT 2005. 
v  Greater security, reliability and ease of management. 
v  Provides a converged, simplified network. 
v  Flexible easily expandable architectural platform to accommodate future evolution of systems. 
v  Create a structure to allow for assimilation and utilization of new technologies as they become available during TIP implementation and further future adaptation.
Investment Requirements: The legislative mandate that the NCRIO Program is based on is Public Law 109925. The URL is as follows:https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-109publ295/pdf/PLAW-109publ295.pdf.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) St. Elizabeth’s Headquarters (St. Es) is in the Mixed life cycle phase. The program continues to operate within recommended Office of Management and Budget (OMB) thresholds for cost and schedule variance. Since last assessment, an Acquisition Decision Memorandum (ADM) signed by Deputy Under Secretary of Management (DUSM) on December 9, 2016 renamed the program as “St. Elizabeth’s Headquarters (St. Es)? on the Master Acquisition Oversight List (MAOL) and changed from an Chief Readiness Support officer (OCRSO) Component Acquisition Executive (CAE) governed major program on the MAOL to a Level 2 major program governed by the DHS Acquisition Decision Authority (ADA). Also OCRSO, the Office of the Chief Security Officer and the Office of the Chief Information officer (OCIO) are working to determine the best way to report and present the DHS funded portions of the St. Es program in the OMB business case, as ADM action item. Technology Integration is the only portion of the St. Es consolidation program that is funded by DHS, however, the contract for these DHS funded items are still awarded and managed out of General Service Administration (GSA) with nominal DHS oversight. Operational Analysis (OA) indicates program is meeting technical and performance goals as well as customer expectations. The risk register is current, and program continues to review prioritize the risk and mitigation strategy.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the DHS St. Es program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of Computer Linked Application Information Management System 4 (CLAIMS4) is to provide immigration naturalization benefits and services to applicants in support of DHS Mission 3: Enforcing and Administering our immigration laws, Goal 3.1 Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, Objective 3.1.2: Effectively administer the immigration services system. 

The primary goal for CLAIMS 4 is to grant immigration and citizenship benefits as well as provide accurate and useful information to our customers, and strengthen the security and integrity of our immigration system. 

Key CLAIMS4 customers and beneficiaries include: naturalization applicants, applicant representatives, immigration service officers, adjudicators, field operators, investigators, citizenship branches, community based organizations, Office of the Inspector General (OIG) and Office of Performance Quality (OPQ). In addition, CLAIMS4 interface users, such as service centers, field offices, lockbox, Fraud Detection and National Security (FDNS), JPMorgan Chase (JPMC), National Business Center (NBC), Enterprise Service Bus (ESB), Benefit Biometric Support System (BBSS), Customer Relationship Interface System (CRIS), National File Tracking System (NFTS) and CLAIMS 3. Key stakeholders include DHS, USCIS Management, OPQ - Office of Performance and Quality, OIG-Office of Inspector General, the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the Government Accountability Office (GAO) and Congress.
The investment provides the following benefits including: the processing of naturalization applications, interagency naturalization data sharing, active directory integration and reporting for system user account management. With N400 launch by Office of Transformation Coordination (OTC) in April 2016, the investment does not anticipates any major future benefits or enhancement’s at this time, unless if it’s absolutely necessary and directed by business. CLAIMS4 investment will commence decommissioning of the system during the end of 1st or 2nd quarter of FY18.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System
ROI Description:
CLAIMS 4 is a legacy system that has been in production for over 5 years. Over those years, it has allowed USCIS to meet its mission of providing immigration benefits to approximately 8 million customers annually. This includes: N400, N336, N600, CCA, finger prints/interviews and N600K's fee collection for approximately $500M annually.
CLAIMS 4 calculated ROI is 0% and it has fully recovered its costs. USCIS ELIS has deployed processing N400 early this year and has plans for incorporating the remaining N-Forms by end of this year 2016.
Investment Requirements:
Below are the links that explains the laws, immigration benefits, USCIS mission and core values. https://www.uscis.gov/aboutus
http://www.uscis.gov/portal/site/uscis/menuitem.f6da51a2342135be7e9d7a10e0dc91a0/?vgnextoid=fa7e539dc4bed010VgnVCM1000000ecd190aRCRD&vgnextchannel=fa7e539dc4bed010VgnVCM1000000ecd190aRCRD&CH=8cfr. 
https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/dhs-itstratplan-508_0.pdf 
https://cio.gov/delivering-customer-focused-government-smarter/. 
https://www.uscis.gov/laws.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: No significant changes.
Operational Analysis Results:
In accordance with DHS Operational Analysis Guidance, a detailed Operational Analysis was conducted for CLAIMS 4. The result of the CLAIMS 4 Operational Analysis determined that the CLAIMS 4 program continues to provide the USCIS Mission critical services of immigration benefits processing, accurate fee receipt, and benefits processing case management. Although CLAIMS 4 is a legacy system initiated in the mid to late 1990’s, it continues to exceed volume processing expectations as well as investment lifecycle estimations. 

Customer Results is good in terms of access, availability, reliability, and data sharing. For Strategic & Business Results, CLAIMS 4 does not fit with USCIS goals of moving to a paperless, customer-centric process. However, CLAIMS 4 remains an effective program for meeting current USCIS demands as USCIS transitions to the transformed environment. As for Internal Business Process, CLAIMS 4 provides the ability to receipt, adjudicate, and produce customer proofs of benefit for 90% Naturalization Form. Since CLAIMS 4 was initiated in the mid to late 1990’s there is legacy code that is not user friendly. Graphical User Interface improves the customer experience and strengthens the security profile. However, CLAIMS 4 did migrate primary adjudication functionality to Web couple of years back. In summation, the analysis supports the continuation of CLAIMS 4 until the Transformation Project can subsume it.

The Financial Performance of CLAIMS 4 is within budget and on schedule. During FY2015 and first half of FY2016, it was on schedule and mostly within budget. Prior to April 2016, CLAIMS 4 uses Agile methodology to maintain its schedule and remain within budget. However, with USCIS Transformation deployment of N400 to PROD, CLAIMS 4 has stopped all the new work and doing only maintenance work to keep the systems running.

Innovation: CLAIMS 4 is expected to be subsumed by USCIS Transformation.

Operational & Performance Measures:CLAIMS 4 met most of its operational and performance measures. There were issues with customer support requests during the contract transition from July 2016 - Present, but those issues were being worked on to resolve them by adding additional resources. 

Risk Analysis: CLAIMS 4 program, continues to review its risks monthly and adjust program needs as needed. All risks are dealt with timely.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Naturalization - Computer Linked Application Information Management System 4.0 (CLAIMS 4) is in the Support life cycle phase. CLAIMS 4 is operating within acceptable ranges for cost and schedule variances. CLAIMS 4 is a legacy system that retired 98 workflow servers; developed and deployed Military module data entry to web; and migrated the Dev/Test servers to Amazon Web Services (AWS) Cloud in 2016. Currently, there are no major enhancements scheduled for this investment. The Program Management Office (PMO) will maintain business needs until the system is decommissioned. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the CLAIMS 4 program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of the CSS is to provide the public with access to official information regarding USCIS. The goal of the CSS is to ensure a benefit seeker using the USCIS web site is able to quickly and easily find the information they need and the information itself is thorough, up-to-date and correct. Additionally, the program serves as the authoritative web resource for all information concerning immigration and citizenship. 

The CSS investment supports DHS mission delivery through its alignment to the Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR) mission goal 3.1 “Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, specifically Objective 1-Promote Lawful Immigration—clearly communicate to the public information on immigration services and procedures.  The investment serves as the Internet based gateway to provide the public information regarding immigration services and procedures, as well as serving as the electronic home of the US Citizenship and Immigration Services component within the broader DHS.gov web presence. 

The program’s key customers are individuals who wish to receive the benefits the agency provides and individuals who support those benefit-seekers, be they family members, friends or immigration lawyers. CSS principal stakeholders are: the USCIS Office of Communications, Customer Service and Public Engagement (CSPE), and the Office of Information Technology. The program’s beneficiaries include: the agency’s stakeholders (not just OCOMM but ranging from senior management to immigration and adjudication officers to clerks in the file rooms) by providing accurate agency information. The agency’s immigrant customers as the information that reaches them through the CSS enhances their understanding of USCIS policies and bolsters and improved their ability to navigate the immigration process. The general public is also a beneficiary, as the CSS serves as an authoritative resource for inquiries regarding immigration law and procedures.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System
ROI Description: The quantitative ROI for the program is 0.0, indicating that the program has recovered its costs.  The program is not likely to generate further return beyond this cost recovery.  However, the qualitative benefits of the investment are manifold, and include benefits such as :  serving as the authoritative web based resource for information regarding USCIS immigration benefits and USCIS immigration and naturalization processes and procedures.  Providing a web based case tracking capability for benefits seekers. Providing a comprehensive set of instructions, forms, and frequently asked questions for benefits seekers, the general public, immigration lawyers and other interested parties.  Providing a public forum for the dissemination of critical announcements and changes in policy and procedures.
Investment Requirements: Mandated legislation based on E-Government Act of 2002 http://www.archives.gov/about/laws/egov-act-section-207.html.
Operational Analysis Results:
After a thorough review of the operations of the Customer Service Systems the project team found the system to be operating effectively. 

Customer Results are captured through survey mechanisms. The CSWP regularly scores above 80 in the American Customer Satisfaction Index. This is a very high grade for commercial web sites, let alone government sites. The information gleaned through the survey capability is used by OCOMM and OIT to better target and improve content as well as improve functionality and navigation issues. Details are available in the OA.
 
Strategic and business results are gauged through the mapping to DHS and USCIS goals and objectives (detailed in the accompanying OA). CSWP is judged performing very well for each of these. The team is continually working with USCIS business partners to ensure content is readily available to our customers, our key stakeholders, and our beneficiaries.
 
Financial performance is judged through the review of earned value management for web development activities. The IT PM for CSWP does a monthly analysis of the reported EVM and works with the contract COTR, the contract Program Manager, and the CSS Program Manager to ensure the government is receiving appropriate value. When issues are raised, the team works together to identify solutions. 
 
Innovation is a work-in-progress. The CSWP is a prime candidate for innovation. The team, as described previously, is working closely with DHS to migrate the CSWP to a single DHS-supplied content management system. FEMA has already deployed their site on this system, and USCIS is looking to leverage their success and lessons learned to facilitate a move. Additionally, the USCIS team will be setting up a new document management capability which the entire DHS organization will be able to leverage.

Over the last 12 months, CSS has exceeded the targeted operational performance measures for all metrics.

With the expectation of future system change requests and releases, the systems will continue to be periodically analyzed for risks.  Current risks are monitored and reviewed on a regular basis.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Customer Service Systems (CSS) program is in the Support life cycle phase. CSS is operating within acceptable ranges for cost and schedule variances. During FY16, CSS improved the Web Portal user experience through the implementation of responsive design and provided enhancements to the computer-generated virtual assistant, Emma. During CY2017, the Program Management Office (PMO) will continue responsive design improvement efforts for the Citizenship Resource Center (CRC) subsite and complete regular maintenance and security releases. An Operational Analysis has been performed for this investment.    The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the CSS program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
Purpose: CLAIMS 3 is the primary case management system used for the adjudication of immigrant and non-immigrant benefits and services. The data within CLAIMS 3 is used to assist in verifying and corroborating immigration benefit requests through the use of business rules to ensure that the process is consistent with all applicable laws and regulations.

Goals: CLAIMS 3 allows USCIS to meet its mission of providing immigration benefits and the following strategic goals: 1) achieve and maintain timely processing of immigration benefits; 2) provide information resources and services to appropriate individuals and entities; 3) develop seamless, IT-supported processes that efficiently support immigration benefits adjudication and information sharing; and 4) strengthen key management processes, systems, and administrative support activities, including our information technology infrastructure. CLAIMS 3 supports mission delivery of the following DHS Strategic Goals: Goal 2.1 Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders “Prevent the illegal flow of people and goods across U.S. air, land, and sea borders while expediting the safe flow of lawful travel and commerce.?; 3.1: Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System “Promote lawful immigration, expedite administration of immigration services, and promote the integration of lawful immigrants into American society.?; Goal 3.2: Prevent Unlawful Immigration “Reduce conditions that encourage foreign nationals to illegally enter and remain in the United States, while identifying and removing those who violate our laws.?

Benefits: CLAIMS 3 provides the ability for adjudicators to quickly and efficiently review immigration benefit requests and provide the customers proofs of benefit (e.g. approval notice, travel document, and secure identity card). CLAIMS 3 shares data with internal and external partners by providing detailed biographic and biometric data via the Enterprise Service Bus. CLAIMS 3 follows all DHS and USCIS processes to assure the IT infrastructure is secure, reliable, and stable.

Customers: USCIS adjudicators, USCIS staff with oversight responsibilities, and DHS agencies with enforcement/intelligence responsibilities. The stakeholders include all USCIS Directorates. Other beneficiaries are: applicants for immigration benefits, applicant representatives, community-based organizations, and oversight agencies (e.g. USCIS Ombudsman and US Congress).
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description:
CLAIMS 3 is a legacy system that has been in production for over 25 years.  Over those years, it has allowed USCIS to meet its mission of providing immigration benefits to approximately 6 million customers annually.  This includes: providing proof of immigration status to Customers; providing secure identity documents to customers (ie, Permanent Resident Cards, Work Authorization Documents, and Travel Documents); and fee collection for approximately $2B annually.

CLAIMS 3 calculated ROI is 0% which led USCIS to current path for CLAIMS 3 to be subsumed by Transformation (ELIS) by 2022. 

For internal customers, CLAIMS 3 allows USCIS staff to electronically adjudicate applications and track them through the immigration process which increases production and accuracy. CLAIMS 3 also interfaces with several government entities (Customs and Border Protection, Dept of State, Social Security Administration, Selective Service, etc.) to provide immigration related data to assure that these entities have accurate information to conduct their missions.

For external customers, CLAIMS 3 provides notification of the status of the immigration benefit request as well as the final Proof of Benefit; which could be a notice of action, travel document, or identity card.
Investment Requirements: CLAIMS 3 is the primary case management system used for the adjudication of immigrant and non-immigrant benefits and services. CLAIMS 3 provides the customer information on the status of the request and is used to perform background checks. The data within CLAIMS 3 is used to assist in verifying and corroborating applicant petitions through the use of business rules to ensure that the process is consistent with all applicable laws and regulations. CLAIMS 3 allows USCIS to attain the following strategic objectives: Ensure that benefits are granted only to eligible applicants and petitioners; identify and communicate immigration-related information to partners in support of DHS strategic goals; achieve and maintain timely processing of immigration benefits; provide information resources and services to appropriate individuals and entities; develop seamless, IT-supported processes that efficiently support immigration benefits adjudication and information sharing; and strengthen key management processes, systems, and administrative support activities, including our information technology infrastructure.  All IT systems must make their systems accessible for employees with disabilities.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Not applicable.
Operational Analysis Results:
In accordance with DHS Operational Analysis Guidance, a detailed Operational Analysis was conducted for CLAIMS 3.  The result of the CLAIMS 3 Operational Analysis determined that the CLAIMS 3 program continues to provide the USCIS Mission critical services of immigration benefits processing, accurate fee receipt, and benefits processing case management.  Although CLAIMS 3 is a legacy system initiated in the early 1990’s, it continues to exceed volume processing expectations as well as investment lifecycle estimations.  CLAIMS 3 is now accessible to 100% of the USCIS locations and the system availability and reliability are well within defined expectations.

Customer Results is good in terms of access, availability, reliability, and data sharing. However, it noted that there are some issues with flexibility in terms of meeting emerging needs.  For Strategic & Business Results, CLAIMS 3 does not fit with USCIS goals of moving to a paperless, customer-centric process.  However, CLAIMS 3 remains an effective program for meeting current USCIS demands as USCIS transitions to the transformed environment.  As for Internal Business Process, CLAIMS 3 provides the ability to receipt, adjudicate, and produce customer proofs of benefit for over 90% of Immigration forms.  Since CLAIMS 3 was initiated in the 1990’s there is legacy code that is not user friendly.  Graphical User Interface improves the customer experience and strengthens the security profile.  In summation, the analysis supports the continuation of CLAIMS 3 until the Transformation Project can subsume it.

The Financial Performance of CLAIMS 3 is within budget and on schedule.  During FY2015 and first half of FY2016, it was on schedule and within budget. CLAIMS 3 uses Agile methodology to maintain its schedule and remain within budget.  It is within limits for Cost and Schedule.

Innovation: CLAIMS 3 is expected to be subsumed by USCIS Transformation.

Operational & Performance Measures: CLAIMS 3 met most of its operational and performance measures.  There were issues with customer support requests during the contract transition from March 2016 - June 2016, but those issues were resolved and measures are improving.

Risk Analysis: CLAIMS 3 program, continues to review its risks monthly and adjust program needs as needed.  All risks are dealt with timely.  CLAIMS 3 was able to retire contract risk in FY2016 since the new contract is FFP.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Immigration - Computer Linked Application Information Management System 3.0 (CLAIMS 3) is a legacy system in the Support life cycle phase. CLAIMS 3 is operating within acceptable ranges for cost and schedule variances. During FY16, the Program Management Office (PMO) updated immigration forms approved for public use and ensured all screens were Section 508 Compliant. For FY17, the PMO will maintain current capabilities to meet business needs and complete quarterly maintenance release for system security and stability. An Operational Analysis has been performed for this investment.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the CLAIMS 3 program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
This investment supports the Enforcement and administration of immigration laws by providing these capabilities and benefits: 
-Improve security by uniquely identifying beneficiaries and petitioners and by applying automated security checks, fraud and risk rules-against all benefit requests.
-Improve customer service by allowing e-filing, reducing cycle times and providing real-time case update information.
-Increase ability to share data with partner agencies electronically.
-Improve system integrity by creating customer accounts enabling a person-centric view of an individual’s benefits related data.
-Provide a single, worldwide case management system for immigration benefits with an anticipated user-base of 50,000 authorized users, within USCIS and its partner agencies.
-Improve employee satisfaction by creating an electronic case management system.
The goal of the USCIS Transformation investment is to modernize USCIS by deploying an enterprise-wide investment that will transition the Agency from a fragmented, paper-based operational environment to a centralized and consolidated environment, facilitating electronic processing of benefits. The new operational environment will contribute to accomplishing USCIS’ mission of enforcing and administering our immigration laws. In addition, the new operational environment will reshape the way we share information by providing digital immigration files for faster information sharing, and integrated, secure access to relevant information internally and with Federal partner agencies.  The investment contributes to USCIS’ mission delivery by addressing four major mission initiatives: (1) National Security and Integrity; (2) Customer Service; (3) Operational Efficiency; and (4) Quality Improvement.
The key customers, stakeholders, and beneficiaries of the Electronic Immigration System (ELIS)are: enterprise partners; Department of Homeland Security components; USCIS employees; customers and advocates (the persons petitioning USCIS for benefits and services and the organizations representing those individuals), stakeholders with oversight and review responsibilities including Congress, the Office of Management and Budget, the Government Accountability Office, and the DHS Office of the Inspector General; and other stakeholders including public IT industry groups, U.S. citizens, and media outlets.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System
ROI Description:
Transformation’s estimated cost avoidances fall into five categories:  avoidances from reduced mailings (FY12-33), decommissioning of legacy systems (FY18-20), reduced data entry (FY12-33), reduced call center calls (FY12-33) and reduced file movement and storage (FY12-33).

Therefore, the Return on Investment (ROI) is calculated by determining the net benefit, which in this case is the total cumulative cost avoidances for reduced mailings, systems decommissioning, reduced data entry, call center calls, and file movement and storage over the lifecycle of the system (FY12-33), dividing the net benefit by the total initial capital investment, subtracting 1, and converting the remaining figure to a percentage.

A negative 42% ROI indicates that this investment will recover some of its initial purchase and implementation of new capital assets to create a new capability.  However, this ROI calculation is in the early phases of this investment’s development and does not fully quantify the additional internal and external benefits that have not yet been assessed.

The benefits for the system included Transformation Program Objectives:
 
·         Increase security by accurately identifying individuals at each interaction with USCIS.  
·         Increase security by timely sharing of data with partner agencies.
·         Improve immigration benefits system integrity by standardizing processes and systems throughout the agency
·         Improve immigration system integrity by cultivating a culture that respects and protects privacy.
·         Improve ability to detect and investigate fraudulent activity by improving the quality and availability of data.
·         Minimize the burden to customers interacting with the agency.
·         Inform customers in a manner most likely to result in understanding and appropriate action.
·         Provide benefits, quickly, consistently, and accurately to those who are entitled
·         Deliver an open and transparent work environment.
·         Enable managers to match work and resources on a needs basis.
·         Provide a work environment that promotes success.
Investment Requirements: The investment is making efficient use of the security related aspects of the overall architecture of the Transformation Program.  Specifically, the investment benefits from detailed account identification and administration to ensure greater data integrity as well as improved data access.  The increased attention the investment pays to data integrity and access, will aid in noting and marking cases for further investigation.  This attention to security assists in the uncovering of illegal access both from outside the organization as well as within.  By focusing on timely re-examination of identity details the investment helps to identify the possibilities created by insider threats.  In addition, the investment will be sharing information within USCIS as well as within DHS (e.g. ICE, CBP) and within the Federal government (e.g. FBI, Department of State, etc) to ensure that the most current information is available both from these connected partner systems as well as information that will be provided by these systems to aid in the Transformation security effort.
PM Qualificiations: 7 - No certification, but with 4 or more years PM experience (within the last five years)
Operational Analysis Results:
- Financial Performance Analysis: The Hybrid Alternative was selected due to its significantly higher overall fit with the Agency’s strategic goals and higher qualitative benefits score (particularly considering the importance of customer service and national security). USCIS recalculated a program Life Cycle Cost Estimate covering the period FY2016-2034.  The Return on Investment  is estimated at -42%. USCIS will continue to assess costs savings that result from the investment.
- Customer Satisfaction Results: Transformation (OTC) has conducted a nationwide internal user survey with USCIS federal employees measuring how the ELIS system is meeting the needs of the workforce. The results of the survey were mixed -40% or more agreed to positive statements about ELIS navigation, reviewing and searching for case information, and sufficient training. The survey provided a benchmark to begin assessing how to focus efforts to improve ELIS to meet the needs of the agency’s workforce.  Our external user survey returned an aggregate user satisfaction level of 93.50% for 2016. This result exceeds the Program’s customer satisfaction goal of 85% and far exceeds the 64.4% citizen satisfaction rate reported in the 2014 Federal Government Services published by the American Consumers Survey Index.
- Business and Strategic Analysis: OTC’s strategic goals align with the updated USCIS Strategic priorities for 2012 and Mission 3-Enforcing and Administering Immigration Laws of the DHS Strategic Goals for 2012-2016. The goals also relate to the goals in the USCIS Pre-Decision Strategic Plan 2014-2018.
- Operational Performance Measures: OTC is currently meeting the targets reported in the OMB Exhibit 300 Business Case.
- Innovation: In FY2017, OTC will continue to plan for rapid and continuous deployment to deliver agile releases to implement the Immigrant Line of Business which consists of 3 major releases and small enhancement throughout the year. The Program also plans to deliver functionality to share petition data with the Department of State, establish immigration account for organizations, obtain relevant information from authoritative government and commercial sources such as DOL labor certification and Dun & Bradstreet as well as support premium processing.
- Risk Analysis: PL.001 Adherence to GAO best practices, PL.047 OMB Clearance times, PL.050 Interface Dependencies, PL.052 Lifecycle costs, PL.056 Technical Defects, PL.059 Re-Compete Development contracts.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Transformation program is in the Mixed life cycle phase. The program continues to operate without a Department of Homeland Security (DHS) approved Acquisition Program Baseline (APB), as a result of its 4QFY16 APB schedule breach. Since the last assessment, the program continues to provide updates to the Acquisition Review Board (ARB) through quarterly program reviews; the last review took place in July 2017. The program is aiming to re-baseline, exit its APB breach and strategic pause, no later than 4QFY17. However, during the July 2017 ARB, Transformation leadership requested a submission extension for its remaining five acquisition governance action items assigned in the April 2017 Acquisition Decision Memorandum (ADM). USCIS plans to have all documents available to approval authorities by 1QFY18. Additionally, the program will award five new contracts (three currently awarded). The contracts will support the program’s ability to execute against a new operating plan to support data architecture modeling and data analytics services, User Interface (UI) / User Experience (UX) analysis and design,  Continuous Integration(CI)/Continuous Delivery (CD)  system delivery, and continuation of DevOps services – proposed award date 4QFY17. Additionally, USCIS is in final preparation for N-400 full pivot back to the Electronic Immigration System (ELIS) from CLAIMS 4 by 4QFY17. Transformation continues to incorporating the appropriate mitigation strategy; however, they still carry a significant risk exposure score. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the USCIS Transformation program due to breach as a Moderately High Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of the Verification Modernization (VER MOD) investment is to strengthen and improve E-Verify and SAVE to support workload growth through the modernization of the Verification Information System (VIS) and associated applications.  VIS is the single source of eligibility verification for those seeking employment authorization or access to certain benefits in the US. 
 
E-Verify and SAVE are mandated by the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 (IRCA), the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (PRWORA), and the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 (IIRIRA).  E-Verify is an Internet-based system that allows employers to determine the eligibility of their employees to work in the United States. SAVE is a program that enables benefit-granting institutions, licensing bureaus, and other governmental agencies to determine an applicant's immigration status
VER MOD supports the DHS mission to Enforce and Administer our nation’s immigration laws by strengthening the infrastructure for the E-Verify and SAVE programs.
 
The goal of VER MOD is to address the reliability, scalability and functionality challenges that currently impair efficient operations of the E-Verify and SAVE programs. Specifically, the goals are to address six identified capability gaps, decrease reliance on expensive manual verifications, increase system reliability, and expand capacity. The benefits of modernization will be streamlined business processes with reduced risks of identity fraud, data inaccuracies, and system misuse.
 
Failure to modernize will negatively impact the performance and quality of the E-Verify and SAVE programs, compromising DHS’ ability to meet its mission to enforce and administer our nation’s immigrations laws.
   
Primary users/customers include Employers and E-Verify Employer Agents using E-Verify to verify work eligibility of newly hired employees; Federal, state, and local agencies that administer benefits; and Verification Division employees and contractors charged with performing status verifications, identifying potential misuse of E-Verify or SAVE, and providing customer support.  In addition to users, VER MOD stakeholders include data partners such as the Social Security Administration and Department of State, Congress, immigrant advocacy groups, and employee rights organizations.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System
ROI Description:
This investment in modernizing VER, an existing capability, will recover a majority of the acquisition costs both by significantly reducing operations and maintenance costs over the system lifecycle and by enabling the system to efficiently address the anticipated greater than 175% increase in verification workload expected over the planning horizon.  VER MOD will achieve these objectives by: Optimizing the effectiveness of VER operational staff using VIS and associated systems for verifications; by minimizing the need for additional staff to address anticipated verification workload growth; and by increasing system capacity in order to address expected verification workload growth.  

- Expand System Capacity: System capacity will be expanded to address the over 80 million queries per year and 200 thousand MOUs expected by 2027
- Streamline and Reengineer Business Processes: Streamlined and reengineered verification business processes will both increase verification accuracy and efficiency by reducing the need to use high touch non-automated processes and by increasing the accuracy and efficiency of manual verification processes.
- Reduce Data Entry: Employers will reduce the time spent on data entry due to the Mobile E-Verify application and photo-based text importing from Form I-9 to E-Verify. Improving the ease of use of E-Verify is an important aspect of increasing ease of adoption and improving customer satisfaction. 
- Make the System More Stable: Employers and benefits agencies will gain a more stable system. Increased uptime will allow employers more consistent access to the systems.
Investment Requirements:
The Verification Modernization (VER MOD) investment aims to strengthen and improve E-Verify and SAVE to support workload growth through the modernization of the Verification Information System (VIS) and associated applications.  VIS is the single source of eligibility verification for those seeking employment authorization or access to certain benefits in the US.  Presently VIS experiences reliability, scalability and functionality challenges that impair efficient operations of the E-Verify and SAVE programs.   
 
Modernization will streamline and automate business processes to increase the capacity of these programs, while also reducing the risk of identity fraud, data inaccuracies, and system misuse.  Failure to modernize will negatively impact the performance and quality of the E-Verify and SAVE programs, compromising DHS’ ability to meet its mission to enforce and administer our nation’s immigrations laws.
 
E-Verify and SAVE are mandated by the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 (IRCA), the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (PRWORA), and the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 (IIRIRA).  E-Verify is an Internet-based system that allows employers to determine the eligibility of their employees to work in the United States. SAVE is a program that enables benefit-granting institutions, licensing bureaus, and other governmental agencies to determine an applicant's immigration status.    
   
Primary users include Employers and E-Verify Employer Agents using E-Verify to verify work eligibility of newly hired employees; Federal, state, and local agencies that administer benefits; and Verification Division employees and contractors charged with performing status verifications, identifying potential misuse of E-Verify or SAVE, and providing customer support.  In addition to users, VER MOD stakeholders include data partners such as the Social Security Administration and Department of State, Congress, immigrant advocacy groups, and employee rights organizations.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: The variance seen in FY16 from the prior year request is due to a change of program scope, as directed in the Acquisition Decision Memorandum signed by the DHS Under Secretary for Management on October 6, 2015.  The program scope now includes costs associated with the operation of E-Verify and SAVE, which are primarily related to government FTE.
Operational Analysis Results:
Financial Performance Results:
This investment does not generate revenue; it achieves additional cost avoidance and/or savings in government operations by providing benefits to society beyond recovery of the initial investment. The Program Management Office has developed a robust business case model to evaluate the costs and benefits of different alternatives in consultation with DHS-PARM. The model showed that modernization will improve efficiencies, enable scalability and avoid manpower costs. 

Customer Satisfaction Results:
ACSI; Satisfaction with E-Verify remains high with the satisfaction index being 21 points above the 2014 federal government average. VER Customer Satisfaction Metrics met or exceeded target for 100% of the FY15 VER Customer Satisfaction Metrics

Business and Strategic Results:
The VER MOD investment supports the SAVE and E-Verify programs, which are integral components of the President’s immigration reform agenda. 
The Verification Division’s five year Strategic Plan and Strategic Goals align with DHS, USCIS, and IRIS Goals and Objectives. The VER MOD Strategic Planning effort  has established performance metrics to monitor all program and system objectives and enable leadership to assess performance against achievement of the goals and objectives defined in the Strategic Plan. 

Operational Performance Measures:
Investment is meeting defined operational performance targets. VER defined five FY15 metrics that are aligned with VER Strategic Goal to “Strengthen the Security and Integrity of the SAVE and E-Verify Programs,? and met or exceeded targets for all goals.  

Innovation:
New technologies or alternatives that could potentially improve functionality or performance or lower cost include Amazon Web Services Cloud Hosting and Mobile Applications.  Modernization is also currently improving Status Verification Operations and E-Verify and SAVE Enrollment Operations with VER MOD Release work.

Risk Analysis:
VER created Risk Management (RM) Action Plans that defined, monitored, and tracked specific tasks and objectives to effectively manage identified risks. The plans contained specific actions, due dates, responsible parties, and status to ensure active management of medium and high priority risks. VER also maintains an active Risk Register which includes risks and issues identified by the IPT.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Verification Modernization (VER) program is in the Mixed life cycle phase. The program continues to operate within acceptable OMB range for cost and schedule variance. Since the last assessment, the program completed modernization of the Status Verification System (SVS) and decommissioned the legacy SVS to reach Initial Operating Capability (IOC) in 3QFY17. Overall, the new SVS is allowing cases to be processed an average of 24% faster. The remaining pieces of the legacy E-Verify and Systematic Alien Verification for Entitlements (SAVE) applications were successfully migrated to the Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud. E-Verify has reduced the volume of abandoned enrollments and reduced the overall average enrollment time by 45%. VER returned to the Acquisition Review Board (ARB) in early 4QFY17 for a scheduled program review; the next program milestone is Acquisition Decision Event (ADE) - 2C for low-rate initial production (LRIP) by the end of the fiscal quarter. The program continues to meet operational performance targets and improve capabilities, scalability, security, availability, and accuracy. While the program is showing moderate risk exposure, risk strategies and mitigations are managed through agile, incremental approaches. VER continues to work towards preparation for mandatory E-Verify by conducting performance testing and improving auto-scaling and automation. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the USCIS Verification Modernization Program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: The Document Management Division investment funds the production of secure documents for USCIS. The purpose is to enable CIS to meet the non-discretionary duty to issue secure identification documents in accordance with the Immigration Naturalization Act, 8 USC 1304 (d) codified at section 264. USCIS has the sole statutory responsibility for producing secure identification documents (SID) under existing immigration laws.  The investment provides program management, oversight, acquisitions, projects and programs required to ensure the successful, timely, and efficient performance of the production operations for the creation of secure identification documents, as well as Forms Center operations. These documents include the Permanent Resident Card (PRC) Form I - 551, also commonly known as the Green Card, the Employment Authorization Document (EAD) Form I - 766, Travel Document Booklets including the Re - entry Permit Form I - 327 and the Refugee Travel Document Form I - 571.The goal of the investment is to establish a program that is sole source for printing U.S. immigration related proof of benefit documents and ID cards within DHS and for other government agencies. The investment contributes to the administration of the immigration laws of the United States, thus supporting USCIS mission to secure America's promise as a nation of immigrants by ensuring the integrity of our immigration system, through tamper resistant proof of benefit documents and identification cards. DMD provides benefits to USCIS, DHS and other federal agencies by producing tamper-resistant documents that are machine-readable, and biometrically enabled using the latest technologies to combat counterfeiting and fraud at lower cost. Key stakeholders of the DMD document printing services include Office of Information Technology (OIT), Government Printing Office (GPO), U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Customers and Boarder Protection (CBP), and ICE’s Forensic Lab.  and played key roles in redesigning our SIDs with enhanced security features that enhance border security. Key customers and beneficiaries include law enforcement, employers and recipients of immigration benefits by providing evidence of granted immigration benefits. These documents can be used as proof of legal working status, resident status and travel enabled status of recipients in the United States.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description: The quantitative Return on Inventment (ROI) for the program is 0.0, indicating that the program has recovered its costs. The program is not likely to generate further return beyond this cost recovery. However, the qualitative benefits of the investment include: personalization of secure identification documents which are produced within 24 hours of application receipt, and less than 3% reject rate, use of state of the art identification technologies to ensure tamper resistance, combat counterfeiting and fraud, enable electronic verification through technical capabilities of the produced documents, ensuring secure delivery through Secure Mail Initiative (SMI), and the positioning of USCIS as Center of Excellence in Secure Identification Documentation production.
Investment Requirements:
Legislative Mandate -As part of the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) statutory mission, USCIS produces a variety of secure identification documents used to provide evidence of eligibility for immigration benefits to its customers. https://www.uscis.gov/ilink/docView/SLB/HTML/SLB/0-0-0-1/0-0-0-29/0-0-0-8289.html
Presidential Direction - USCIS follows presidential mandates, initiatives, and executive orders as directed. The USCIS IDP program aligns with DHS goals to improve national security and homeland security postures of the United States. https://www.uscis.gov/ilink/docView/SLB/HTML/SLB/0-0-0-1/0-0-0-29/0-0-0-8289.html
Other Requirements - Specific immigration laws include: Public Law 104-208, Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996, which modified the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) of 1952 requiring biometric machine-readable documents for border crossing documents; the INA at 8 USC 1304 (d), codified at section 264, requires that every individual who has been granted lawful permanent residence status “be issued a certificate of alien registration or an alien registration receipt card in such form and manner and at such time as shall be prescribed under the regulations issued by the Attorney General.? Federal courts have held that this provision imposes upon DHS nondiscretionary duty to issue such documentation in a timely manner; the INA at 8 USC 1324 a and 8 CFR 247 a (12) requires that individuals in those classes referenced in the statue to be authorized to be employed in the United States and they must apply to USCIS for a document evidencing such employment authorization (same URL as listed above).
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: N/A.
Operational Analysis Results:
Customer Result -DMD conducts a program reviews twice a year to solicit customer feedback from both internal and external customers and is committed to performing 100 percent quality assurance is performed and mailing documents within 72 hour of order receipt.
Strategic and Business Results – DMD supports the DHS strategic goals of Organizational Excellence and Service. Card Personalization System Technology Refreshment (CPSTR) produces highly secure cards to document the status, eligibility to enter the U.S., authorization to work of immigrants/non-immigrants.  Average turnaround time for all mailing card orders is 3 days using the Secure Mail Initiative (SMI) with delivery confirmation from USPS.  
Financial Performance - The DMD investment is operating well within the pre-established cost baseline of $45 million.  For the past operating period year (52 weeks) the production goals for all cards were met in accordance with the requirements of the production contract.  All contractual requirements were met within the allocated program budget with no deviations.
Innovation - The DMD secure identity personalization process unites seamless, continuous, automated and integrated personalization technology that provides quality secure identification cards and performs as designed to support agency business processes.   DMD is in the process of shifting to one solid body card type that will be configurable for future benefits.   
Operational Performance Measurements -The Investment is currently exceeding targets on the entire agency established production turnaround time goals of 72 hours for PRC and EAD card production goals and 48 hours for booklet production goals.  Currently, cards and booklets are produced and mailed within 24 hours of receipt of the electronic card order. This measurement alone has reduced the turn-around time for an EAD or PRC card to be produced by almost 66% and travel documents by 50%. Card/Booklet Reject Rates averaged a little over1.25% for FY16 which is significantly better than the established threshold reject rate of 3%.
Risk Analysis - The Program Management Branch (PMB) is responsible for conducting all risk management and analysis activities for risks that may impact DMD projects and programs.  PMB maintains and updates the risk register and risk management plan at least annually and proactively conducts environmental scanning to minimize the potential for disruption to USCIS secure identification document production.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Document Management Division (DMD) program is an O&M investment in the Support life cycle phase. DMD is operating within acceptable ranges for cost and schedule variances. Since becoming operational in FY1998, DMD has produced over 54 million authorized cards for mailing. During CY16, DMD produced in excess of 2 million Permanent Resident Cards; 1.8 million Employment Authorization Documents (EADs); and 2 million Permanent Resident Cards while maintaining less than 3% reject rate. The Program Management Office also completed a 2nd full scale operational facility to create capacity and redundancy while ensuring continuity of operations. An Operational Analysis has been completed for this investment.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the DMD program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) is the component of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) that oversees lawful immigration to the United States. USCIS’ mission in part is to secure America’s promise ‘as a nation of immigrants’ by providing accurate and useful information to its customers, granting immigration and citizenship benefits, and ensuring the integrity of the immigration system. For Infrastructure-End User Support (I-EUS) to accomplish the mission, USCIS employs more than 24,000 federal and contractor personnel in 260 offices world-wide in 30 countries. The purpose of the I-EUS investment is to sustain an IT services and management framework that supports the mission of USCIS which consist of processing over 7 million immigration applications and petitions annually, equating to more than 29,000 form completions each working day. The goal of this investment is to maintain systems with 99.99% accessibility, availability, and reliability, being fiscally responsible to the American public, while employing emerging technologies. The current and anticipated benefits are streamlined business processes, increased customer satisfaction, and improved organizational performance, and in doing so, enriching the lives of America’s immigrants seeking benefits. This investment consists of an Enterprise Service Desk which includes Tier I, Incident and Problem Management support, Deskside Support, Deployment Services, Hardware Maintenance, and Asset Management. I-EUS provides a Master Delivery Order vehicle for purchasing information technology hardware and minimal maintenance support. This investment is the sustainment vehicle through agency approved procurements. Information systems facilitate the processing, storage, and transmission of data necessary to carry-out mission-related functions. The I-EUS investment is critical to the operation of the USCIS immigration system, and without this investment, the impact of system degradation is a viable probability. The key customers and beneficiaries are the millions of immigrants and non-immigrants that use the USCIS immigration system to obtain benefits, immigration awareness, claims adjudication, work visas, and temporary residence. USCIS ensures that our stakeholders are informed and engaged in our program. Stakeholders of this investment are the U.S. President, Secretary, Deputy Secretary, Director, Chief Information Officer, Division Chief, and end users.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System
ROI Description: The I-EUS investment’s Return on Investment (ROI) has a quantitative ROI for the program of $0.0. USCIS, which is largely dependent upon fees to fund its services, provides a support program to address the operations and maintenance of the immigration information system it supports. This investment delivers qualitative benefits that improve customer service by supporting an enterprise-wide centralized service desk, deskside server support, product services and procurement, hardware maintenance support for over 50,000 pieces of hardware, and software installation, for over 24,000 federal and contractor personnel in more than 260 offices worldwide in 30 countries. I-EUS provides service support for over 29,000 desktop and laptops, 150 Video Telecommunication (VTC) units, over 5,900 mobile devices, and to over 50 conferences and naturalization ceremonies annually. This investment effectively reduces duplicity, effectively streamlining processes, while employing cost efficient alternatives. The I-EUS investment directly supports the mission of the USCIS which is, in part, to secure America’s promise as a nation of immigrants by providing accurate and useful information to our customers, granting immigration and citizenship benefits, promoting an awareness and understanding of citizenship, and ensuring the integrity of our immigration system. The I-EUS program supports the operations and maintenance infrastructure of the United States immigration system.
Investment Requirements: The specific requirements for this investment are derived from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security Strategic Plan for Fiscal Years (FY) 2012-2016 (URL https://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/dhs-strategic-plan-fy-2012-2016.pdf ); Mission 3: Enforcing and Administering our Immigration Laws; Goal 3.1: Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System; Objective 3.1.2: Effectively administer the immigration services system by creating a user-friendly system that ensures impartial, consistent, and prompt decisions. This Strategic Plan presents the Department’s goals, derived from the conclusions of the Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR) and the Bottom-Up Review (BUR). The goals include objectives and key performance indicators that are essential for implementation and execution of the Department’s responsibilities.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Comparing PY and CY to the final FY2016 President's Budget realized a decrease, in part,  due to organizational re-alignments within the Office of Information Technology structure.
Operational Analysis Results:
The results included in the I-EUS Operational Analysis provide the data to substantiate the critical nature of this investment, and illustrate our alignment to the mission of USCIS through six areas of focus: Financial Performance, Customer Results, Business and Strategic Analysis, Innovation, Operational Performance Measures, and Risk. 
Financial Performance: This investment uses a variety of vehicles including Firm Fixed Price contracts. I-EUS also uses agency shared contracts with the intent of removing legacy system redundancies to cloud-based technology decreasing cost output. 
Customer Results: This investment, through the enhancement of myIT, users experience faster response time and reduced wait time from 15 minutes to 30 seconds. Over a 12-month period Customer Satisfaction ratings continue to measure above 4.40 with the most recent at 4.55. 
The Business and Strategic outcome of this investment is to ensure the availability and reliability of the immigration system. I-EUS consists of an enterprise Service Desk which includes Tier I, Incident and Problem Management support, Deskside Support, Deployment Services, Hardware Maintenance, and Asset Management and a Master Delivery Order vehicle for purchasing information technology hardware. 
Innovation: This investment demonstrates technical innovation by implementing Workplace as a Service (WPaaS) which provide users virtual computing to replace traditional desktops and laptops and provide secure access to DHS information and applications on almost any computer, including mobile devices. 
Operational Performance Measures: I-EUS is a sustainability investment that continues to meet or exceed established baselines. Performance metrics are assessed and measured monthly as well as annually and include delivery time, response time, service availability, reliability, timeliness and standards compliance and deviations. In order to maintain strong performance, an Enterprise Data Center provides servicecapabilities in the area of Computing Services, Application Services, Disaster Recovery/Continuity Services, and Data Storage Management. 
Risk: The assessment of risk throughout the life of this investment is addressed on a monthly basis by the integrated project team through the use of a risk mitigation plan and a risk register and reported monthly in the Invest system. Risk areas addressed include Project Resources; Technical Obsolescence; Lifecycle costs and Service Desk and Desk-side Support.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Infrastructure - End User Support (I-EUS) program is in the Support life cycle phase. I-EUS is operating within acceptable ranges for cost and schedule variances. Since the last assessment, the Program Management Office (PMO) completed work station refresh of 6,479 infrastructure deployments to 30 offices. The current 4-year refresh strategy cycle has performed well against baseline targets and proven to be a more manageable, cost effective way to deploy new technology in a fiscally responsible manner. The PMO will employ this same strategy in FY18 to refresh 85 additional offices. An Operational Analysis has been performed for this investment.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the I-EUS program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: The Enterprise Infrastructure Program’s purpose is to provide IT infrastructure engineering, design, testing, implementation, and operational support services for all USCIS enterprise components, to include: cloud services, data center hosting, networks, server rooms, data storage, telecommunications, video conferencing services, and infrastructure security.  Goals of the Enterprise Infrastructure Program include assuring availability, reliability, and security of USCIS’s infrastructure; and providing superior customer service in network services, voice and video services, and data center hosting across USCIS.  Key benefits include the ability of the program to perform pilot programs for Department of Homeland Security (DHS); and to provide cloud services such as Email as a Service, Infrastructure as a Service, and WorkPlace as a Service.  The program also serves as the center of excellence for supporting and maintaining the infrastructure, correcting issues, installing circuits, telephones, and other information technology needs on behalf of the USCIS customer base.  The Program’s key customers are principally the USCIS directorates, including: Administrative Appeals; Chief Counsel; Office of Citizenship; Communications; Customer Service and Public Engagement; Office of the Director; Equal Opportunity and Inclusion; Executive Secretariat; Field Operations Directorate; Fraud Detection and National Security; Immigration Records and Identity Services; Legislative Affairs; Management Directorate; Policy and Strategy; Privacy; Refugee, Asylum & International Operations; Service Center Operations; and Transformation.  Key stakeholders are the Office of Information Technology (OIT), including: Workforce Management (WM), Office of Customer Engagement (OCE), Resource Management Division (RMD), Applied Technology Division (ATD), Information Security Division (ISD), End User Services (EUS), and System Development Division (SDD).  This investment specifically supports the USCIS OIT Strategic Plan, Goal 2; Objective 2.1: Develop a consolidated utility model for server, storage, desktop, and bandwidth provisioning, using cloud-based service offerings and shared services where appropriate.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, 5442 - Goal 4.1:  Strengthen the Security and Resilience of Critical Infrastructure against cyber attacks and other hazards, 5502 - M&S Goal 6.6: Strengthen Service Delivery and Manage DHS Resources
ROI Description: This program is not a new startup capability, and is currently in O&M. The initial cost to startup this program has long been recovered. Key benefits include: the ability of the Enterprise Infrastructure to perform programs such as Amazon Web Services, Email as a Service, Infrastructure as a Service, and Work Place as a Service.  The program also serves as the center of excellence for supporting and maintaining the infrastructure, correcting issues, installing circuits, telephones, and other information technology needs on behalf of the USCIS customer base. The program also manages data centers and over 800 servers, several hundred virtual servers and over 80 terabytes of data on a daily basis.
Investment Requirements: Clinger/Cohen Act directs the development and maintenance of Information Technology Architectures (ITAs) by federal agencies to maximize the benefits of information technology (IT) within the Government. In subsequent guidance on implementing the Act, the Office of Management and Budget stipulated that agency ITA's "...should be consistent with Federal, agency, and bureau information architectures.  The Enterprise Infrastructure continues to work under a Legislative Mandate, the Clinger/Cohen Act, when developing and maintaining IT.  The Enterprise Infrastructure also follows the USCIS OIT Strategic Plan, which outlines the goals and expectation of USCIS Enterprise Infrastructure investment.  The Enterprise Infrastructure continues to follow the 25 point Implementation Plan to reform federal information technology management. Specifically, this Presidential Direction relates to data center consolidation and cloud migration within this investment. Migrating services to the cloud, Amazon Web Services, is saving the agency money overtime.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: No. Our funding levels did not decrease. The Infrastructure (Enterprise) was able to complete all its major projects and refined the organizations requirements within budget.
Operational Analysis Results: The OA covers financial performance analysis, customer satisfaction results, business and strategic analysis, operational performance measures, innovation, and risk analysis. Based on the financial performance analysis and in relation to user/stakeholder count and usage/volume count, the percentage of firewall requests completed on-time have a target of greater than 97 percent and a margin of 94 percent, the percentage of change requests completed on-time have a target of greater than 84 percent and a margin of 95 percent, the percentage of incidents completed within 10 days have a target of greater than 96 percent and a margin of 93 percent.  In regards to customer results, the Enterprise Infrastructure has an user assessment/evaluation tentatively scheduled to take place in September 2017 after the call center services have been in use for one year.  In terms of the business and strategic analysis, the Enterprise Infrastructure Program provides infrastructure services for the agency's systems, personnel, and customers.  The investment is meeting financial and business reporting and achievement goals under our old O&M lifecycle as required.  The Enterprise Infrastructure Program has defined several metrics under the operational performance measures, in which all targets are currently being met and reported on monthly.  In regards to innovation, the Enterprise Infrastructure Program is on the forefront of change within the Government in terms of cloud adoption.  New technologies and alternatives are being implemented into the program that could potentially improve functionality or performance or lower cost.  The program continuously works to: use "virtual" server technology and Amazon Web Services (AWS) public cloud services, promote a converged environment integrating voice, video, and data, and has a forward looking approach to tie together identity management, account setup, physical access, and logical access to software systems.  The program identified three significant operational risks (SPEDI, End of Life equipment, and insufficient funding) and several other risks in an updated (July 22, 2016) risk register.  All in all, the Enterprise Infrastructure is always looking for areas for improvement and efficiencies.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Infrastructure (Enterprise) (EID) program is in the Support life cycle phase. EID is operating within acceptable ranges for cost and schedule variances. During FY17, this investment will continue to expand consolidated storage environments to include all field sites, and the DHS Data Centers. Work Place as a Service (WPaaS) has become the primary desktop interface for both remote and on-site employees; significantly reducing overall workstation support costs. The deployment of wireless infrastructure in new and existing field offices will continue, thereby reducing cabling and facility stand-up costs. For FY18, EID will continue application migration to the cloud and expand the wireless footprint across the Enterprise. An Operational Analysis has been performed for this investment.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the EID program as a Low Risk investment.

The USCIS Information Security program is in the Support life cycle phase. It is considered a new program to undergo the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assessment process and as a result, the necessary program metrics required to complete an assessment were not fully captured in the source systems. This program will be reassessed during the next cycle.  Therefore, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the Information Security program as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary: The Enterprise Financial Management System (TOPS) is used to manage and account for appropriated funds provided for the investigative and protective mission of the Secret Service.  TOPS enables the investigative and protective missions by providing the systems necessary to acquire and pay for goods and services necessary to fulfill the day to day primary investigative and protective activities and the administrative support that is the foundation for the primary activities that occur twenty four hours a day, everyday worldwide.  Senior leadership are the key stakeholders for this investment.  DHS, OMB, the Department of the Treasury and TOPS users are beneficiaries of the TOPS investment.  The goals of this investment are to ensure compliance with OMB Circular A-127 and Circular A-123, ensure high system availability and close the books within 5 business days.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks, 5442 - Goal 4.1:  Strengthen the Security and Resilience of Critical Infrastructure against cyber attacks and other hazards, 5502 - M&S Goal 6.6: Strengthen Service Delivery and Manage DHS Resources
ROI Description: This program is not a new startup capability.  The initial startup costs were recovered and it will not generate any additional return.
Investment Requirements:
OMB Circulars A-123, A127 and FFMIA - Operations and Maintenance ensure compliance with federal laws and regulations.

See link below in legislative mandate.
PM Qualificiations: 5 - Other certification with between 2 and 4 years PM experience (within the last five years)
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: The funding level increased to account for inflation and additional help desk and maintenance support.
Operational Analysis Results:
Strategic and Business Results: The results of the analysis indicated that the investment is meeting its intended objectives and is yielding the expected benefits for back office support.  Business processes have been streamlined due to integration, use of web technology and use of workflow capabilities.  DHS has designated TOPS as a Center of Excellence and TOPS aligns with the DHS financial systems strategic vision.

Customer Results: Actual results were verified with customers, business owners and senior management through a survey that was performed in May of 2016.  DHS has designated TOPS a Center of Excellence and TOPS.  Performance goals have been achieved as documented in the performance section.  This is a steady state investment and the OA indicates that performance continues to meet = (good) the performance goals.  Example - improved financial reporting by closing financial books in compliance with DHS requirements.  Customer satisfaction remains in the "good" category due to continued use of integration of various system components and external interfaces.  The ability to close the books in 5 days continues to achieve a score of green for the USSS and further supports the Departments goal of improving financial management.
