The use of technology has reduced the amount of time to complete processes and has improved data quality which enhances the ability to close the books within 5 days and improves financial management within DHS and the Federal Government.  Improved financial processes benefit from innovative configuration of  software providing automated versus paper processes.  

Financial Performance:  Cost avoidance has been achieved by integrating systems which eliminated manual processess, duplication of effort, use of paper and centralized management of back office systems.  System Operations is within cost and savings have been achieved by consolidating support contracts.  Innovation: TOPS is comprised of commercial of the shelf software that has not been customized in order to minimize costs and to allow for vendor supplied software efficiencies. 

Innovation is achieved through configuration, virtualization and reuse of software and other automated processes as well as unique methods of providing user education and help desk support.

Program - Operational Performance measures all exceeded the established metric.

Risk analysis - The team continues to monitor risk during steady state operations and maintenance.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Secret Service (USSS) Enterprise Financial Management System (TOPS) is in the Support lifecycle phase. The program continues to meet and exceed performance metrics and is operating within acceptable Office of Management and Budget (OMB) range for cost and schedule variance. TOPS continues to maintain its system availability above the 98.5% target. Additionally, TOPS leadership closes monthly financials within the 5-days target. TOPS routinely performs operational and technical updates to its core suite of applications, while maintaining its day-to-day operations and support of the enterprise financial systems. TOPS program remains in compliance with OMB circulars A-127 (Financial Management Systems) and A-123 (Management's Responsibility for Internal Control). Program risks continue to be actively monitored while having effective mitigation strategies in place. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the USSS TOP program as a Low Risk investment.

Investment Title: USSS - Information Integration and Technology Transformation (IITT)
Brief Summary:
The IITT Program is essential to increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of the USSS’s information technology (IT) infrastructure, communications systems, applications and processes. This program includes delivery of projects in Enabling Capabilities, Communications Capabilities, Control Capabilities, and Mission Support Capabilities, all critical to modernizing the infrastructure and supporting mission operations.    
-The purpose and primary goal of the IITT program is an extensive re-architecting of the current infrastructure and the careful selection and integration of interoperable capabilities supportive of USSS core functions and priorities. Approved projects in the IITT program include Cross Domain and Multi-Level Security, (Control Capability), and the Combined Operational Logistics Database (COLD2) (divided into four sub-projects) and Protective Threat Management System, (Mission Support Capability) projects.  Comms Interoperability (Communications Capabilities) continue in the procurement and sustainment phase of the acquisition cycle.    
-The IITT program and related capability area projects benefits include improvements in security effectiveness, continuity of operations, interoperability with other government and private systems and networks, system availability in support of USSS business operations, and scalability to support growth.  Performance improvements to the network include database response time, system failover, and network security and availability enhancements.  These effectiveness improvements (quantitative and qualitative) have been documented in the DHS program approval process.    
-All IT and communications systems and applications reside on, and are dependent upon, the USSS IT infrastructure. The IITT program and discrete projects will provide service-wide benefits to USSS users.  Enterprise mission support improvements are expected in areas of forensic and investigative technologies, protective threat management, and information assurance support to customers and stakeholders of the USSS. As the foundational IT infrastructure for USSS it helps support DHS QHSR mission areas, particularly "Safeguarding and Securing Cyberspace/Secure Federal Civilian Government IT Enterprise" by making the USSS IT infrastructure more secure and safe from outsider intrusion and attacks.  
-IITT Stakeholders and beneficiaries include all IT infrastructure users at the USSS and DHS.  IITT customers are all IT users at the USSS.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3264 - Goal 1.3:  Reduce Risk to the Nation's Critical Infrastructure, Key Leadership, and Events, 5442 - Goal 4.1:  Strengthen the Security and Resilience of Critical Infrastructure against cyber attacks and other hazards
ROI Description:
The USSS Information Integration and Technology Transformation program is a strategic investment to modernize and replace the existing IT Infrastructure. IITT does not have a calculated ROI and, given the scope and strategic nature of the needed infrastructure modernization, it is not intended to produce a positive ROI.  In fact, the Analysis of Alternatives which provided the recommended solution concluded that the qualitative benefits to be derived from modernization, are not quantifiable, but improve the welfare of the organization and reduce the operational risk associated with meeting mission objectives.  These qualitative benefits of the investment are essential to increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of the legacy IT infrastructure, communications systems, applications and processes. The IITT program is designed to address documented technology gaps all of which support the desired qualitative return on investment.    
   
Additionally, the benefits of the IITT program and related capability area projects include improvements in security effectiveness, continuity of operations, interoperability with other government and private systems and networks, system availability in support of USSS business operations, and scalability to support growth.  Performance improvements to the network include database response time, system failover, and network security and availability enhancements.  These effectiveness improvements (quantitative and qualitative) have been documented in the DHS program approval process.     
   
All IT systems and applications reside on, and are dependent upon, the USSS IT infrastructure. The IITT program and discrete projects have already begun to provide service-wide benefits to USSS users.  Enterprise mission support improvements are expected in areas of forensic and investigative technologies, protective threat management, and information assurance support to customers and stakeholders of the USSS. As the foundational IT infrastructure for USSS it helps support DHS QHSR mission areas, particularly Safeguarding and Securing Cyberspace by making the USSS IT infrastructure more secure and safe from outsider intrusion and attacks.   
   
IITT is mixed lifecycle and is not yet complete, cancelling funding in the middle of this important project will result in unrealized capabilities and a partially modernized solution that will cost more to maintain than the fully implemented solution.
Investment Requirements: See table below for URLs linking to drivers for this investment.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: IITT funding is relatively flat through the Future Years Homeland Security Plan (FYHSP).  While this  funding profile results in a less than desirable rate for improvement of critical IT programs, the rate is not fully dependent on funding since a contract protest resulted in a schedule slip of approximately one year.  The result is an adequately funded program across the FYHSP.
Operational Analysis Results:
OA Overview: The 2016 Operational Analysis validated that IITT continues to meet the original investment expectations and is fully aligned with USSS mission needs. 
Customer Results: CIO is in close contact with customers/stakeholders of the IT infrastructure.  User and customer satisfaction is determined via user group meetings, meetings with stakeholders, and review of help desk calls.  CIO seeks customer feedback and makes ever attempt to incorporate the comments to continually enhance the systems and ensure user/customer needs are being met.  As part of the performance metrics reported in this Business Case, and to the Federal IT Dashboard, Overall Customer Service Quality is routinely measured via # of Customer Satisfaction Surveys sent related to # Help Desk Tickets opened monthly with a target of 98% and an actual of 100% as of the date of the OA.
Strategic and Business Results:  The OA focused on Fiscal Year 2015 and first half 2016 improvements in Strategic and Business Results as demonstrated by infrastructure performance during various National Special Security Events (NSSEs) in which user satisfaction and mission results were evaluated by senior USSS executives who rated the results as "flawless."  Communications capabilities, in particular, were improved over comparable previous events.
Financial Performance: The IT infrastructure continues to operate 24x7x365. As the IITT modernization effort has continued, USSS has been able to stem the tide of increasing costs due to aging legacy hardware and harder to find equipment and the need for unique and specialized skillsets required for the aging equipment as this equipment has been replaced with new modern technology.  Thus far, the Enabling Capabilities project within this investment has not reduced costs, nor is it expected to, but will increase capabilities and provide for long term stable IT infrastructure.
Innovation is embodied in the Enabling Capabilities and other capabilities deployed as part of the IITT Program.  
Operational performance measures.  IITT meets or exceeds all performance metrics.  With the deployment of COLD2/UDRMS new metrics will be in place and monitored to improve performance.
Risk Analysis showed no currently active risks becoming events in the past year.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Secret Service (USSS) Information Integration and Technology Transformation (IITT) program is in the Mixed life cycle phase. IITT is operating within acceptable ranges for cost and schedule variances. Since the last assessment, Enabling Capabilities (EC) Increments 1 and 2 were successfully deployed. The Critical Design Review (CDR) and Integration Readiness Review (IRR) for EC Increment 3 were completed. All exit criteria items were addressed and approval was granted to proceed to Integration and Test. EC is the DHS approved and funded Level 2 modernization program within IITT that addresses the capabilities and operational security requirements. EC will not achieve Acquisition Decision Event-3 (ADE-3) in Q2FY17. The current schedule did not enable fielding to an operational environment which is needed to conduct Operational Test and Evaluation (OT&E). An administrative reset of the schedule will occur in order to support OT&E. An Operational Analysis has been performed for this investment.  The administrative reset is not expected to affect the IOC and Full Operational Capability (FOC) schedules. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the IITT program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Investment Title: TSA - FAMS Mission Scheduling and Notification System (MSNS)
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description:
The FAMS MSNS investment began in 2001 and has been in Operations and Maintenance for over 10 years.  Based on a further 5 years of utility, using the MSNS system results in a net benefit of approximately 5*$30.7M = $153.5M which was calculated based on input from FAMS Flight Operations division.
In addition, the following qualitative benefits continue to be achieved through improved automation:
Each month, MSNS facilitates coordination of thousands of air marshal availability schedules. This greatly reduces the amount of time it takes to create FAM missions.
Each month, MSNS automatically communicates tens of thousands of mission assignments with FAMS field offices and air marshals. This dramatically reduces the amount of time it takes to notify the workforce of their assigned FAM missions.
MSNS is now able to more efficiently and more cost effectively reserve and purchase tens of thousands of airline tickets for air marshals every month. This drastically reduces the amount of time it would take to perform this task manually.
On a 24x7 basis, MSNS is now able to more accurately track FAMS mission execution and facilitate live mission updates in response to a wide variety of emergent conditions in the global air transport system.  This improved tracking capability increases situational awareness of personnel at the FAMS Transportation Security Operations Center (TSOC). It also keeps them informed of the status of FAMS currently flying on missions at all times on a real-time basis, and in turn greatly increases the speed and frequency at which they receive flight status updates.
Investment Requirements:
ATSA: SEC. 105. (a) (a) In General. The Under Secretary of Transportation for Security under the authority provided by section 44903 (d) (2) shall provide for deployment of Federal air marshals on every such flight determined by the Secretary to present high security risks. The MSNS investment meets this requirement by electronically retrieving the entire airline industry flight schedule and creating FAM missions based on the FAMS Concept of Operations (CONOPS), incorporating FAMS business rules and FAMS quality of life initiatives.
QHSR: Mission 1 PREVENT TERRORISM AND ENHANCE SECURITY, Goal 1.1: Prevent Terrorist Attacks, Strengthen transportation security. The MSNS investment provides electronic mission scheduling and notification IT services that enables TSA to place thousands of FAMs onto transportation security missions every day.
PD: "... have ordered today on a number of our planes a Border Patrol man who will ride on a number of our flights." The MSNS investment fulfills President Kennedy's directive of having armed law enforcement officers on selected U.S. airplanes.
OR: The MSNS investment fulfills all of its requirements as set forth in its Operational Requirements Document, published in 2003.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no changes in funding levels for PY and CY.
Operational Analysis Results:
MSNS performs its mission for end users in an exemplary manner. 
1) MSNS customer results are very positive, meeting operational requirements, 
2) MSNS continues to accomplish its strategic and business results,  
3) MSNS continues to execute within budget; procurement activities completed early and thoroughly annually, and 
4) MSNS continues to innovate in both business and technology in support of its customers and mission.
5) MSNS is currently meeting or exceeding all of its operational performance measures
6) MSNS maintains a risk register and actively records and tracks its on-going risks. All risks are reviewed weekly by the Program Management Office (PMO), and significant risks are reviewed weekly with branch and division management. The Program Manager directs actions to mitigate risks as needed.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Federal Air Marshal Service (FAMS) Mission Scheduling and Notification System (MSNS) Program is in the Support life cycle phase. Program Cost Variance (CV) and Schedule Variance (SV) are within OMB specified guidance. MSNS has one active project for security patching. This keeps hardware, firmware and software up-to-date for system security. The project provides life cycle support for FAMS and MSNS Applications. These Operations & Maintenance (O&M) activities encompass network, systems, applications and end-user support. They follow agile development processes. The MSNS program employs DHS Application Lifecycle Management Shared Services (ALMSS) for requirements management. On-going O&M constitutes the majority of MSNS annual costs. All update/refresh costs and activities are budgeted and tracked in recurring status and invoice reviews. The current Operational Analysis (OA) reports the program as fulfilling mission needs. Detailed methods are described for collecting cost, schedule and performance data. The OA does not identify any program deficiencies, and resources are adequate to meet requirements. The MSNS system uptime record meets specified Key Performance Parameters. For BY18 MSNS plans include technical hardware and software refresh and a modernization project. This will align all Air Marshal IT services through upgrade of applications, methodology, and platforms. Agile development, COTS integration, and a Cloud platform are included in this solution. Program funding is being sought to begin the program. The DHS CIO assesses the TSA FAMS MSNS program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
STIP is an agency-wide data information technology (IT) program that connects all Transportation Screening Equipment (TSE) to a single network enabling two-way exchange of information to address challenges in security, configuration management, information sharing and enterprise management, resource management, and remote monitoring and maintenance.  
STIP’s goals aligns to DHS’s QHSR by Preventing Terrorism and Enhancing Security, Ensuring Resilience to Disasters and Maturing and Strengthening the DHS enterprise through its strategic objectives, resulting in enhanced benefits to the stakeholders noted below. 
The anticipated benefits expected from this investment are; 1. STIP has the ability to push software updates from a central location to TSE in the field programmatically, significantly reducing the time to implement these updates.  2. Improve property management and configuration control by providing the automated capabilities necessary to maintain a higher level of standardization and oversight of equipment operations. 3. Improve the timeliness and accuracy of checkpoint and checked baggage information by automating and centralizing the collection and management of operational and performance data.
STIP stakeholders are  Airlines; airport authorities; local, state and federal law enforcement organizations; local, state and federal regulatory agencies; vendors; TSA Office of Security Operations (OSO), including Federal Security Directors (FSD) and their staff; Office of Security Capabilities (OSC), including the Mission Analysis Division (MAD), Deployment Division, Checkpoint Technologies Division (CTD), Checked Baggage Technologies Division (CBTD), and the Operations Support Division (OS); Office of Intelligence and Analysis (OIA); Maintenance Service Providers (MSPs); and Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs), Support Contractors, Air Carriers, Airport Authorities, American Association of Airport Executives(AAAE), Air Transportation Association (ATA), Airport Council International – North America (ACINA), International Air Transport Association (IATA). 
STIP customers include both DHS and TSA, who achieve operational and cost efficiencies through the implementation of STIP. TSA customers include Office of Security Operations (OSO), Office of Security Capabilities (OSC), and Office of Intelligence Analysis (OIA). Other beneficiaries are the airline travelers and local law enforcement.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3241 - M&S Goal 6.1: Integrate Intelligence, Information Sharing, and Operations, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description:
The ROI of 87.8% indicates that STIP is a performing program that, when fully implemented, external benefits will increase such that the initial acquisition costs will be recovered and the program will return $0.88 for every acquisition dollar invested. The initial STIP CBA was conducted in 2006. The current ROI is derived from the 2015 STIP CBA update, which updated the most current costs and expected benefits for the selected alternative. By integration/networking of screening equipment (TSE), STIP provides cost savings for TSA through efficiencies gained by 1) automating data collection process which results in time savings for TSOs no longer having to manually collect data from all the STIP-enabled TSEs at the check point and checked baggage area.  2) Remote Monitoring and Maintenance (RMM) capability has the potential to reduce time required for maintenance technicians to travel to the TSE that requires diagnostics and consequently reduce maintenance costs for EBSP and PSP.     

Benefits of a continued investment in STIP baseline capabilities and software development to have the STIP Application Suite (STIP AS) interface with the Office of Security Operations (OSO) Performance Information Management System/Performance Management Information System (PIMS/PMIS) include a reduction of the data collection burden that each airport has to undertake to collect various data points and manually enter into the PIMS/PMIS database.  An additional investment for EMD (Enhanced Metal Detector) retrofits to enable automated collection of passenger throughput and alarm data counts will result in the enhancement of STIP baseline capabilities, due to higher accuracy and fidelity of passenger counts, developed and further reduce the OSO data collection burden.  Investment in future software development efforts and business process development for a Remote Monitoring and Maintenance (RMM) capability  provides benefits in terms of maintenance savings for TSEs, regardless of their warranty status or maintenance provider.  Additionally, RMM provides efficiencies gained by streamlining the maintenance issue diagnosis and resolution and the potential for an increase in uptime of TSE. 

A positive ROI indicates that the purchase and implementation of new capital assets to create a new capability should result in a net reduction in recurring costs over the investment lifecycle greater than the total of the original non-recurring costs required to create said capability.
Investment Requirements:
STIP is an Information Technology (IT) program with the goal of addressing the need for an automated exchange of information between TSE and TSA stakeholders. By addressing this need, STIP addresses the following key capability gaps identified by the TSA: 
 
1.      Security: TSA lacks the capability to dynamically transfer information between TSE and vetting and security operations. 
2.      Configuration Management: TSA lacks the capability to automatically upload configuration updates and software on TSE, as well as capability to efficiently collect, track, and harmonize configuration settings on TSE.
3.       Information Sharing and Enterprise Management: TSA lacks the capability to automate data collection processes used to capture and upload operational data for TSE.
4.      Resource Management: TSA lacks the capability to automatically collect Transportation Security Officer (TSO) threat detection performance data from TSE. 
5.      Remote Monitoring and Maintenance: TSA lacks the capability to remotely monitor and maintain the health of TSE. 

STIP is authorized directly by the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) of 2001 (Public Law 107-71), which mandates TSA screening requirements. STIP is further authorized through the derived requirement for “data interchange/exchange? and provision of “effective communication and metrics reporting through a system wide network? outlined in the Passenger Screening Program (PSP) and the Electronic Baggage Screening Program (EBSP) Mission Need Statements (MNS).
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no changes in funding levels for PY and CY.
Operational Analysis Results: Customer Satisfaction: STIP exceeded the FY16 target for customer satisfaction. Business and Strategic Analysis: STIP supports several TSA strategic goals and aligns with DHS’s mission as outlined in the DHS QHSR. STIP remains a priority of DHS, meeting information collection, retrieval, and dissemination requirements of EBSP and PSP, and addresses potential areas of improvement within O&M for TSE. Financial: STIP benefits are projected to outweigh long-term O&M costs. The networking of TSE that STIP provides increases the degree of effectiveness & efficiency that TSA are able to mitigate threats & improve security operations. STIP operations cost variance has remained under +/-8%. The STIP Acquisition Strategy focuses on use of FFP contracts in order to reduce risk of cost overruns even if schedule delays occur. The program has determined that although there has been growth in implementation of remote device technology throughout industry and government, the few sources in existence during STIP’s initial procurement have not increased. Innovation: STIP is working closely with PSP & EBSP to identify new & emerging technologies for STIP-enablement. STIP is collaborating closely with the Credential Authentication Technology project to provide a medium for transferring Secure Flight information to CAT devices in the field, significantly mitigating known security gaps in existing TSA Document Checker Standard Operating Procedures. STIP has declared a schedule breach due to interdependence with CAT operational testing. The program is working with DHS to remediate the breach, rebaseline, and proceed to ADE3 once CAT is ready for testing. STIP is exploring leveraging cloud services to streamline existing business processes that currently pose significant challenges to the program. STIP is exploring the possibility of providing OEMs who perform STIP development with access cloud-hosted versions of current EM software in order to expedite the formal testing process, decreaserisk of introducing errors into production software & increase velocity of production deployments. Risk: STIP monitors and updates program and project level risks on a monthly basis and reports risk in the IT Dashboard and INVEST monthly reports.  Active risk monitoring enables STIP to quickly address potential issues before they arise, and proactively develops mitigation strategies to address issues once the risk has been identified.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Security Technology Integrated Program (STIP) is in the Mixed life cycle phase.  STIP breached its original Acquisition Program Baseline (APB) December 2016 ADE-3 date due to new cybersecurity requirements enacted by TSA’s Office of Acquisition Program Management (OAPM), in response to Office of the Inspector General (OIG) and Government Accountability Office (GAO) audits.  These new requirements significantly impacted the program’s schedule. To better align STIP’s requirements with its mission, STIP’s Program Management Office in coordination with TSA’s Office of Requirements and Capabilities Analysis (ORCA) have submitted a new acquisition strategy to the Department’s Office of Program Accountability and Risk Management (PARM) and the Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO), removing outdated requirements and realigning unmet requirements to the programs that have been identified as directly responsible.  The Department is currently reviewing the proposed acquisition strategy and will continue to work closely with the STIP Program Management Office and TSA leadership to ensure the program has identified the optimal way forward to meet its mission and is making continued progress. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the Security Technology Integrated Program (STIP) program as a Moderately High Risk investment.

Brief Summary: The purpose of this investment is to adhere to the USA Patriot Act which prohibits a state from issuing a license to transport hazardous materials in commerce unless a determination has been made that the individual does not pose a security risk.  This investment meets this statutory mandate and conducts a security threat assessment for those that seek to apply for, renew or transfer a hazardous materials endorsement (HME) on a state-issued CDL. This investment delivers a capability to assess risk through leveraging intelligence data, criminal history and immigration status information in order to effectively identify persons known or suspected to pose a threat to transportation security. The primary goal is to protect the national transportation system, through identifying and prohibiting high risk persons from holding a HME, identifying low risk persons as eligible to possess a HME, and minimizing misidentifications of individuals as potential threats.  Performance Goals: timeliness, accuracy and efficiency, completing the adjudication process within 30 days; YTD average is 99% within 30 days or less; fingerprint reject rate is less than 0.11%. In accordance with DHS FY 2014-2018 Strategic Plan this investment supports Mission 1: PREVENT TERRORISM AND ENHANCE SECURITY, Goal 1.1 Prevent Terrorist Attacks by improving/standardizing the STA performed to determine if a commercial driver should be allowed to transport hazardous material. More than 3.117 million drivers have been vetted. Primary benefits external to DHS are Key customers, stakeholders & beneficiaries are US citizens, commercial trucking industry, carriers and trade associations, commercial truck drivers and state DMVs. Internal DHS Primary benefits relate to improved efficiency and processes. By implementing improvements and enhancing system capabilities, anticipated benefits include decreased time, work and costs required for the vetting process during the comparability/ vetting process, and increaseddata. Historically the endorsement process for transport of hazardous materials focused on the state's driver safety record and how to the reduce risk of a Hazmat incident. HTAP assumed the responsibility of conducting uniform security threat assessments, ensuring a consistent approach to identify known or suspected terrorists.  The process is proven to be more timely & accurate than methods previously utilized.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks, 5442 - Goal 4.1:  Strengthen the Security and Resilience of Critical Infrastructure against cyber attacks and other hazards
ROI Description:
As this investment has been operational since 2005, recovery of the initial investment has been realized. As this is a fee-based program, the fee charged may cover services performed: threat assessment fees may be equal to threat assessment expenses since the government may not make a profit on services rendered. 
Hazmat Threat Assessment Program (HTAP) return on investment cannot be measured in terms of dollars because of the intangible benefits that related to preventing acts of terrorism from occurring. The value that HTAP provides cannot be measured in monetary terms since it is providing matching and vetting services and strengthens national security by identifying high and low risk persons in order to mitigate known and unknown threats involved in the transport of hazardous materials.  This program provides quantifiable societal benefits by reducing the risk of terrorist events and the resulting economic impact if a government-controlled watch list and threat assessment process is not implemented. Benefits attributable to the capability are assumed to be a small portion of the cost of damages that would result from not preventing a terrorist from transporting hazardous materials. 
Additionally, this investment provides the following qualitative benefits to user groups for which the capability has been implemented:
1. Enables strict security controls
2. In non-agent states, leverages DMV infrastructure for transmittal/receipt of results prior to HME endorsement issuance
3. Integrates automated watch list matching and manual review and resolution of near matches.
4. Reduces organization complexity and simplifies integration, program control and management.
Investment Requirements: The USA PATRIOT Act prohibits states from issuing, to any individual, a license to transport hazardous materials in commerce without a determination as to whether or not the person is a security risk. The Act requires that checks be conducted against criminal history, immigration, & international databases. TSA HTAP meets this mandate by conducting a security threat assessment (STA) on drivers applying to obtain, renew, or transfer a hazardous materials endorsement (HME) on state-issued Commercial Driver's License. HTAP addresses the specific level of risk and supports the mission of preventing terrorism and enhancing security to the homeland.  HTAP leverages existing criminal history, legal status & intelligence data to perform a STA on commercial drivers who transport hazmat to determine the threat status to transportation security.  STAs utilize national data sources and consistent vetting standards which are universally applied to applicants seeking a HME.  https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-107hr3162enr/pdf/BILLS-107hr3162enr.pdf  .
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: This program is funded from user fees. Variances between budgetary resources and outlays are a result of the variable nature of the program. Since this is a fee based program, actual fees collected do not always correspond directly with projected fee collections.
Operational Analysis Results:
The analyses show that the Hazmat Portfolio is meeting customer, strategic/business, financial performance and achieving innovation. This investment is aligned to the DHS and TSA Strategic Plans.
Customer Results:
This investment is meeting its target performance measurement in completing the security threat assessment within 30 days or less and having a 0.11 reject rate on fingerprint enrollment.
A qualitative Customer Satisfaction score of 99.75% was achieved. 
Summary of  Business and Strategic:
This program is an important and key component of the DHS/TSA layered approach to transportation security and meets the statutory requirements of both the USA PATRIOT and Safe Explosives Acts to further protect against the threats to transportation posed by terrorists, dangerous criminals, and illegal aliens that may attempt to transport hazardous materials in commerce.  Some examples of shipments classified as hazardous materials include gasoline, explosives, radioactive and infectious substances, propane, chlorine, acids, ammonia, and other poisonous gases.
 This investment aligns with the DHS QHSR Goal 1.1. Preventing Terrorist Attacks Malicious actors are unable to conduct terrorist attacks within the United States through screening 100 Percent of applicants applying for, renewing or transferring an HME endorsement are vetted against the terrorist watch list.
Financial Performance:
The program is self-sustained and 100% fee-based. The financial performance is adequate, as actual costs have not exceeded planned costs; cost variance is within + - 10 % which are within acceptable parameters. HTAP maintains a small fee revenue balance and continues to provide efficient operations.
Innovation:
Programmatic innovation was introduced this BY through implementing the OIA Universal Enrollment Birth Certify that provides an alternative process for acquiring required documentation for program enrollment capability.  
HTAP participation in the current efforts to implement the Technology Infrastructure Modernization (TIM) will simplify the process for applicants by eliminating redundancy and provide comparability. The legacy HTAP system is currently scheduled to transition to TIM in FY20. Any planned areas of innovation will be incorporated into the TIM effort. The legacy HTAP system will sustain O & M until the planned migration to TIM scheduled for FY 2020 Q3/Q4.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Hazardous Materials Threat Assessment (HAZMAT) program is in the Support life cycle phase. HAZMAT continues to maintain adequate control of cost, schedule and performance, while operating within OMB’s recommended threshold for cost and schedule variances. Since the last assessment, the program continues to complete change requests for Universal Enrollment Services (UES) to provide ongoing support and minor modifications to meet program requirements. Total enrollment of UES remains at 41 states and the District of Columbia.  HAZMAT leadership worked with IT on a technical solution to reduce the number of National Crime Information Center (NCIC) false positive hits, decreasing the time to adjudicate cases, and improving the overall operational performance.  HAZMAT is performing strongly against the established targets for its operational performance, continuously meeting and exceeding them. These metrics include fingerprinting rejection rate, and operational system availability. However, some metrics are highly dependent upon entities outside of the HAZMAT program oversight, such as the overall application processing time which is owned and managed by Office Law Enforcement (OLE)/Federal Air Marshall Service (FAMS). HAZMAT program continues to work on the consolidation of IT functionality with TSA Technology Infrastructure Modernization (TIM) program. This consolidation is scheduled to be completed by Q3FY18. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the HAZMAT program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: SF supports both Missions 1 & 2 of the DHS Strategic Plan (Preventing Terrorism/ Enhancing Security, & Securing/Managing Our Borders) by identifying high & low risk passengers in order to mitigate known and unknown threats to aviation security and designate them for enhanced screening, expedited screening, or prohibition from boarding a covered flight, as appropriate. The SF program operates a threat-based, watch-list matching capability for covered Aircraft Operators (AO) with flights into, out of, within, and overflying the U.S., and for covered U.S. aircraft operator flights between two international points and enhances the security of domestic and international commercial air travel by vetting aircraft passengers. SF’s goals are to: support TSA’s Risk-Based Security (RBS) mission by identifying high-risk passengers for appropriate security measures, prevent individuals on the No Fly List from boarding an aircraft, identify individuals for enhanced screening, minimize misidentification of individuals as potential threats, incorporate additional RBS capabilities, and protect passengers’ personal information from unauthorized use and disclosure.  A key benefit is that SF provides a consistent, effective means of meeting these security goals within strict privacy requirements. AOs operators benefit from the SF program through improved aviation security, streamlined redress processes, relief from the watch-list matching burden, timely and accurate matches and resolution, and government response coordination (including law enforcement).  SF provides early insight into potential matches to the watch list and an interactive capability for recurring or manual watch-list matching on a 24/7 basis through Secure Flight operations within the National Transportation Vetting Center; integrates DHS redress results into the watch-list matching process to reduce delays of misidentified passengers; and enables the TSA PreCheck program that applies RBS procedures at airport security checkpoints. SF’s primary stakeholder is the traveling public. Nongovernmental stakeholders include covered aircraft operators, the aviation industry, third-party service providers, and privacy advocacy groups. Government stakeholders include TSA HQ, other DHS agencies, the Federal Aviation Administration, the Department of Justice including the FBI’s Terrorist Screening Center, and other law enforcement agencies.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description: The SF program's ROI can be measured based on cost avoidance dollars that relate to preventing an act of terrorism from occurring.  Through FY16, it is estimated that $414B in cost avoidance dollars are attributable the SF Program.  SF benefits national security by identifying high-and low-risk passengers in order to mitigate known and unknown threats to aviation security and designate them for enhanced screening, expedited screening, or prohibition from boarding a covered flight, as appropriate. The SF program operates a threat-based, watch list matching capability that enhances the security of domestic and international commercial air travel by vetting more than 2 million aircraft passengers a day.  SF plans to include additional list and rules-based enhancements to expand TSA PreCheck and SF user interface enhancements to further automate operational processes that support identification of known or suspected terrorists.  SF expected outcomes are to successfully identify individuals on the Selectee List for enhanced screening, minimize misidentification of individuals as potential threats to aviation security, incorporate additional RBS capabilities to streamline processes, and protect passengers’ personal information from unauthorized use and disclosure. SF integrates DHS redress results into the watch list matching process to help prevent future delays of misidentified passengers. SF also enables the TSA Pre-Check program, part of TSA’s effort to apply RBS procedures at airport security checkpoints primarily benefiting the traveling public. SF’s primary stakeholder is the traveling public. Nongovernmental stakeholders include covered aircraft operators, the aviation industry, third-party service providers, and privacy advocacy groups. Government stakeholders include TSA HQ, other DHS agencies, the FAA, the Dept. of Justice including the FBI’s Terrorist Screening Center, and other law enforcement agencies.
Investment Requirements: The Secure Flight program was mandated by Congress through the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 to protect the Nation’s aviation transportation system and ensure freedom of movement for people and commerce while respecting individual privacy and civil rights. Secure Flight directly supports Mission 1 of the DHS Strategic Plan (Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security). Secure Flight conducts watch-list matching for all covered aircraft operators with flights into, out of, within, and overflying the U.S., and for covered U.S. aircraft operator flights between two international points. The Secure Flight mission is to mitigate known and unknown threats to aviation security by identifying higher- and lower-risk passengers, designating them for appropriate screening based on their risk level, and/or prohibiting them from boarding a covered flight, as appropriate. Secure Flight also has established a watch-list matching infrastructure and internal procedures and policies to maintain the privacy of passenger information collected as part of the program. The program’s intended business/mission outcomes are to: prevent individuals on the No Fly List from boarding an aircraft, identify individuals on the Selectee List or other high-risk lists for enhanced screening, minimize misidentification of individuals as potential threats to aviation security, incorporate additional risk-based security capabilities to streamline processes and accommodate additional aviation populations, and protect passengers’ personal information from unauthorized use and disclosure. Secure Flight promotes consistency and quality in watch-list matching efforts, monitors aircraft operator compliance with Secure Flight regulations, and contributes to efficient security screening and boarding for passengers through low-risk population initiatives such as the TSA PreCheck initiative. TSA PreCheck is a risk-based initiative that allows TSA to maintain the highest possible security standards while improving the passenger experience by ensuring that as many travelers as possible experience the benefit of expedited screening. This approach allows TSA to focus resources on individuals who pose a higher risk to aviation security, while improving the travel experience of those who pose a lower risk to aviation security.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no significant changes from the final FY2017 President's Budget for PY and CY.  Variance is less than 10%.
Operational Analysis Results: SF continues to meet its operational performance measures on annual basis for the past three years the program has exceeded targets each month.  The SF Program continues to meet financial performance targets.  As illustrated in the Health Assessment form in the DHS Investment Management System, SF currently has a cost variance of  less than -2%. The execution of the SF budget is a continuous review and control of the allocation of funds to ensure consistency with the Programs’ operating plans and thereby maintaining a fiduciary responsibility. SF measures its performance to its customers through these metrics, “Percent of service availability of the SF system?, “Percent of compliant SF Passenger Data submissions?, and “Percent of Redressed passengers?, and actual results have consistently exceeded target. SF supports both Missions 1 & 2 of the DHS Strategic Plan (Preventing Terrorism/ Enhancing Security, & Securing/Managing Our Borders), by operating a threat-based, watch-list matching capability that enhances the security of domestic and international commercial air travel.  The program will continue to support testing of aircraft operator system modifications and migrations to new service providers. SF  watch-list matching has proven to be significantly more timely and accurate than previously performed by aircraft operator matching efforts. The "One DHS Solution" has improved the efficiencies for SF as it continues to reduce the burden on airlines to submit unique sets of passenger data to multiple agencies.  SF has developed eSecure Flight, an innovated web-based application for passenger data submission. ESecure Flight is an online interface used by the airlines to directly submit passenger manifests. SF correctly and effectively applies risk management principles. SF Management conducts a risk review meeting on a monthly basis. Risks and corresponding mitigation strategies are documented on the SF risk register.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Secure Flight (SF) program is an investment in the Support life cycle phase. The program continues to maintain cost and schedule variances within OMB acceptable threshold. Since the last assessment, the program completed the Acquisition Plan (AP) annual review, Risk Management Plan (RMP), and IPT Charter. Additionally, an Operational Analysis (OA) was completed in 2QFY17 addressing the following areas: innovation, customer results, strategic and business results, and financial performance.  The OA did not find deficiencies with the program, and it indicated that the program is continuing to enhance its security, and to strengthen its capabilities to keep terrorists from boarding commercial aircraft. SF program has been working on aligning passengers pre-screening capabilities with TSA policy, as well as implementing updates to make sure that changes to Secure Flight Passenger Data (SFPD) are vetted correctly. In response to an Office of Inspector General (OIG) recommendation, SF is working on making changes to TSA Pre-Check rules for frequent fliers. Additionally TSA Pre-Check was enabled for all DHS Federal employees. Despite its moderate risk exposure score, SF continues to actively monitor its risks and have solid mitigation strategies. SF continues to be a program that is meeting customer, strategic business, and financial performance, as well as achieving innovation and meeting its operational performance measures. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the TSA Secure Flight program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
Purpose: The Transportation Worker Identification Credential (TWIC) program was established pursuant to §102 of the Maritime Transportation Security Act of 2002 (MTSA) and §104 of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 (SAFE Port Act) (October 2006). These statutes require DHS to prevent individuals from entering a secure area of a vessel or facility unless the individual holds a transportation security card or is accompanied by another individual who holds a card.
Contribution to Mission Delivery or Agency Management Support Functions: In accordance with the DHS Functional Capabilities and Activities Catalog, Version 2.0, dated June 2014, the TWIC program supports the PREVENTING TERRORISM AND ENHANCING SECURITY Mission and the Screening function as listed in the Capability Portfolio.  As of August 1, 2016, more than 4.0 million workers had applied for a TWIC.
Goals: The TWIC program provides a vital security measure to ensure that individuals who pose a security threat do not gain unescorted access to secure areas of the nation’s maritime transportation industry. 
Current or Anticipated Benefits: TSA (1) positively verifies each applicant’s claimed identity; (2) performs a security threat assessment on each applicant; and (3) produces and issues a TWIC card containing biometric and physical information for each applicant meeting the threat assessment eligibility requirements. The TWIC security threat assessment provides a terrorism/intelligence check, a criminal history records check, and an immigration check. TWICs are tamper-resistant biometric credentials. The TWIC program provides a tamper-resistant biometric credential in compliance with regulatory requirements.
Key Customers, Stakeholders, and other Beneficiaries: Workers who may be required to obtain a TWIC include facility employees, longshoremen, U.S. mariners, deckhands, long haul and drayage truck drivers, laborers, and other individuals requiring unescorted access to secureareas of MTSA-regulated facilities and vessels. The TWIC program maintains an extensive outreach effort to an exceptionally diverse group of key stakeholders: Congress; American Association of Port Authorities; National Association of Waterfront Employers; American Trucking Association; American Waterways Operators; Offshore Marine Service Association; Passenger Vessel Association; Intermodal Association of North America; International Longshoremen and Warehouse Union and others.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks, 3264 - Goal 1.3:  Reduce Risk to the Nation's Critical Infrastructure, Key Leadership, and Events
ROI Description:
To calculate ROI, the program did a cash flow analysis using the TWIC Funding History report published by the TSA CFO which has the history of funding for the program up to September 30, 2015.  ROI for the TWIC program is calculated as (Cash In – Cash Out)/Cash Out.  Cash In is derived from two sources, appropriated funding provided early in the program and fee revenue collected from transportation workers once the program reached operational capability.  Consequently, as of September 30, 2015, Cash In (Appropriations) $155.875M + Cash In (Fees) $593.775M = $749.650M; Cash Out (Expenses) = $429.637M; therefore ROI = ($749.650M-$429.637M)/$429.637M = 74.49%.  The details for this method are included in the first tab of the TWIC Funding History report which is uploaded.
 
The program has been in Operations and Maintenance since October 2008. The program's external benefits include providing a biometric credential to over 3.7 million transportation workers as of March 1, 2016. TWIC is one part of the layered approach to port security and establishes a minimum, uniform, vetting and threat assessment requirements for mariners and port workers across the country.  The nationwide recognition of TWIC as the one common credential needed to allow a worker unescorted access to secure areas of facilities and vessels enables facility and vessel operators to verify the identity of individuals, including the use of biometrics—steps that were not feasible prior to TWIC implementation with potentially thousands of different facility-specific credentials.  The credential is being used in over 2500 MTSA-regulated maritime facilities and vessels nationwide.  Through the use of a universally accepted common access card, the TWIC system has eliminated the duplicative costs associated with redundant credentials and application processes, thereby reducing costs to the individual transportation worker. In addition, a simplified program supports efficient execution and a reduced threatwindow.
Investment Requirements:
Legislative Mandate:  The Maritime Transportation Security Act (MTSA) of 2002 requires DHS to issue a biometric transportation security card to those requiring unescorted access to MTSA-regulated facilities and vessels after determining the individual does not pose a security risk.  The TWIC program provides a secure credential and biometric security card for eligible transportation workers who require unescorted access to areas of MTSA-regulated facilities and vessels.  TWIC positively identifies applicants by determining the authenticity of identity documentation, and it conducts a Security Threat Assessment (STA) on each individual, including continuous vetting against Terrorist Screening Databases.
 
Agency Strategic Plan:  TWIC supports DHS Strategic Goal 1.1 – Prevent Terrorist Attacks and Goal 1.3 Reduce Risk to the Nation’s Critical Infrastructure, Key Leadership, and Events.  Via enrollment and vetting processes, TWIC prevents ineligible applicants from obtaining a TWIC card to gain unescorted access to facilities and vessels.  Also, TWIC supports TSA Strategic Goal 1.0 - Establish a risk-based approach to all operations to identify, manage, and mitigate risk in all TSA lines of business, and Goal 2.0 - External Engagement - Sustain transparent and proactive relationships with external stakeholders and the traveling public.  The TWIC program’s enrollment, vetting, and adjudication processes maintain effective controls to mitigate the risk of an ineligible applicant obtaining a TWIC card.  Also, the TWIC program uses customer service strategies, a stakeholder communications committee, visits to individual facilities and Coast Guard districts/sectors, and speaking at national stakeholder conferences and meetings to maintain communication with transit workers and maritime industry representatives.
 
Outstanding Audit Finding:  As of August 2016, the TWIC program is addressing a GAO recommendation to perform an internal control assessment by analyzing existing controls, identifying related weaknesses and risks, and determining cost effective actions needed to achieve program objectives.  In FY 2017, TSA will conduct an internal control assessment of the TWIC program to further identify internal control strengths, risks, and vulnerabilities.  The assessment will focus on TWIC’s enrollment, vetting, adjudication, and credential issuance processes.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Increase in PY 2015 funding is to account for actual fee collection as well as the third party vendor fee that were previously unaccounted for in the budget. This program is funded from user fees. Variances between budgetary resources and outlays are a result of the variable nature of the program. Since this is a fee based program, actual fees collected do not always correspond directly with projected fee collections.
Operational Analysis Results: Customer Results: Between October 2013 and July 2016, customer satisfaction exceeded 99.63% for all respondents.  The Universal Enrollment Services (UES) contract maintains a Call Center to provide transit workers with case status updates and issue resolution.  TWIC staff routinely travel to enrollment centers to evaluate performance, interact with customers, and develop corrective actions.  Strategic and Business Results: The TWIC program makes U.S. ports more secure by providing a federally mandated biometric credential to workers who require access to facility secure areas.  Aligned to DHS and TSA strategic goals, the TWIC program has enrolled and vetted over 4.0M transit workers.  TSA positively identifies applicants by determining the authenticity of identity documentation, and it conducts a Security Threat Assessment (STA) on each individual, including continuous vetting against Terrorist Screening Databases.   Financial Performance: The TWIC program is entirely funded through the fees paid by applicants.  The TWIC Cost Benefit Analysis determined that the program created a new capability to meet DHS and TSA goals.  With a focus on cost efficiencies, TWIC takes advantage of consolidated service delivery contracts to control TWIC costs.  Innovation: The Technology Infrastructure Modernization (TIM) system provides all TWIC infrastructure services and is consolidating all systems that perform adjudication, vetting and credentialing to improve processing.  The Next Generation (NEXGEN) TWIC is a technology refresh project that will allow a migration to PIV-I and utilization of additional security features.  TWIC PMO is also evaluating technologies to provide automated recurrent criminal and immigration vetting capability.  To further improve quality assurance, we are initiating an internal control assessment to review end-to-end business processes and consolidate existing controls and risks.  Operational Performance Measures:  As of July 2016, TWIC® is meeting orexceeding all of the established targets for measures required by OMB Exhibit 300.  In addition, the program manages a portfolio of performance indicators aligned to DHS, TSA, and TWIC program priorities, goals and objectives.  Risk Analysis:  12 project and 13 operational risks have been identified and are continuously monitored.  Risks are managed in accordance with the Risk Management Plan and the TWIC Risk Management Board meets quarterly to review current risks and/or nominate new risks.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Transportation Worker Identification Credential (TWIC®) program is in the Support life cycle phase. The TWIC® capability has already been developed and delivered, and the program is now a fielded operational activity. All three active TWIC® projects remain on-schedule and on-budget. TWIC® continues to meet or exceed monthly operational performance objectives to decrease the average wait time of credential activation, reduce the number of adjudication decisional and administrative errors, and decrease the number of inaccurate or ineligible enrollments. Due to changes in the hours-of-operation at several enrollment centers, the operational availability metric is running slightly under target. Key risk mitigation strategies include (1) maintaining strategic engagement with congressional and stakeholder communities, (2) closely tracking enrollment errors, adjudicators’ accuracy and Technology Infrastructure Modernization (TIM) system performance to proactively identify and resolve issues, and (3) expanding quality assurance activities. The TWIC® Risk Management Board (RMB) meets quarterly and necessary revisions are included in the Risk Register. TWIC® program issues are also included in the TSA TIM Executive Steering Committee (ESC) which meets quarterly. In Fiscal Year 2017, the program will continue activities aimed at improving customer service and oversight of all contract services that are involved in the process of issuing TWIC® credentials to transportation workers from enrollment to activation. As a program entirely funded through applicant fees, the program will also conduct a TWIC® fee review, examine fraud detection techniques, and assess the internal and quality controls for the TWIC® Security Threat Assessment process. Also, TSA will conduct activities to update the physical TWIC® card with enhanced topographical security features. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the TSA TWIC® program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of this investment is to provide information and metrics such as Airport Customer Throughput, Customer Throughput, Wait Time, and other key performance metrics. Internally, the program supports integrated data collection and operational performance reporting. The program has worked to enable greater levels of self-service across the TSA enterprise.  The innovative Airport Information Management (AIM) modules provides real-time business intelligence for operational performance, and is customizable at the airport level by Federal Security Director designated AIM Site Administrators.  TSA must create and implement a programmatic approach to performance management and accomplishment to achieve its goal of becoming a performance-based organization. This investment directly supports DHS Mission: Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security - Prevent Terrorist Attacks - Deter/disrupt operations.   This investment contributes to this mission through CAP103 Coordinate Partnership Management and Outreach – BRM220 Manage Relations with External Stakeholders and contributes to mission support through real-time data collection and business intelligence reporting and analysis.  There are approximately 45,000 AIM and PIMS users, and approximately 16,800 PMIS users. 
TSA has a need to expand this capability to other offices for greater information sharing, leveraging the existing asset to continue to enable operational activities both in the field and at TSA HQ for real-time reporting. Sharing knowledge and lessons learned will provide TSA users with the information needed to improve their decision making processes. TSA is now better able to leverage end user inputs into solid data entry and business rule requirements, allowing greater security controls for data submissions as well as specific data. This program is in Support. Key Customers include Program Managers within the Office of Security Operations, Office Of Civil Rights and Liberties, and Office of Training and Development.  Key stakeholders include Federal Security Directors at the 430+ Federalized Airports.  Beneficiaries include TSA’s Office of Strategic Communications and Public Affairs, Office of Legislative Affairs, the media, other government departments, and Congress.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description: TSA installed the MicroStrategy software in 2004 and has spent the last twelve years creating a series of performance-based solutions including real-time business intelligence.  Using the MicroStrategy tool, OSO created the Management Objective Reports (MOR), a report generated for over 160 airports each pay period.  MicroStrategy generated over 2800 pages of performance data each pay period, and since FY07 has documented cost savings and cost avoidance of over $300m.  The MOR was rebranded in 2016 as the Measures of Effectiveness (MOE) and is used by TSA Leadership to establish targets for a series of performance measures, both efficiency measures as well as effectiveness measures.   MicroStrategy 10 was deployed February 2016.  The PMIS Program Team will review the ROI during Summer 2016 to recognize features and capabilities within MicroStrategy 10. A copy of the AIM Cost Benefit Survey is attached.  The AIM Return On Investment (ROI) average annual Airport savings of $38,185 for many of the functions within the current AIM module suite. This translates to $17,183,500 for all 430+ Nationwide airports annually.   TSA employees are no longer creating and maintaining separate databases at each airport for the AIM modules.
Investment Requirements:
TSA leverages the PMIS Program investment to meet a variety of legislative mandates and address a number of audit findings, including:

Audit findings: TSA Is Taking Steps Improve Expedited Screening Effectiveness, but Improvements in Screener Oversight Are Needed

http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-13-43

TSA concurred and is taking actions in response.  Automated process in place to integrate data from TSA Contact Center within AIM.  Airports also use AIM to collect and complete local customer service records.

http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-13-186T
Audit findings: Transportation Security Administration Needs to Improve Complaint Processes
Status Completed.  Automated process in place to integrate data from TSA Contact Center within AIM.  Airports also use AIM to collect and complete local customer service records.

Specific requirements include:  URL to associated requirements:  \\tsahqf001.network.ad.tsa.gov\tsa\TSASharedFolders\COS\SMA\PerfInfoMgmt\PMIS\Requirements.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Funding levels have been lowered to reflect decision from PMIS In Process Review (IPR) (January 2016) for the program to conduct an Alternative of Analysis (AoA).  Once the AoA results and leadership decision has been made the PMIS Program may update the Life Cycle Cost Estimate (LCCE) and supporting acquisition documents to sufficiently fund the decision.
Operational Analysis Results:
PMIS has realized internal efficiencies such as dissemination of information which contribute to Organizational Effectiveness
1. Customer Results – PMIS provides data collection capability to 20,000 PMIS users and enterprise reporting to 10,500 PIMS users. AIM adoption has increased to just over 35,000 unique users.
2. Strategic and Business Results – Based on the results customer questionnaires, the following functions were most valuable and of use; Functionality that allows for comparative analysis nationwide, Ability to track and retrieve operational data (Airport Stakeholders, public), and track wait time and throughput.
3. Financial Performance – The information currently collected in PMIS includes: wait time, passenger throughput, baggage throughput, and prohibited items. Airport Information Management (AIM) modules allow airports to use an innovating intake process to enable real-time business intelligence for reporting and analysis as they complete their airport operations. Cost savings and cost efficiencies realized thus far result in savings or cost avoidance of approximately $17 million each year.  The PMIS Program calculates and tracks/trends the cost of AIM modules, based upon adoption at the 430+ federalized airports.   
4. Innovation – Building upon the financial performance aspects above, through ongoing strategic planning efforts, the program is positioned to anticipate, prepare for, and respond to reporting requirements for expanded data collection efforts.  TSA has been better able to effectively meet its business results in how the program responds to yearly DHS IG and GAO inquiries as follows: GAO response on Performance Based Organization, Baggage Screening, Prohibited items, E-gov Initiatives, Pat Down Complaints, Pre?™ , and Screener Theft.  The PMIS Program spent three years planning, and then implementing Real-Time Business Intelligence, with station level administration and local and national reporting.  This has allowed TSA toeliminate over 10,000 local databases built to manage airport operational performance.
5. Operational Performance Measures – Operational performance metrics reported through IT Dashboard and are running in line with targets.
6. Risk Analysis- The PMIS Program currently has a great deal of integrated administration capability to be able to support the user base.  Key federal employees are trained to support an enterprise reporting framework, providing additional efficiencies and effectiveness to TSA.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA), Performance Management Information System (PMIS) program is in the Support life cycle phase. The program continues to operate within acceptable OMB ranges for cost and schedule variance while continuing to meet mission goals and customer expectations. However, the program continues having challenges with providing Office of Information Technology (OIT) contractor access to its system, as well as maintaining consistency across its four environments. Since the last assessment, the program completed an effort with (OIT) to double the number of MicroStrategy server CPU licenses to address increased user adoption and to improve average time to generate reports in the business intelligence tool. Given its success, the Airport Operations Center (AOC) dashboard will continue to be the primary means of monitoring and supporting airport wait times for the Summer Surge 2017. Airport Information Management (AIM) application suite continues to gain steady user adoption with recent logins surpassing 13,000 per day.  AIM supports approximately 85% of daily airport operational activities with integrated data entry and real-time reporting.  Next release of AIM, expected to deploy by 4QFY17, will improve both event and incident management, while providing airports the capability to manage corrective actions. The program is scheduled to complete PMIS Commercial off the Shelf Software (COTS) maintenance and Operating System (OS) upgrade in 4QFY17 and 1QFY18 respectively. The program continues to monitor its risk, keeping an updated risk register on file, while maintaining a negligible risk exposure. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the Performance Management Information System (PMIS) program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: The Transportation Vetting System (TVS) formally known as the Crew Vetting Program (CVP) is an IT system. The purpose and goal of TVS is to provide TSA the ability to conduct initial and recurrent name-based matching against defined terrorist related data sets of individuals regulated by TSA who require access to the transportation infrastructure and to determine if they pose a threat to transportation across the various modes and the homeland. The benefit of the investment is an added layer of security and contributes directly to TSA’s mission of protecting the homeland and detecting potential threats to transportation infrastructure. In addition to contributing to the goals/objectives of the DHS QHSR Strategic Plan (DHS Strategic Goal 1.1: Preventing Terrorist Attacks and DHS Strategic Goal 1.3 Manage Risk to Critical Infrastructure). TVS was originally intended to conduct biographic matching of flight crew members that fly into, out of and over US airspace. Over time, the technology supporting the vetting or name-based background checks were leveraged to support the vetting of other transportation related populations regulated by TSA. To date, TVS’s infrastructure conducts vetting for all individuals regulated under TSA’s maritime, surface and aviation security programs. It also, provides a watchlist service for the Secure Flight program and supports the Office of Intelligence’s Encounter Management Division. Specifically, TVS’s infrastructure helps to identify potential threats posed by individuals to transportation infrastructure by conducting initial and recurrent vets of more than 19 million individuals across the transportation infrastructure in a highly efficient, effective and scalable environment. Key customers, stakeholders and beneficiaries of TVS include international flight crews, port workers, hazardous material drivers, airport workers, air carriers, indirect air carriers for access to cargo, other federal government entities and agencies, transportation related associations and advocacy groups. The Transportation Vetting System (TVS) is managed by the Office of Information Technology  (OIT). The expectation is that TIM and TVS will evolve to two systems but one Program in FY17.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks, 3264 - Goal 1.3:  Reduce Risk to the Nation's Critical Infrastructure, Key Leadership, and Events
ROI Description: The critical mission of TVS is Preventing Terrorism, every day, preventing known/suspected terrorists from gaining trusted access to the nation’s transportation and critical infrastructure. TVS is the TSA’s Vetting System, carries out recurrent vetting of over 4 million records daily and over 19 million individuals and 36 TSA regulated populations annually. The recurrent vetting, immediately alerts users on suspects and enables TSA/DHS to protect the people, commerce and infrastructure from an act of terrorism. TVS conducts real-time vetting of Flight Crew for flight to/from and over United States preventing known suspected terrorist (KST) from flying. TVS vetting results aided in providing over 2 million Credentials for Transportation Workers to obtain employment in the Maritime industry, and clearances to over 4 million applicants to enable them to obtain HAZMAT/Commercial Driver’s License. It also provides Watchlist update service to Secure Flight, enabling efficient Secure Flight operations. The vetting benefits are derived from the following alerts to protect against terror threats: (1) subject-to-watchlist match alerts signifying a subject may be on a watchlist; (2) subject-to-subject link alerts signifying a subject who is not on a watchlist may be somehow related to subject who is on a watchlist; (3) subject-to-other match alerts signifying the subject data may contain purposefully deceptive information; and, (4) subject-to-subject match alerts signifying that two or more subject records may represent the same individual; (5) subject-to-encounter match alert signifying that a person may have been also encountered by a partner organization; (6) subject-to-encounter link alert signifying that a person may be somehow linked to a person encountered by a partner organization. (7) BOLO (Be On the Look Out) match alerts signifying that a system record of any type may match an individual on a “Be On the Look Out? list.  The value TVS provides cannot be measured in real monetary value, because the benefits are intangible benefits.
Investment Requirements: The provisions of the Aviation and Transportation Security Act of 2001, and Title 49, U.S. Code , Section 114, concerning Foreign flight crews, created a statutory requirement for the TSA to conduct security threat assessments of internationally-flying aircrews against terrorism watch lists. Consistent with the TSA mission in late 2003 the President directed TSA to develop and implement a capability to screen flight crew members on international flights flying into, out of, or over the continental United States prior to an aircraft being released by the airport for takeoff. In meeting this requirement the Crew Credentialing Vetting System was created and met it's Full Operating Capability by 3/1/2004.  TVS was originally intended to conduct biographic matching of flight crew members that fly into, out of and over US airspace. Over time, the technology was  leveraged to support the vetting of other transportation related populations regulated by TSA. To date TVS conducts recurrent vetting for over 19 million individuals and 36 TSA regulated populations annually. TVS’s infrastructure conducts vetting for all individuals regulated under TSA’s maritime, surface and aviation security programs. In addition to meeting the requirements of the Aviation and Transportation Security Act of 2001 TVS meets requires of the Office of Intelligence and Analysis Strategic Plan for Fiscal Years 2014-2016.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: The funding increase of $8.992M reflects full O&M costs for TVS in FY16. The TVS systems funding will  be absorbed into the TIM program starting in FY17.
Operational Analysis Results: 1) Customer Results –TVS strives for continuous improvement by continually communicating with stakeholders to identify and prioritize customer needs, and to provide timely and cost effective solutions. Analysis shows TVS is achieving customer satisfaction results. Specifically, the program is achieving 99% on time delivery rate for customer reports which contains weekly metrics of system volume and population covered by the vetting system. 2) Strategic and Business Results –TVS strives to continuously meet goals and objectives of DHS and TSA TVS supports the QHSR and DHS Strategic Plan under Goals 1.1 Preventing Terrorist attacks and Goal 1.3 Managing Risks to Critical Infrastructure. TVS achieves these mission results by effectively and efficiently performing biographic matching of individuals seeking access to transportation infrastructure and identifying any potential threats. TVS recurrently vets over 19 million individuals in 36 populations. 3) Financial Performance – TVS continues to meet financial performance through the efficient and effective use of contract services for O&M activities. TVS continues to meet yearly acquisition funding requirements. Cost and schedule variance over the last year has remained in the +/-5% range. However the value that TVS provides cannot be measured in monetary value. TVS continues to offer significant benefits to TSA and stakeholders. In addition to providing 24/x 7 initial and recurrent vetting, TVS produces several hundred encounters with known and suspected terrorists (KSTs) each month preventing many KSTs from obtaining positions of trust. 4) Innovation – TVS plans to implement a number of maintenance activities that would improve systems operations which includes; upgrading the system to have the capability to perform Tier II reconciliation identities in the system between TVS and WLS, automate the process of exporting TVS SF encounters to the WebEOC system, upgrading the TVS FAA Interface to a Web Service to improve efficiency by removing manual processes, and to improve system performance moving Biographic Matching Engine Pipeline servers from AIX to Linux 5) Operational Performance Measures – over the last year TVS has consistently met or exceeded its Reliability, Availability/Uptime and Delivery of Customer System Reports metrics. 6) Risks – in the last 3 Annual IT Program Health Assessments the Department of Security Chief Information Officer continues to assess the TVS Program as a Low Risk investment.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Transportation Vetting System (TVS) program is in the Support life cycle. The program is operating within specified OMB ranges for cost and schedule variance. TVS is implementing operational and financial plans to merge with the TSA Technology Infrastructure Modernization (TIM) program. This move began during FY17 and is subject to the TIM re-baseline process. No TVS elements will be eliminated with the merger. The current Operational Analysis (OA) determined that TVS is achieving 99% on-time delivery for reporting system metrics and vetted populations. TVS vets 19M+ individuals in 36 populations. Cost objectives comply with the program lifecycle cost estimate. TVS supports its mission to detect “Known and Suspected Terrorists (KSTs). Those identified as KSTs are denied access or removed from positions of trust within the transportation industry. TVS is further improving system operations that will directly support the TIM program.
