These include automating generation of the Secure Flight Encounter Report, synchronizing the Transportation Worker Identity Card (TWIC) population between TVS and TIM, and upgrading the “Be On Lookout? (BOLO) alert distribution process. TVS is hosting TIM development, test and production environment in the TVS/Colorado Springs Operations Centers (CSOC). Another TVS innovation is roll-out of a pilot FBI “Rap Back? program for “recurrent vetting of criminal histories at all commercial airports?. The FBI generated Rap sheets are made available to airport and airline badging offices with a Web application. The program has had no failures in service and is prepared to expand vetting capabilities as required.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the TVS program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: This investment supports the mission of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) by providing secure, reliable IT services across the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) that includes personal computers, desktop/network and enterprise applications, system centric applications, local and wide area networks, data-hosting centers, operational support centers, help desk services, telecommunications, and information security.ITIP provides a modern, efficient, and robust IT infrastructure for the production, processing, managing, storage, protection, and communication of information. ITIP benefits TSA by allowing the organization to work more efficiently and maximize productivity.  ITIP provides TSA the capability to communicate quickly and effectively.In FY14 ITIP absorbed the TSA Operating Platform (TOP) and the Federal Air Marshall Service Network (FAMSNet).TOP supports mission critical applications across TSA and maintains uninterrupted network, data, and communication, helpdesk and field services while incrementally improving the adaptability of these services that will enable them to grow and change with TSA. FAMSNet is the primary electronic data transport infrastructure for the Federal Air Marshal Service (FAMS).The FAMS primary focus is to detect, deter, and defeat terrorist or other criminal hostile acts targeting U.S. air carriers. FAMSNet provides the Information Technology infrastructure in support of the FAMS’ critical mission including operations and maintenance support, help desk support, engineering and telecommunications services. ITIP supports over 60,000 TSA customers these include the Transportation Security Officers (TSO) cadre, the Freedom Center, TSA Hosting Center in St. Louis, MO, 620 CONUS/OCONUS locations, Primary and alternate Continuity of Operations (COOP) locations, and 23 international support offices. The Key Stakeholders of this investment includes Chief Information Officer (CIO), the IT Operations directors, approximately 500airports and Federal Security Director (FSD) offices, 23 international support sites, the TSA Command Operations Centers, TSA Headquarters, and industry. The beneficiaries are the entire agency (HQ and field), TSA employees-FAMs, TSOs, and administrative staff, TSA mission areas, and DHS components, Federal, state and local governments, airlines and other transportation operators, shipping entities, and the general traveling public.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks, 5442 - Goal 4.1:  Strengthen the Security and Resilience of Critical Infrastructure against cyber attacks and other hazards
ROI Description: The Information technology Infrastructure program (ITIP) is in the operations and maintenance phase and the benefits of this investment are fundamental for TSA mission success. The ITIP investment greatly compliments TSA mission of protecting and securing our nation’s transportation systems while preserving freedom of movement for people and commerce. ITIP's return on investment (ROI) provides TSA and its stakeholders with an enterprise-wide platform capable of delivering an evolving set of technology and mission-centric services; provides mission-centric services for developing critical applications with reduced time; facilitates the sharing of common data and application frameworks between applications through the provisioning of standardized hardware, software, and development tools; provides common functionality across constituent user groups, increasing communication and collaboration. Additionally, ITIP's return on investment provides electronic data transport infrastructure in support of the Federal Air Marshal Service (FAMS) to facilitate email, and access to critical administrative and operational applications; facilitates Internet access as well as internal access to FAMS critical information systems in administrative and law enforcement related programs. Because TSA is one of the most visible elements of DHS, with more than 50,000 frontline employees screening over 1.7 million people a day in airports around the country the ITIP return on investment is the robust, efficient, and reliable IT services it provides to ensure the security, integrity, and accessibility of data and IT dependent security systems. ITIP benefits extend to DHS components who work in airports, along the borders and in ports to protect our country and citizens from the threat of terrorism. A remarkable benefits of ITIP have been the potential reduction in investment costs by simplifying the IT environment through technology innovation, consolidating operations and maintenance supportat lower costs; sharing enterprise data/content repositories, for easier, faster dissemination of critical data; centralizing security and role-based access, enabling stronger IT security efforts against potential threats; eliminating redundant application and data stovepipes, reducing investment costs; single face to citizens, and increasing the effectiveness of communication during National Security issues.
Investment Requirements: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has a vital mission: To protect the Nation’s transportation systems to ensure the freedom of movement for people and commerce. The TSA vision is to provide the most effective transportation security in the most efficient way as a high performing counterterrorism organization. These overarching goals are the basis for ITIP. ITIP provides information technology and functions central to TSA intelligence and information sharing that directly impact TSA ability to carry out its mission and business operations. ITIP enables global transportation security by providing world class information technologies and services anywhere anytime.  ITIP supports TSAs IT administrative and mission operations requirements.  It is the responsibility of the IT Infrastructure Program to provide modern IT services to support TSA in execution of its overall counterterrorism mission. The management of IT Infrastructure assures the uninterrupted day-to-day operational availability of IT services required for users of voice, video and data computational capabilities; as well as connectivity and interface with the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and external law enforcement entities.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Funding levels did not change significantly from PY to CY.
Operational Analysis Results: Customer satisfaction with IT Infrastructure Program products and services is conducted weekly and monthly reviews that assess the IT Infrastructure Program performance in terms of cost, schedule and quality of services.  Overall, the stakeholders are satisfied with the quality of the IT Infrastructure Program. *Financial Performance: ITIP is Firm Fixed Price contract, and therefore, costs remain constant unless the requirements change. The customer survey results are reviewed, and necessary improvement is implemented to increase quality and delivery time. Due to this joint effort, the customer satisfaction is improved with the investment in the last 12 months. *The costs and schedule are tracked and reported weekly and monthly, which enabled the customers to accurately forecast future procurement needs, and focus on potential performance/quality gaps and take actions.* Strategic Business Results:  The IT Infrastructure Program is aligned with multiple DHS and TSA goals. The IT Infrastructure Program supports the QHSR and the DHS Strategic Plan, and TSA’s strategic Plan goals. The IT Infrastructure Program meets current and future business needs of the agency by providing the IT capabilities required to protect the nation’s transportation systems, while ensuring the freedom of movement for people and commerce. The TSA IT users/customers receive robust IT services to accomplish their mission and to contribute to the mission success of DHS.*Innovation: New innovative technologies are consistently being evaluated for improvement and inclusion into both the DHS and TSA Enterprise Architecture and IT Infrastructure Program. The latest innovation effort includes the planning future implementation of a cloud solution and WINS 365.*Risk Performance: All program risks are being tracked and mitigated at an acceptable level and are being kept updated as the program evolves.  The numbers of risks has been reduced through the years as the program matures.* Performance: The program performance is reported via INVEST in a monthly basis.  The program has continued to meet performance metrics and established baselines.  These performance measures are determined through the implementation of SLAs and leadership surveys. Overall, the customers of the IT Infrastructure Program are satisfied with the Program performance. IT Infrastructure Program supports approximately 65,000 TSA employees and  supports approximately 750 million airport passenger screens annually.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Information Technology Infrastructure Program (ITIP) is currently in the Support life cycle phase. The ITIP capability has already been developed and delivered, and the program is now a fielded operational activity. Acquisition Program Baseline (APB) parameters have been met and there are no current APB milestones as the program is in sustainment.  All ITIP projects are within acceptable OMB range for cost and schedule variance. The program conducted an Operational Analysis (OA) in 1QFY17: ITIP continues to meet current and future business needs of the agency by providing the IT capabilities required to protect the nation’s transportation systems, while ensuring the freedom of movement for people and commerce. New innovative technologies are consistently being evaluated for improvement and inclusion into both the DHS and TSA Enterprise Architecture and IT Infrastructure Program. Operational performance metrics continue to be met including mandated training, virus protection, and in-process reviews. Increased help desk call volumes have increased the average speed to answer calls, however, this metric has not hampered other critical IT infrastructure operational metrics. Appropriate risk management is a feature incorporated into every aspect of this program: schedule, performance, cost, organizational, and technical. The program continues to define requirements early, prepare contingency plans, and emphasize the necessity to ensure continuity of mission-critical services. In FY17, ITIP will continue the active deployment of TSA router refresh, secure mobile computing, and enterprise-wide desktop refresh. The DHS Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the ITIP program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
TIM implements TSA's centralized system for enrollments, vetting, adjudication and redress mission services in support of the maritime, surface and aviation programs. The TIM Program mission is aligned and consistent with the overarching DHS and TSA mission, DHS Mission 1: Preventing Terrorism and Enhancing Security. The TIM System supports operations by reducing the probability of a successful terrorist attack on the transportation system by applying threat assessment methodologies intended to identify known or suspected terrorist threats working in or seeking access to the Nation's transportation system.

TIM is being built and operated in the DHS datacenter cloud environment. TIM is a fully integrated system utilizing service oriented architecture capable of providing more effective and efficient security threat assessments to all transportation sectors including: surface, maritime and aviation. TIM is the Security Threat Assessment infrastructure focal point for stakeholders including: Congress, FBI, State Department, Coast Guard, State & Local agencies, U.S. airports, U.S. ports, as well as transportation employers, transportation employees, and travelers.

The TIM program’s goals are to improve customer service, provide one-stop shopping, enable a person-centric view, to implement “enroll, once and use many?, to increase the efficiency of security threat assessments and information sharing with federal, state, local authorities and industry partners, to promote secure operations, to support fee-fairness and comparability between credentials for  transportation workers,and to realize economies of scale; as well as operational efficiencies through integration of processes.

TIM customers (transportation workers and travelers) will benefit from the efficiencies and cost avoidance once TIM is fully implemented. Workers and travelers will also experience improved service at a lower cost. TIM is poised to be an Enterprise-level solution for Screening Coordination Office (SCO) Credentialing Framework Initiatives (CFI). TIM is one of the first DHS programs to use DHS Data Center Cloud Services. TIM is paving the way for new security and data sharing methodologies. TIM is a DHS agile pilot program that enables agile responses to changing business conditions and operational requirements via engineered business processes, and seamless information sharing services based on managed data (accurate, timely, trustable) with tuned IT performance.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description:
TIM is a Performing Program.  Though not fully implemented yet, the TIM Program already eliminates redundant business practices and processes, TIM also achieves cost and performance efficiencies by integrating now separate IT systems (TWIC, Consolidated Screening Gateway, Screening Gateway, Crew Vetting, Alien Flight Student Program) functionality under one program.  TIM enables support for external stakeholders such as Maritime, Surface, and Aviation transportation worker / traveler populations.

TIM provides TSA internal benefits by enabling information sharing across TSA / DHS.  The TIM system is being designed to function in a cloud environment.  TIM's cloud infrastructure will result in significant cost savings, especially in future years in the O&M phase.  Benefits to external stakeholders include streamlined vetting and credentialing services that are timely and person-centric.  TIM is person centric in that the system recognizes workers applying for multiple credentials, endorsements, or Security Threat Assessments (STA) to work in multiple transportation modes.  This person-centric capability enables TSA to fully integrate enrollment information across all programs, transportation modes, and commercial entities which saves users time and money.

TIM's STA process uses biometric and biographic information to perform automated immigration, criminal history, finger print, and terrorist watch list checks.  The transportation worker must have an approved STA to start or continue work, or even to apply for a job within the US transportation infrastructure.  Any significant delays impact the worker and may also impact commerce. 

TIM cost benefit analysis computes forecasted savings by subtracting TIM's Life Cycle Cost Estimate (LCCE) from the“As Is? Baseline defined in the TIM Analysis of Alternatives (AoA).  The annual savings are projected from 2014 to 2025 is $397M.  The DME investment to achieve these savings is $260M.

The ROI for this investment is computed as ((Benefits – Investment) / Investment).  Thus, the ROI for the TIM DME investment is 53%.

Please note that the savings detailed above are being recomputed as part of the TIM planned rebaseline process. Please see the ‘DHS Supporting Explanation Comments’ section for additional detail on the ARB.
Investment Requirements:
Maritime Transportation Security Act.
Aviation Transportation Security Act of 2002.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: FY14, FY15 and FY16 are consistent with the LCCE and the build schedule for the TIM program.In FY14 we are funding the surface builds which requires a reduced level because the majority of the architecture will already be present from the previous builds. The same holds true for the aviation builds in FY15.  With completion in FY2016 of FOC, the TSA TIM program completes development and is in full operation across the transportation mode populations.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Technology Infrastructure Modernization (TIM) Program is in the Mixed life cycle phase. Per an Acquisition Decision Memorandum (ADM) released in 3QFY17 and the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO), the program will initiate an effort to accelerate front-end development of the next generation Adjudication and Redress Case (ARC) solution. The program is currently assessing the schedule to meet this accelerated requirement and a briefing is due to the Office of Program Accountability and Risk Management (PARM) and OCTO in 4QFY17. TIM will also brief on its portfolio management process to ensure that operational and technical priorities are aligned with the direction of the TIM Executive Steering Committee (ESC). At the request of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the TIM program was suggested as a candidate to move into a FEDRAMP Cloud hosting environment within the next two years. The program is working with OCTO to determine the scope for moving a portion of the system into the Cloud in order to meet the requirement. Security and connectivity to external partners from a Cloud provider may require significant costs and schedule changes. Cost and schedule variances are currently not being computed relative to the October 2016 approved re-baseline. TIM continues to work closely with PARM and the Enterprise Business Management Office (EBMO) and expects to include the re-baseline with the BY19 submission. Significant risk exposure for programmatic and technical risks are managed by the Integrated Product Team (IPT) that meets biweekly and the ESC that meets quarterly. The DHS Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the TSA TIM program as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of this investment is to ensure the security of passenger aircraft that carry cargo. The primary goal of the investment is to support the systems that enable TSA to regulate the activities of Air Carriers and Indirect Air Carriers (IACs), regulate and approve companies to conduct screening operations, and determine the identity, validity, and risk of companies shipping goods on passenger aircraft.  The investment supports QHSR Mission 1: Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security and Mission 2: Secure and Manage Our Borders. The investment consists of three major systems, IACMS, KSMS, and FAS, and two minor systems, STAT and DAT, that serve to capture and manage data that help TSA mitigate the risk of terrorist incidents with impact on security operations (domestic and international). IACMS manages the IAC certification and renewal process, ensuring IACs implement security programs that reduce the risk of terrorism.  IACMS also enables IACs to obtain Security Threat Assessments (STAs) for their employees and agents, vetting individuals to reduce the threat of insiders introducing explosive or incendiary devices into commerce. KSMS vets shippers, reducing the likelihood that a shipper would introduce such a device.  FAS provides historical domestic and foreign air cargo screening data and is used by the TSA Cargo Targeting Unit (CTU) to manage time-sensitive data requests and identify high risk ports and entities via reliable risk data.
Primary benefits of this investment include improved oversight of regulated parties and shared security data (reducing costs and improving efficiency). By enhancing agent access to IACMS, deploying web services via KSMS, and automating manual processes via FAS, primary benefits include decreased time required for the vetting process, decreased transaction costs and processing times, decreased workload during the vetting process, increased data quality, and a reduction in the compliance burden by industry. Key internal stakeholders, customers, and beneficiaries include the Consolidated Screening Gateway (CSG), Certified Cargo Screening Program (CCSP) Office, TSA Cargo Inspectors, and Principal Security Inspectors (previously known as Regional Compliance Coordinators). Key external stakeholders, customers, and beneficiaries include passenger ACs, all-cargo carriers, IACs, cargo trucking agents, companies shipping goods via passenger aircraft, Certified Cargo Screening Facilities, airports, and aircraft passengers.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description: The layered approach to Air Cargo Security is the most cost effective means of ensuring the security of passenger air cargo, which blends several layers of security together, reducing or eliminating single points of failure. As noted in the Air Cargo Final Rule (http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2011-08-18/pdf/2011-20840.pdf) the main benefit of this approach is the improved security of the traveling public through reduction in the risk of an explosive or incendiary device being placed on an aircraft from the passenger air cargo mode, and an overall decrease in the risk of terrorism. It is difficult to determine how many planes would be destroyed by terrorism absent of the Air Cargo Security Program’s approach; however, the program can conservatively assume that its systems can help prevent a terrorist incident on 1 flight per year, saving 0.00000011% (1 flight/8,843,510 domestic flights in 2015 according to transtats.bts.gov) of the nation’s annual domestic flights from potential acts of terrorism. As a part of the final rule, TSA also estimated the cost of a terrorist incident to be $732.5M per incident. Air Cargo estimates the potential total cost avoidance to be $5.856B (1 incident x 8  years (total lifecycle) x $732.5M) and the program’s total cost avoidance to be $585.6M (conservatively allocating 10% of this total cost, as the program plays a portion of the nation’s layered approach to aviation security). Therefore the program calculates its return on investment (ROI) to be 1.31 ((Cost Avoidance/Risk Adjusted Total Lifecycle Cost of Program) -1). The $253.7M in Air Cargo Security program costs will be recovered and the program will then return $1.31 in terrorist incident avoidance costs for every dollar invested into the program.
Investment Requirements:
Legislative Mandate- The Aviation Transportation Security Act (ATSA) mandated that a system be in operation to screen, inspect, and ensure the security of all cargo that is to be transported in all-cargo aircraft as soon as practicable.  Additionally, the 9/11 Act mandated that TSA establish a system to screen 100% of cargo transported on passenger aircraft by August 2010. The Air Cargo Security investment consists of three systems that enable TSA to meet these statutory requirements. http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-107publ71/html/PLAW-107publ71.htm 
Outstanding Audit Finding or Material Weakness- In the GAO-03-344 report, the GAO recommended that TSA develop a comprehensive plan for air cargo security that includes priority actions identified on the basis of risk, costs of these actions, deadlines for completing those actions, and performance targets.  As a result, the Air Cargo IT investments directly support the strategic plan and enable TSA to carry out the priority actions. In the GAO-06-76 report, the GAO found that the Known Shipper database’s effectiveness was limited and this limits TSA’s ability to identify shippers who may pose a security threat.  The report also recommended that the data used in the Freight Assessment System to identify elevated risk cargo are complete, accurate, and current. In the OIG-09-35 report, the OIG recommended to resolve all remaining KSMS technical problems in order to achieve a specific date for mandating regulated entities compliance with the new method.  As a result, TSA invested in KSMS and FAS to address these issues. http://www.gao.gov/products/A05762 and http://www.dhs.gov/strategic-plan-fiscal-years-fy-2014-2018#
Published Agency Strategic Plan/Annual Performance Plan- The investment support the DHS FY14-18 Strategic Plan Mission 1: Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security, and the Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR) Mission 1: Prevent Terrorist Attacks and 2: Secure and Manage Our Borders.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: The funding levels for PY and CY to final FY 2016 don't present a significant change that presents a variance.
Operational Analysis Results:
Customer Results: The majority of stakeholders view IACMS, KSMS, STAT and FAS in a positive light. IACMS navigation, KSMS layout, and STAT performance were noted as the systems’ greatest strengths. Improvement opportunities for IACMS included system availability and login with multiple browsers, search function, and ability to search and access older alerts; KSMS included increasing speed, better identifying human errors during shipper submissions, and introducing the ability to delete multiple shippers; and STAT included allowing disassociations of former employees. Addressing these concerns are key program objectives for CY, BY and out years. 

Strategic and Business Results: This program is a key component of the DHS/TSA layered approach to air cargo security and meets the statutory requirements of both the ATSA and 9/11 Act to protect against the threats to air cargo posted by terrorists, dangerous criminals and others who would try to introduce an explosive, incendiary, or destructive device into the stream of commerce. The Air Cargo Security Portfolio supports 2014 DHS Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR) Mission 1.0 (Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security) and Mission 2.0 (Secure and Manage our Borders).The portfolio continues to meet DHS’s and TSA’s business needs by providing CAP3/4/16/18/20.

Financial performance: Financial performance is within goals with no expected overages. 

Innovation: In order to continue implementing technical innovation, the program has plans to enhance its web services capability for shipper vetting. Through the use of web services, IACs and ACs are currently able to access the vetting service provided by KSMS directly through their corporate information system, thus providing seamless integration between the familiarity of the corporate system and the functionality provided by KSMS. Enhancements to KSMS’s web services capabilities are planned for deployment in late calendar year 2016.

OperationalPerformance: Air Cargo Security is largely meeting or exceeding its 2016 operational performance targets for all systems.

Risk Analysis: Program risks are currently manageable with 6 identified, most relating to technology upgrades and security patching. All risks are accepted or have a mitigation strategy.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Air Cargo Security (ACS) program is in the Support life cycle phase. The investment supports the operation of several TSA IT systems. Since the last assessment ACS continues to operate within acceptable ranges for cost and schedule variance. However, schedule variance is negatively impacted from historical projects that are closed. The program continues to work on one of its systems interface redesign, which is scheduled for deployment by 4QFY17. Additionally, ACS is working on one of its verification systems, which will allow the collection and storage of certain documents from the US population. This implementation is scheduled to be completed by 4QFY18. ACS program continues working on adding an authentication solution to all Air Cargo systems. This effort is expected to be completed by 4QFY17. ACS program continues to meet and exceed its performance metrics, keeping all of its systems availability above target. The program is continually analyzing likely risks with both high and low impact, as well as mitigation strategies.   The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the ACS program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of this investment is to provide a financial system of record and a core financial management system for the following components of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS):  ICE, CIS, DHS Headquarters, National Protection and Programs Directorate, DHS Office of Health Affairs and DHS Science and Technology Directorate.  The system, Federal Financial Management System (FFMS), is a Web-based, workflow management and financial transaction system that allows users to create and maintain records for allocations, commitments, obligations, travel advances, and accounts payable and receivable.   Key goals of the investment are to ensure compliance with the Standard General Ledger account structure and posting rules required by the CFO Act of 1990, improve the accuracy and auditability of financial data and processes, and to provide a tight integration among the eight distinct modules of FFMS ensuring an efficient and accurate system with appropriate checks and balances.  ICE's OCFO, Office of Financial Management (OFM) is responsible for operating and maintaining FFMS.  Other stakeholders include DHS components and their budget and financial personnel (e.g. accounting technicians and budget and cost analysts), U.S. Department of Treasury, contractors/vendors, members of the public that participate in DHS programs, contracting officers, contracting officer's representatives (CORs), IT program/project managers, and program management office (PMO) support staff.
Benefits of FFMS include compliance with accounting standards and requirements (e.g. Prompt Payment Act); reduction in data redundancy with re-use of data after entered once; providing timely, reliable, and complete financial data for decision-making; promoting standard information integration and electronic data sharing with internal and external entities; increased accountability, internal controls, and security built within its processes coupled with audit trail for all financial transactions;and tracking spending by program, project, specific funding string, fund appropriation type and other financial record attributes.
Based on the above benefits, the investment directly supports Mission 3: Enforcing and Administering Our Immigration Laws, specifically Goal 3.1, strengthen and effectively administer the immigration system as stipulated in the Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR) Report and Mission 6: Mature and Strengthen Homeland Security.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, 5502 - M&S Goal 6.6: Strengthen Service Delivery and Manage DHS Resources
ROI Description: The current system continues to provide the automated financial support in the area of cost management, receipt management, financial reporting for ICE and the other five DHS components. The AoA provided a cost comparison among several alternatives: continue with FFMS, enhancing the current system, obtaining a Government service provider to serve as a financial service provider, replacing the current system with a more robust COTS product.
Investment Requirements: ICE has established plan of action and milestone (POA&M) for the each of the security weaknesses identified during internal scans and security audits.  These weaknesses are slated for mitigation within the year or a waiver was obtained for long-term solution(s) (e.g. the FFMS Stabilization Effort): FFMS database idle time out threshold is too high; inadequate patch management occurs on FFMS servers with a future plans to upgrade the existing system and its supporting software to meet ICE requirements with Stabilization effort; FFMS is not PIV mandatory and Phase 4 of the Stabilization Effort will implement the appropriate authorization and authentication protocols to PIV-enable and Single Sign-in enable FFMS;  FFMS is not configured with the latest patch for Symantec Endpoint Protection (SEP) Client. Also, FFMS is configured with vulnerability in Secure Socket Layer (SSL) 3.0, Weak Cipher and MAC algorithms -- these issues will be addressed with HTTP Server configuration changes, patching, and the stabilization effort which includes replacement of mainframe with Oracle Database Appliances (ODA) and upgrade to Oracle 11g and upgrade of Windows O/S to Windows 2012 on middle-tier servers.  As for regulatory mandates, the code base of FFMS is in the process of being changed to meet the October 1, 2016 mandate to accommodate the new Common Appropriations Structure (CAS)/ Program Project Activity (PPA) funding string format.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Funding levels for PY and CY to the final FY 2015 President's Budget for those same years were revised. The earlier estimate anticipated funding needs to support implementation of the FFMS' technology refresh and an anticipated increase in major and off-cycle releases to address defects and to ensure compliance with financial regulations.
Operational Analysis Results: The results identified the following: For financial performance, the estimated cost-savings from the Stabilization effort will greatly reduce the O&M cost and will result in a quick ROI.  Also, FFMS assist with prompt payment of invoices generating discounts and reducing the cost of the services.  For example, the prompt payment of invoices by one COR is estimated to save the agency approximately $100,000.  The effort will also improve FFMS with lower CPU utilization and faster response time (operational performance).  The team is seeking solutions to identify poor performance and potential failures.  Via e-mail and other communication methods, these notices will alert the team if certain measures are near the high-end of threshold settings and allow it to implement solutions to avoid those situations.  Other innovations include implementing SSO and the use of virtual machines (VMs) as reporting instance to reduce the workload on the production system; thus, improving performance.  The stabilization effort upon completion will remove three risks; however, resource availability, particularly federal FTEs, has hampered the team from completing all tasks and reduce it to focus their efforts on highly prioritized and visibility tasks.  Internal reporting requirements and administrative tasks may not get completed in a timely manner.  In support of the Government and ICE's missions (strategic and business results), realized benefits and outcomes include compliance with accounting standards and requirements (e.g. Prompt Payment Act); reduction in data redundancy; providing timely, reliable, and complete financial data for decision-making; promoting standard information integration and electronic data sharing with internal and external entities; increased accountability, internal controls, and security built within its processes coupled with audit trail for all financial transactions. In sum, the investment directly supports Mission 3: Enforcing and Administering Our Immigration Laws, specifically Goal 3.1, strengthen and effectively administer the immigration system as stipulated in the QHSR Report and Mission 6: Mature and Strengthen Homeland Security.  Finally, based on trouble tickets, the users are comfortable with FFMS and most questions regarding its functionality are resolved via a single call.  However, questions regarding the FFMS/CGE interface are high in volume and may require some changes to meet the needs of the users.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Federal Financial Management System (FFMS) is currently in the Support life cycle phase. FFMS is a mature system and has no major enhancements planned because it will be decommissioned and replaced in FY20. In the interim, FFMS continues to be useful with implementation of new enhancements to improve functionality and meet regulatory changes. System changes are limited to essential operating and maintenance (O&M) activities; mainframe and server uptimes continue to be 100%. A stabilization effort has been implemented to improve performance, ensure software compliance, and change FFMS to enable personal identity verification (PIV) and single sign-on (SSO). The effort will result in more processing power, memory, and storage which will provide major improvements to CPU utilization and financial reporting metrics. This stabilization effort is slated for completion by 1QFY18 and is also expected to greatly reduce O&M costs. The program is not reporting any cost or schedule variance and has been encouraged to update project information in the investments database so that the Federal IT Dashboard reflects current and accurate data.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the FFMS program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Investment Title: ICE - Detention and Removal Operations Modernization
Brief Summary: DROM is in the Operations and Maintenance Sustainment lifecycle phase, having achieved DHS Acquisition Decision Event 3 (ADE3) status in Sep 2014. The DROM program provides IT upgrades and improved functionality to support ERO's business processes and capabilities for conducting enforcement and managing the detention and removal of illegal aliens from the U.S.  A major goal accomplished was the replacement of the legacy Deportable Alien Control System (DACS) for case management, with a modernized Service Oriented Architecture based system called the ENFORCE Alien Removal Module (EARM).  DROM goals have been achieved through the creation of an ERO IT systems portal and modernization improving the management and throughput of detainees to reduce detention times with detainee location tracking and improved Alternatives to Detention (ATD) tracking. Other improvements have resulted in new or improved capabilities for electronic and traditional bond processing, electronic travel document generation, criminal alien tracking, risk assessment as part of custody determination through risk classification and prioritization, civil law enforcement agency notification, and greatly improved information sharing in support of interagency partnerships. Key enhancements include faster data access, improved data exchange and sharing, tighter interoperability among ERO systems, and expanded data collection to allow for improved forecasting and trends analysis and reporting.  DROM program improvement  provide ERO with the necessary automation solutions focused to meet  ERO automation needs in support of the continuing ERO mission and enforcement of immigration laws.  DROM program solutions also support other ICE enforcement initiatives and support the identification and processing of alien offenders and inmates in state and local civil law enforcement custody. Stakeholders of this investment include ICE ERO and the ICE Office of Detention Policy and Planning. The Investment’s primary users include ERO agents, detention facility administrators, ICE headquarters personnel, surety/bond agents, foreign consular/embassy staff, and the general public.  Additionally, DROM improved data sharing and exchange with other DHS and law enforcement components, including CBP and Office of Field Operations, Citizenship and Immigration Services, U.S. Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigations, the Department of State, DHS headquarters, and the Social Security Administration.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 30982 - Goal 3.2: Prevent Unlawful Immigration
ROI Description: ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO), formerly called DRO for Detention and Removal Operations, conducts enforcement operations to identify and apprehend removable aliens, to detain these individuals when necessary, and to remove illegal aliens from the United States. DROM program IT systems support the process of prioritizing the apprehension, arrest, detention, and removal of convicted criminals, those who pose a threat to national security, fugitives, recent border entrants, and aliens who impede immigration controls. The DROM program implementation of EARM provides a centralized point where detention and deportation officers are able to rely on one integrated system to facilitate and coordinate detention and repatriation. The ROI, including internal and external benefits for the DROM program, are time savings for reduced intake process, time and cost savings for electronic transmission of travel documents, and cost savings for bond processing (e.g. travel expenses) by allowing officers to use the information system versus traveling to surety offices nationwide to issue bonds for detainees.
Investment Requirements: All requirements have been met. DROM is in sustainment. Five recommendations were identified in the original GAO Audit. All five recommendations were implemented as identified here http://gao.gov/products/GAO-05-805. DROM supports the DHS Strategic Plan MISSION 3: ENFORCE AND ADMINISTER OUR IMMIGRATION LAWS, GOAL 3.2: PREVENT UNLAWFUL IMMIGRATION. DROM identifies criminal aliens for removal, individuals who pose a threat to public safety, health, or national security, repeat immigration law violators, and other individuals prioritized for removal. DROM utilizes a scoring methodology to generate recommendations as to whether a subject should be detained or released, the custody classification level (if detained),  the bond amount (if released), and a community supervision level (if released). The system shall generate a risk to public safety score based on the severity of charge or conviction, a subject’s prior convictions, open warrants, and other special public safety factors. The system shall generate a risk of flight score based on a subject’s ties to the community and other flight factors.  DROM allows agents to arrest, detain, and remove criminals, fugitives, and other dangerous foreign nationals by leveraging federal information sharing and state, local, and federal criminal justice systems to take enforcement action based on priorities with regard to criminal aliens, and working with the Department of Justice to ensure more timely hearing of immigration cases and appeals.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: The differences are based upon a significant reduction in PMO staff, a reduction in GFTEs, and a cost reduction in DME and O&M activities because of limited funds available and the integration of DROM applications (i.e. FMS and RCA) into EARM that reduced the overall maintenance cost.
Operational Analysis Results: Customer Results: The DROM program reports monthly and informal assessments. Customer expectations are met by reducing cycle times for issuing travel documents, improved and faster reporting and greater data integrity. Strategic and Business Results: DROM is aligned with the Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR) by providing ERO and other stakeholders with the automation tools necessary to manage detainees that enter the detention system and help ensure the that the immigration system works in a streamlined manner. Financial Performance Analysis: A Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA) was conducted on June 30 2007. The CBA revealed that the DROM investment supports the DHS Enterprise Architecture by providing an interoperable, interconnected and secure IT infrastructure. DROM has an ROI of 17%. The DROM investment cost avoidance benefits reflects expected savings in ICE government and contractor labor costs and other costs (i.e., travel, equipment, operations costs and service charges.) Improved system productivity has allowed ICE detainees to be processed faster reducing operating cost through a reduction in the lengths of detentions. Innovation: The DROM program will assess cloud computing for the applications within the DROM program. To address integrity concerns in the lower environments, the DROM applications currently hosted in the lower environments will be virtualized. Operational Performance Measures: The key benefits measured include; higher prioritization for investment tasks related to testing environments and deployment, timely completion of independent testing and evaluation, efficient movement through the ICE SLM lifecycle process, reduced repair time and maximum availability of systems. Risk Analysis: Risk Analysis identified technical risks regarding non-production environments reliability, the dependence upon the solution's technology and contract award cost estimates. All risks were assessed and mitigations included virtualizing the lower productionenvironments, cohesive license management and contract oversight support.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Detention and Removal Operations Modernization (DROM) program is in the Support life cycle. The DROM mission is to modernize ICE IT systems that support detention and removal of illegal aliens from the United States. The program is an Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO) initiative that demonstrates effective program management practices and is currently operating with acceptable cost and schedule variances. Historical projects from FY13, now closed, previously drove these variances out of range. The program has a Life Cycle Cost Estimate (LCCE) and approved Acquisition Program Baseline (APB). An Operational Analysis (OA) was completed since the last assessment. The OA reports meeting customer expectations through reduced travel document issuing cycle times and faster data reporting with higher integrity. Other accomplishments are automated travel document processing and posting on-line electronic bonds. These functions achieve cost savings through shortened detainee stays in detention centers. The program budget going forward does not include development and modernization funds. This prevents major application upgrades. However, Operations & Maintenance (O&M) funding is meeting program needs. A single five year O&M contract was awarded in Q3 FY16. This provides DROM with software maintenance and minor development using agile techniques. A Cloud hosting service contract is planned for award after Q2 FY17. During the last FY 16, Performance Metrics were updated to align with the Office of Information Technology Multi-Year Investment and Management Plan. The DROM program has developed stable production IT systems.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the ICE DROM program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The infrastructure investment for U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is called the IT Infrastructure Program and consists of 10 sub-programs that directly align to DHS specified lines of business, to include the following Services: Network, Email, Help Desk, Data Center, Desktop, Site, Video, Voice, Wireless, and Identity, Credential and Access Management (ICAM).   
The investment’s purpose is to enhance ICE's technology foundation, maximize workforce productivity, secure the IT environment, and improve information sharing across ICE and DHS. The Program is comprised of multiple systems that encompass the activities of the Office of the Chief Information Officer's Operation, and consists of the architecture, acquisition, integration, and operations and maintenance of the hardware, software, and services that comprise the ICE IT foundation.   
The Program is charged with delivering IT products and services that provide the 24x7x365 systems availability that enable ICE and DHS to achieve the mission. Goals include: Ensuring ICE has access to necessary IT resources; Upgrading and improving technology; Procuring and integrating hardware and software products and services; Managing a comprehensive IT disaster recovery response strategy; and Providing onsite technical support.   
Benefits to the homeland and its citizens include: Providing IT equipment, connectivity, office productivity systems and support to ICE personnel; Providing the IT platform, connectivity and security for the mission-specific systems covered by the other ICE IT investments.   
Contribution to Mission: The Program directly supports DHS 2014-2018 Strategic Objective 6.6.3: Manage/optimize financial resource/property/assets/procurements/security/DHS IT.   
Key Customers of the investment are the ICE operations and mission support users.   
Stakeholders encompass DHS; ICE organizational elements; and all the other ICE IT programs.   
Other Beneficiaries include users of DHSenterprise services, other DHS/non-DHS systems, and users authorized to access ICE information resources, such as its law enforcement partners.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 5502 - M&S Goal 6.6: Strengthen Service Delivery and Manage DHS Resources
ROI Description:
There are a number of qualitative benefits provided by this investment:  
Provides the foundation and infrastructure for a wide range of IT application systems and capabilities for receiving and disseminating data (The data centers provide ICE staff the capabilities to perform their work efficiently and effectively)  
Provides the capabilities for securing the confidentiality, integrity and disaster recovery of ICE data and other IT resources  
Provides the capabilities for information sharing and collaboration among ICE IT users and program areas, the DHS community, and other law enforcement agencies  
The rapid sharing of information and collaboration with international, federal, state, local, and tribal law enforcement partners significantly increases the efficiency and effectiveness of the ICE components to perform their mission, and results in a significant increase in the safety of law enforcement personnel and the morale and job satisfaction of the administrative personnel within ICE  
Internal accomplishments maximize external citizen benefits to Prevent Terrorism and Enhance SecurityWhen the program was established, a baseline for the costs and benefits was not established as this is not a typical system where an analysis of costs and benefits were analyzed before a system was developed. All of the current costs are for Operations and Maintenance.  Without costs to develop and implement this investment, and only qualitative Benefits, the Return on Investment (ROI) has to be zero.
Investment Requirements:
Homeland Security Presidential Directive 12 (HSPD-12) and Federal Information Processing Standards Publications 201 (FIPS 201) require a mandatory standard for secure and reliable forms of identification for Government employees and contractors. HSPD-20 and the Federal Executive Branch Continuity of Operations (FPC-65) mandate continuity requirements be incorporated into daily operations and agencies be prepared for the full range of potential emergencies. Executive Order 13514 addresses the requirement to consolidate federal data centers. As a result, reliable technology and adequate cyber security capabilities need to be incorporated into the ICE IT infrastructure, as well as the need to consolidate data center assets—all of which this investment is chartered to achieve.
References: https://www.dhs.gov/homeland-security-presidential-directive-12
Section 501 of the 9/11 Act, information sharing investments align ICE with the comprehensive DHS information technology architecture, connecting its various databases and related information technology assets to promote information shareing with federal, state, and local homeland security partners.  NIST has also mandated the use of encrypted communications for systems that contain Sensitive but Unclassified Information; and the Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP) mandated that all agencies that participate in drug law enforcement must employ encrypted communications.



There are wide variations in the quality and security of identification used to gain access to secure facilities where there is potential for terrorist attacks. In order to eliminate these variations, U.S. policy is to enhance security, increase Government efficiency, reduce identity fraud, and protect personal privacy by establishing a mandatory, Government-wide standard for secure and reliable forms of identification (i.e. PIV card) issued by the Federal Government, Department of Homeland Security, to its employees and contractors (including contractor employees). This directive mandates a federal standard for secure and reliable forms of identification.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Due to DHS budget reductions, O&M costs for the ICE IT Infrastructure program will be reduced by nearly four and one half percent.
Operational Analysis Results:
The Operational Analysis found that while the investment continues to support ICE by providing a platform for the other OCIO IT investments, significant challenges lie ahead. 
•        Customers are satisfied in general with program performance but have concerns with technical refresh, migration to cloud platforms, consolidation, and cost reduction. This is influencing 
•        Strategic Business Results manage the limitations between offering maximum platform flexibility and maintaining cost controls.
•        Financial Performance has been as projected, but is being continually monitored to ensure that consolidation and cloud adoption do not inadvertently become cost drivers. 
•        Innovation managing an enterprise technology aligning for efficient organization and improve alignment between technology initiatives and business goals.
•        Operational Performance Measures capabilities against established cost, schedule, and performance goals.
•        Risk Management is reported by justification on workforce management, acquisitions operations, and project costs.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) IT Infrastructure program is in the Support lifecycle phase. This investment is chartered per Under Secretary for Management, Acquisition Decision Memorandum (ADM). The ADM waives formal Management Directive 102 documentation requirements. Program cost and schedule variances (CV/SV) are within OMB specified ranges. A funding shortage was seen during FY16 for sustainment of end-of-life equipment. Program leadership implemented cost efficiency measures to fill this gap during the fiscal year. Equipment modernization realized reduced maintenance expense and a balanced-budget. A concession is maintained for platform flexibility against cost control maintenance. During the last fiscal year IT Infrastructure reported several new capabilities. The Operational Analysis (OA) documents specific accomplishments for Personal Identity Verification (PIV) Logical Access (LACS) card roll out with remote access, continuous network security patches, mobile workforce technical support and other capabilities. The program continues to meet mission goals and customer expectations. The OA determined that the investment is supporting ICE IT capabilities. IT security spending is projected to cost significantly less starting in FY18. ICE plans to maintain its own IT security and contract staff to eliminate an overhead cost burden. This plan directly addresses technical and financial challenges. The program continues to manage concerns with technical refresh, migration to cloud platforms, and data center consolidation. The program elected to rate each identified risk as “high-high? which results in a reported “significant risk exposure.? The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer assesses the IT Infrastructure program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
Purpose: To enable the ICE Health Service Corps (IHSC) to effectively administer and oversee healthcare services delivered to detainees in ICE custody, improve the quality of care delivered, expand the availability of medical information to all providers, reduce duplication of services within the ICE healthcare system, better manage infectious diseases, reduce the medicolegal risks and costs to ICE, implement a standardized approach to healthcare delivery, and leverage community best clinical practices in medicine.  
Goals: To acquire and deploy a certified ambulatory complete electronic Health Record system to replace multiple systems and manual processes.  Bring IHSC into compliance with federal health information technology directives and the 2011 Performance-Based National Detention Standards (PBNDS), leverage industry investments in health information technology and product functionality, address detainee healthcare delivery gaps, and promote the exchange of information with internal and external stakeholders.   
Benefits: Will reduce costs and improve efficiencies by: 1. replacing multiple stand-alone systems and manual processes; 2. reducing duplication of work, risk of human error, delays in the documentation of medical care, lack of efficiency and accountability of all activities; 3.providing timely information to guide medical and/or custody-related decisions, reporting of medical summaries, alerts, special needs of detainees, and medical history; 4. providing appropriate linkages between detainees and medical encounters; 5. providing support for records transfers among medical units and facilities; 6. providing clinical tools to support a uniform and standard healthcare delivery method, standard oversight and monitoring tools necessary to evaluate clinic operations; and 7. providing reporting capabilities to accurately provide real time patient information to stakeholders.  
Contribution to Mission Delivery: Supports DHS Mission Objectives 3.1 and 3.2 ensuring compliance with and consistently implementing ICE policy in the field and providing safe and humane detention conditions..  
Key Customers: The primary users of this investment will be IHSC U.S. Public Health Service Officers and contract medical professionals who work under their supervision.  
Stakeholders: DHS leadership, ICE leadership, ERO leadership, IHSC leadership, U.S. Public Health Service, eHR end users.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 30982 - Goal 3.2: Prevent Unlawful Immigration
Investment Requirements: OIG 2008 Recommendation Report which can be accessed at https://www.oig.dhs.gov/assets/Mgmt/OIG_08-52_Jun08.pdf  included several recommendations which this investment would address to meet some weaknesses in ICE's oversight of detainee patient care such as: (1) prompt reporting of patient care; (2) enhance standards of detainee patient care; (3) revision of medical intake forms and detainee medical screening.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: N/A.
Operational Analysis Results:
-       Financial Performance, the investment met the capabilities targeted for this investment
-       Customer Results, the IHSC customers have improved the accuracy of their health records and improved quality and reliability of their medical services
-       Business and Strategic Analysis, the investment supports the missions of DHS and is aligned with the current DHS mission and strategic goals as espoused in the Quadrennial Homeland Security Review
-       Operational Performance Measures, the monthly metrics that measure such items as # of concurrent users, system response time, % availability all show that system is performing acceptably
-       Innovation, the more automated upload of medical devices (e.g. vital signs monitors, radiology units, medication administration software), thus eliminating manual uploads to the system are anticipated 
-       Risk Analysis, the  primary risks are schedule risks, particularly as they relate to the COTS vendor's delivery of new releases continue to be monitored.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO) Electronic Health Record (eHR) System program is in the Support life cycle phase. The program continues to operate within acceptable OMB cost variances. However, eHR’s schedule variance is negatively reported due to historical closed project data. As of this assessment, the program is currently within OMB acceptable schedule variance. eHR continues to be successfully operational using version 10 of eClinicalWorks (eCW). eCW’s next version, which will include major enhancements, continues to be the program’s priority and it is scheduled to be deployed by 4QFY17. However, given the service provider inability to meet deployment dates in the past, a delay is expected. Since the last assessment, the program successfully deployed a system that transmits contractor medical services data to the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), who performs financial services for ICE. The legacy system was dispositioned in 3QFY17. The program completed a deployment in the Pacific Northwest area, of a system used to manage, track and report the dispensing of medications by health care providers in 3QFY17.  The program is developing an interface with the correctional institutional pharmacy software. After the initial interface between these two systems completes the development and testing framework additional deployments are planned. . The Risk Management Plan (RMP) was recently reviewed and updated, and risk register continues to be updated regularly and risks monitored effectively, giving the overall program a moderate risk exposure. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) will continue to monitor and assess the ICE ERO eHR program as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary: The Investigative Case Management system will provide improved case management functionality to more than 6,700 ICE Special Agents, assigned to 200+ cities throughout the U.S. and in 48 countries.  ICE investigations cover a range of areas, including national security threats, financial and smuggling violations, financial crimes, commercial fraud, human trafficking, narcotics smuggling, child pornography/exploitation and immigration fraud. The improvements and benefits include an enhanced user interface to provide employee case dashboards, streamlined processes and simplified user interactions, enhanced search capabilities through structured and unstructured queries, improved data quality and integration through auto population of known data,  removal of duplicate data entry, ease of transition and training for new agents through an intuitive user interface and current technology, improved collaboration between agents and supervisors through enhanced workflow capabilities, and improved accuracy and management of statistics.  The technical improvements and benefits include improved interoperability with other systems, alignment to DHS/ICE architecture standards for long-term sustainability, reduced support costs, and flexibility to quickly meet mission needs, Section 508 compliance, scalable platform allowing for system to change as business needs change, and enhanced interfaces through which agents can access critical data from internal and external partners in support of investigations.  The ICE TECS Mod Program supports the following DHS Mission/Goals: 1) Prevent Terrorist Attacks, 2) Prevent and Protect Against the Unauthorized Acquisition or Use of Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear (CBRN), Materials and Capabilities , 3) Reduce the Risk to the Nation’s Critical Infrastructure, Key Leadership, and Events, 4) Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches , 5) Disrupt and Dismantle Transnational Criminal Organizations, 6) Prevent Unlawful Immigration, and 7) Advance Cyber Law Enforcement, Incident Response, and Reporting Capabilities The Program’s primary customers are the ICE special agents and other investigators who will use this Investigative Case Management system to support enforcement of the nation’s immigration and customs laws.  The ultimate beneficiary will be the American Public. The key stakeholders are: ICE – Homeland Security Investigation, CBP and ICE Office of Professional Responsibility.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3260 - Goal 2.3:  Disrupt and Dismantle Transnational Criminal Organizations and Other Illicit Actors, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks, 3263 - Goal 1.2:  Prevent and Protect Against the Unauthorized Acquisition or Use of Chemical, Biological, Radiological, and Nuclear (CBRN) Materials and Capabilities, 3264 - Goal 1.3:  Reduce Risk to the Nation's Critical Infrastructure, Key Leadership, and Events, 5462 - Goal 4.3:  Advance Cyber Law Enforcement, Incident Response, and Reporting Capabilities, 30982 - Goal 3.2: Prevent Unlawful Immigration
ROI Description:
The TECS Modernization program’s Return on Investment (ROI) for the selected Hybrid COTS/Custom solution is 48% based on the approved Analysis of Alternatives completed on May 12, 2011.  The program will realize benefits associated with a modern technology that provides efficiencies for the creation, management, and oversight of investigative cases at ICE.  The modernized TECS solution will allow for pre-population of data fields resulting in less data entry errors, electronic case management workflow between the supervisor and agent, retention of electronic files (including images), single sign-on, and enhanced notifications allowing for faster processing of cases. The modernized TECS solution will allow ICE to avoid incurring the following costs and realize savings:  
· Maintain Legacy TECS system:  $26M per year
· Support services to manage the outdated programming language: $10.56M as of FY16
· Pre-populate Enforce:  $11.06M per year 
· Retention of documents:  $5.31M per year
· Single sign-on: $0.04M per year
· Manual Table Look-Ups: $4.55M per year
· Manual entry of subject data in ICE and CBP records: $2.02M per year
· Manual development of ROI (Report on Investigations): $3.03M per year
· Enhanced Notification System: $2.27M per year.
Investment Requirements:
The TECS Modernization program is composed of two separate, but related, modernization efforts managed by CBP and ICE.  Each Component is responsible for modernizing the functionality of TECS that is unique to their respective mission. The TECS Modernization Program was formalized under a joint Customs and Boarder Protection (CBP) ICE Charter (http://invest-production.dhs.gov/ProSight/IDR/gd.aspx?docId=6700). 
The TECS Modernization Program is a multi-year effort that uses a phased approach to transitioning from the existing TECS application to the modernized TECS application and service environment. The TECS Modernization initiative will migrate aging, costly and unsustainable technology to a modern technical environment and provide a law enforcement case management solution that meets ICE Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) mission needs in the areas of  Case Management, Subject Records, System Interfaces, and Reporting and Analytics.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: The TECS Mod Program received the full amount it requested funding for PY (2016) totaling $21.5M.  For the CY17, the amount approved totaled $21.0M.  The program’s funding position has been stated in the ADE-2C Approval of the LCCE and the CFO’s signature on the Certification of Funding Memo for the TECS Mod Program dated June 16, 2016.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) TECS Modernization (TECS MOD) program is in the Obtain life cycle phase. The program is operating within acceptable OMB ranges in terms of cost and schedule.  Since the last assessment, the program received the following milestone approval for their Post Implementation Review (PIR) in February 2017. In 3QFY17, the program met with the Acquisition Review Board (ARB) to discuss: 1) The Plan of Action and Milestones (POA&M) to mitigate issues identified during the Initial Operational Test and Evaluation (IOT&E) and 2) Provide the planned strategy to deliver Full Operational Capabilities (FOC) to achieve their Acquisition Decision Event 3 (ADE-3) in 4QFY17. The decision from the ARB included approval of the programs POA&M and the Acquisition Decision Memorandum generated the following assigned actions: 1) Secure Operational Test Authority (OTA) resources to support the development of the FOC test and evaluation strategy to Director of Operational Test & Evaluation (DOT&E) approval by May 2017. 2) Update program’s Acquisition documents no later than 3QFY17. 3) Complete the Follow-on Operational Test & Evaluation (FOT&E) and conduct ADE-3 no later than 2QFY18. 4) Maintain coordination with Customs & Border Protection (CBP) during the Seized Assets and Case Tracking System (SEACATS) modernization.  ICE TECS continues to exhibit effective program management and risk management practices; therefore, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) has upgraded the ICE TECS MOD program to a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose and goals of the Criminal Alien Identification Initiatives (CAII) are to provide information technology tools for ICE’s Secure Communities to transform the way the federal government cooperates with state and local law enforcement to identify, detain and remove aliens who are potentially removable from the United States, particularly those with criminal convictions. CAII supports DHS Mission Goal #3.2: Prevent Unlawful Immigration, and ICE Strategic Plan Objective 2.1: Detain and Remove Priority Aliens, by providing solutions that assist the key customers, stakeholders and beneficiaries, including: Law Enforcement Support Center Law Enforcement Specialists; ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations Agents; and other Federal, State, Local and Tribal law enforcement agents and officers. 
CAII provides the following benefits: 
- Expand information sharing among state, local, and federal partners. 
- Provide a scalable system that can handle changes in demand, is flexible to enable future enhancements, and is adaptable to providing functionality to other ICE and DHS systems. 
- Prioritize immigration queries for processing in the Law Enforcement Support Center using a risk-based assessment. 
- Provide an automated search and retrieval of immigration and criminal history data from multiple DHS and other US Government source systems. 
- Provide search results and other data used in status determinations to ICE agents, along with the capability for agents to conduct queries and create/amend status determinations. 
- Align with the ICE Enterprise Architecture and DHS Service Oriented Architecture models to address existing Immigration Alien Query (IAQ) functionality gaps, such as: limited workflow tracking of queries; manual researching of and copying/pasting of data from other DHS and FBI databases; limited information provided in query responses and requests for enforcement actions; and an inability to identify and track state and local lawchanges. 
- Decrease the overall time it takes to conduct subject threat assessments and to process IAQs, resulting in a decreased cost for each query or assessment. 
- Increase the % of criminal aliens identified, and subsequently increase the number of detainers placed upon them, while they are still in custody.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 454 - Enforce and administer our immigration laws through prioritized detention and removal of criminal aliens, 30982 - Goal 3.2: Prevent Unlawful Immigration
ROI Description: The CAII investment allows the continued support of key DHS and ICE missions of collecting law enforcement information, sharing the information, and providing agents with an analytic tool. The investment allows the expansion of information sharing among state, local, federal and international partners, thus complying with Presidential and Congressional mandates. The CAII projects will provide a flexible, scalable set of systems and services that easily allow for future enhancements and for additional data sets to be ingested. Even as the number of Immigration Alien Queries continues to increase, Law Enforcement Specialist productivity will be greatly increased through the use of the new systems, reflecting in cost avoidances as increased staffing will not be needed. Additionally, CAII will help provide greater accuracy and speed in the identification of criminal aliens, enabling law enforcement to detain them rather than release them back onto the streets.
Investment Requirements:
The purpose and goals of the Criminal Alien Identification Initiatives (CAII) are to provide information technology tools for ICE’s Priority Enforcement Program (PEP) to transform the way the federal government cooperates with state and local law enforcement to identify, detain and remove aliens who are potentially removable from the United States, particularly those with criminal convictions. CAII supports DHS Mission Goal #3.2: Prevent Unlawful Immigration, and ICE Strategic Plan Objective 2.1: Detain and Remove Priority Aliens, by providing solutions that assist the key customers, stakeholders and beneficiaries, including: Law Enforcement Support Center Law Enforcement Specialists; ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations Agents; and other Federal, State, Local and Tribal law enforcement agents and officers. 
CAII provides the following benefits: 
- Expand information sharing among state, local, and federal partners. 
- Provide a scalable system that can handle changes in demand, is flexible to enable future enhancements, and is adaptable to providing functionality to other ICE and DHS systems. 
- Prioritize immigration queries for processing in the Law Enforcement Support Center using a risk-based assessment. 
- Provide an automated search and retrieval of immigration and criminal history data from multiple DHS and other US Government source systems. 
- Provide search results and other data used in status determinations to ICE agents, along with the capability for agents to conduct queries and create/amend status determinations. 
- Align with the ICE Enterprise Architecture and DHS Service Oriented Architecture models to address existing Immigration Alien Query (IAQ) functionality gaps, such as: limited workflow tracking of queries; manual researching of and copying/pasting of data from other DHS and FBI databases; limited information provided in query responses and requests for enforcement actions; and an inability to identify and track stateand local law changes. 
- Decrease the overall time it takes to conduct subject threat assessments and to process IAQs, resulting in a decreased cost for each query or assessment. 
- Increase the % of criminal aliens identified, and subsequently increase the number of detainers placed upon them, while they are still in custody.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Funding for CAII is provided by the Enforcement and Removal Operations business unit.
Operational Analysis Results:
Investment Information: The purpose and goals of the Criminal Alien Identification Initiatives (CAII) are to provide information technology tools for ICE’s Priority Enforcement Program (PEP) to transform the way the federal government cooperates with state and local law enforcement to identify, detain and remove aliens who are potentially removable from the United States, particularly those with criminal convictions
Financial Performance: A refactored version of ACRIMe Mod, which addresses the performance issues, is scheduled for deployment in October 2016.
Customer Results: User Acceptance Testing (UAT) determined that ACRIMe Modernization is working as designed and provides the LESs the tools they need to determine a subject’s immigration and criminal status.  ACRIMe Mod is completing the roll out plan to add users to the system.
Business and Strategic: The primary users of this investment are ERO Law Enforcement Specialists (LESs) within the ICE Law Enforcement Support Center (LESC).  Other stakeholders include ICE Agents, Federal, State, Local and Tribal law enforcement agents and officers, DHS leadership, ICE leadership, ERO leadership, and LESC leadership.
Operational Performance: The primary deficiency of this investment is the intermittent performance issues which prevented the LESC from migrating all of the LESs onto the system.  
Innovation: Two key maintenance relationships necessary for effective sustainment are the CAII Operations & Maintenance (O&M) contractor and the LESC management.  The O&M contractor provides Tier 2 and Tier 3 Service Desk support and supports the Operations staff at the DHS Data Center.  LESC management monitors internal policies and procedures to ensure that queries are processed in an expedient manner with highly accurate results.
Risk Analysis: Test data is a significant risk to the program to be successful along with external systems availability. The program is working to use production data to mimic the production environment and performance testing. The program is always working to eliminate the dependency on CIS's PCQS system for better performance and system availability.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Criminal Alien Identification Initiatives (CAII) Program is in the Mixed lifecycle phase. The program is performing within acceptable OMB schedule thresholds; however, the cost variance is outside the acceptable range due to closed historical project data. Since the last assessment, the program has delivered Alien Criminal Response Information Management (ACRIMe) Communication Center capabilities in March 2017, National Crime Information Center (NCIC) and Phase 1 of the National Law Enforcement Telecommunications System (NLETS) Web Services capabilities in April 2017. The new capabilities will eliminate the program’s dependency on the counter proliferation investigations (CPI) switch.  The program also completed its Operational Analysis (OA) in March 2017, which analyzed performance metrics in four core areas: Customer Results, Strategic and Business Results, Financial Performance, and Innovation. The OA indicated that the program has not met all the performance measures but is expecting to meet all Key Performance Parameters (KPPs) upon achieving Full Operating Capability (FOC) in Q4FY17. The program continues to manage risk by prioritizing the most imminent risk and putting the mitigation strategy in place according to the risk management plan. Program currently has a moderate risk exposure score.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the HRIT program as a Medium Risk investment.

Investment Title: ICE - Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS)
Brief Summary: The purpose of SEVIS is to fulfill a legislative mandate to electronically collect certain information from approved schools and exchange programs on nonimmigrant students, exchange visitors, and their dependents.
