· Directly supporting operational functions like the National Targeting Center – Passenger, National Targeting Center – Cargo, Passenger Analytical Units, Advanced Targeting Units, cargo, passenger, and port/border enforcement program offices.
Customer Results: Satisfaction remains high. User Acceptance Testing is an ongoing activity and performed throughout all maintenance releases. 
Strategic & Business Results:
· Supports CBP officers and OGAs providing 24/7/365 screening capability.
· ATS is used to analyze over 17M transactions per day.
· Oracle production databases and data warehouses hold about 200 TBs of data.
· An example of how large our databases includes one with 83 tables that have roughly 26.18 billion rows.
· ATS delivers one or more shippable increments of functionality each month via Agile methodology.
· ATS has procured additionalconsolidated database storage units to increase data capacity for ATS disaster recovery systems at DC2.
Financial Performance: Financial performance remains steady with little variance in cost and schedule.
Innovation: ATS will continue to maintain and meet expectations required of its customers and stakeholders.
Oper. Performance Measures: ATS is meeting or exceeding the targets for FY16 based on current measures.
Risk Analysis: Risks are being managed through agile scrums and stakeholder communication is very high.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Automated Targeting System (ATS) Maintenance program is in the Support life cycle phase. The program is currently operating within OMB recommended threshold for cost and schedule variances. Since the last assessment the program completed integration of Internal Affairs (IA) vetting process within ATS to enhance vetting checks and streamline the vetting process to support the hiring goal of 2,000 CBP officers. Also deployed auto populate Advance Passenger Information Sharing (APIS) and Passenger Name Records (PNR) detail pages within Unified Passenger (UPAX) application on 3QFY17.  This will eliminate the need for users to access Automated Targeting System-Passenger (ATS-P) for older APIS records and PNR records. The program continues O&M activities along with infrastructure refresh and adopted agile methodology to delivers iterative quarterly maintenance releases. The program currently has a Moderate Risk Exposure Score. However, the program continues to manage risk by prioritizing the most imminent risk and putting the mitigation strategy in place according to the risk management plan. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the ATS program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of TECS Mod (TM) program is to modernize the core TECS subject record and support services for all TECS users and to address screening requirements of federal agencies. After modernization, it will improve the technological and data sharing functions at and between the Ports of Entry (POEs) and to improve Primary and Secondary Inspection processes at border POEs. 
 
The goal is to prevent terrorists and terrorist weapons from entering the United States and to facilitate entry and exit for law-abiding travelers.
  
Current benefits of TECS Mod program are: 
1.     reduce the possibility of missing potential terrorist who should have been intercepted by data integration and search capabilities
2.     improve access to person-centric information, allowed person data to be re-queried upon inspection at Air/Sea Primary 
3.     improve the effectiveness and efficiency of secondary inspections by sending data from the primary to the secondary application upon referral, ensuring integration from primary to secondary.  
 
The long term benefits include improved overall functionalities, reliability and accuracy of primary query responses. Modernized report modules give managers visibility into field activities and the ability to supervise them. It complies with CBP and DHS Service-Oriented Architecture.
 
TECS Mod supports the DHS and CBP missions by protecting the nation from the entry of dangerous or illegal people, ensuring efficient flow of lawful people crossing US borders and enabling effective decision making through rigorous screening of travelers to provide improved intelligence and information sharing. It directly addresses the provisions of sections 201 through 203 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002.


Key customers include DHS (CBP, ICE, Secret Service, TSA, Coast Guard, USCIS), DoJ (ATF, DEA, FBI), DoS (Visas, Passport Office, Bureau of Consular Affairs and Office of Diplomatic Security), DoT (IRS and Officeof Foreign Assets Control), Department of Commerce, DoD. 
Stakeholders providing oversight are CBP OFO, CBP CIO, CBP CPO, CBP CAE, DHS HQ, and ICE TECS Mod. 
Other beneficiaries are CARICOM (Association of Caribbean Nations), Mexico, New Zealand, Australia, Canada, Air Carriers, US domestic terminals and commercial ports of entry.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description: TECS Modernization's return on investment is 0.15.  This number was based on risk adjusted program costs over the life of the program of $538.591M into adjusted net benefits over the life of the program of $81.588 M.  The adjusted net benefits are the net present value and is the difference between the total discounted baseline of $620.179 M and the adjusted program costs.  The benefits are in the form of reduced costs for operational maintenance over the initial 14 year duration of the life cycle, especially in the final years as maintenance costs were expected to greatly exceed current costs as the system became increasingly difficult if not impossible to maintain.  Other benefits that could not be accurately quantified but were considered significant were the improvement of management reporting by which managers could extract information from operational databases that could significantly improve their ability to monitor and supervise TECS processes.  Increased efficiency, accuracy and reliability of responses to primary queries provide additional benefits to inspectors and to travelers.
Investment Requirements:
TECS Mod program fulfills the requirement specified in the Homeland Security Act of 2002 Section 201 – 203: prevent terrorists and terrorist weapons from entering the United States and to facilitate entry and exit for law-abiding travelers. And it conforms DHS strategic goal of Protecting the Nation from Dangerous People - DHS Strategic Mission 2: Securing and Managing America's Borders and CBP Strategic Goal 2: Securing and Expediting the flow of people and movement of goods. 
In order to fulfill all these requirements, TECS Mod program is to modernize the core TECS subject record and support services for all TECS users and to screening requirements of federal agencies. After modernization, it will improve the technological and data sharing functions at and between the Ports of Entry (POEs) and to improve Primary and Secondary Inspection processes at border POEs. 
Currently, TM program has already
1.             reduced the possibility of missing someone who should have been intercepted by data integration and search capabilities
2.             improved access to person-centric information, allowed person data to be re-queried upon inspection at Air/Sea Primary 
3.             improved the effectiveness and efficiency of secondary inspections by sending data from the primary to the secondary application upon referral, ensuring integration from primary to secondary.  
 
After the complete modernization, TM will improve overall functionalities, reliability and accuracy of primary query responses. Modernized report modules will give managers visibility into field activities and the ability to supervise them. It will complies with CBP and DHS Service-Oriented Architecture.
PM Qualificiations: 4 - Other certification with 4 or more years PM experience (within the last five years)
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There have been no changes for the Prior Year and the Current Year from the FY16 president's Budget.
Operational Analysis Results:
Financial Performance
The program meets Financial Performance goals by remaining consistent with program LCCE. Based on the expenditure data derived from all relevant invoices of FY15, it was determined that the variance between actual cost (61.232M) and the projected cost ($62.224M) was only 1.6%. 
 
Customer Results
The program continuously meets customer’s satisfaction. TECS capabilities continue to be modernized by replacing mainframe technology using enterprise architecture (infrastructure, databases, user interfaces), establishing infrastructure at a second data center, developing new applications, and enhancing existing applications. These efforts address requirements for improved system availability, scalability, and sustainability.  

Business and Strategic
TM has met the Strategic and Business results by supporting DHS and CBP missions. It protects the nation from the entry of dangerous or illegal people, ensuring efficient flow of lawful people crossing US borders and enabling effective decision making through rigorous screening of travelers to provide improved intelligence and information sharing. The investment remains a priority for DHS due to its focus to improve the technological and data-sharing functions at and between the ports of entry (POEs) and to improve primary and secondary inspection processes at border POEs.   

Operational Performance
The modernized system is meeting all 8 Key Performance Parameters established for the program. As incidents (problem reports) are reported by users, they are triaged, prioritized against ongoing work, and resolved. The majority of reported incidents are able to be resolved by the Tier II team personnel, which greatly reduces the impact on the development teams who are focused on finishing modernization work. 

Innovation
It has been achieved by introducing the dual-data center operations. Fully modernized TECS will be operating from the first data center and work will continue to replicate and operate critical functionality from the second datacenter. This replication will be more than a disaster recovery site in that those replicated functions will be fully operable from the second data center in a switchover capacity. 

Risk
TECS Mod has weekly Program Management meetings to scrutinize its internal operations and has by-weekly risk management meetings to record, track, and report all risks and issues. TM program has not identified any internal risk to efficiency and operability.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) TECS Modernization program is currently in the Mixed life cycle phase. The program exhibits effective program management and risk management practices, and operates within acceptable OMB thresholds for cost and schedule variances, allowing the program to meet its mission objectives. Since the last assessment, the program has accomplished as planned, the build-out of Data Center 2 (DC2) and is on schedule to complete the DC2 milestone to switchover core capabilities; allowing primary applications to run out of DC2 during scheduled maintenance. This milestone marks the program’s ability to discontinue the dependency on the legacy TECS system during maintenance activities. Additionally, the program has also updated its Life Cycle Cost Estimate (Annual update) and routed for final approval with the Component Acquisition Executive. The LCCE remains within the APB cost threshold. As TECS continues to monitor system stability, data quality and performance, the program will also coordinate with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) TECS and the Seized Assets and Case Tracking System (SECATS) modernization to ensure successful integration points and maintain functionality for CBP and ICE users TECS is on track to achieve its Acquisition Decision Event 3 (ADE-3) scheduled for 3QFY17.  The TECS leadership team has identified realistic strategies for delivering and meeting the business needs of the organization; the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the CBP TECS Modernization program to a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: Infrastructure supports the following DHS QHSR missions: Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security, Secure and Manage our Borders, and Administer Our Immigration Laws. It is essential to the DHS mission because it is the IT backbone that supports all of CBP’s systems. The systems supported by CBP’s IT infrastructure allow for a unified border presence and provides for more efficient and effective sharing of information amongst trade and law enforcement agencies. CBP’s IT infrastructure serves a variety of Federal, state, local, and international agencies including but not limited to CBP Officers, Border Patrol Agents, Air and Marine Officials, Agricultural specialists, law enforcement personnel, domestic and international trade partners, and travelers to and from the US. The CBP Infrastructure supports over 65,000 CBP users, provides innovative IT services and solutions, maintains 24x7 operations, deployment, monitoring, and maintenance of CBP systems, and provides full service technical support to field and headquarter employees. The CBP Infrastructure program primarily supports three goals in OIT Strategic Implementation Plan including: modernize and transform the infrastructure, transform and shape the workforce and communications, and streamline and automate the data center and network management environment. The CBP Infrastructure program also contains technical performance measures including but not limited to maintaining 98% network availability, providing 24x7 TECS support to end users over 99% of the time, and a same day technology service desk resolution of 72% of all first level technology support tickets. The IT systems provide qualitative benefits to CBP by provisioning vital tools that CBP and other federal agencies use to defend our borders and support our Ports of Entry (POE). The systems assist CBP Officers in the identification of potential threats from terrorists, weapons of mass destruction and bioterrorism, and also curbs the flow of illicit goodsand people. The systems provide the means by which U.S. Criminal and Trade Laws are enforced and provide the capability to collect tariffs and taxes associated with international trade and commerce. The CBP Infrastructure program’s primary stakeholders, key customers, and primary beneficiaries include but are not limited to CBP Officers, Border Patrol Agents, Air and Marine Officials, Agricultural specialists, other law enforcement personnel, and domestic and international trade partners.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description: Currently, there is no DME funding for this program. The Infrastructure investment has been operational since 2004.  The CBP Infrastructure program supports multiple stakeholders within trade and law enforcement agencies and provides the functionality and means by which U.S. Criminal and Trade Laws are enforced and provide the capability to collect tariffs and taxes related to international trade and commerce.  Because the program supports the infrastructure, that is backbone architecture, by which other systems effectively communicate, and it is considered to be in an operations and maintenance (O&M) mode, a return on investment value cannot be predicted or determined.  A return on investment cannot be determined at this level due to the wide range of support provided to other programs utilizing Infrastructure services.  Their independent values and the overall benefits (returns) that the Infrastructure provides each program can only be measured in the successful IT communications and the ability to facilitate mission success.
Investment Requirements:
Legislative Mandate: Data Center Migration - Fulfills the Department's mission, strategic goals and objectives to create "One Infrastructure" for all DHS and addresses the DHS Secretary  "S1" Goal to unify IT and technology Infrastructure across DHS. https://cio.gov/wp-content/uploads/downloads/2012/09/25-Point-Implementation-Plan-to-Reform-Federal-IT.pdf
Published Agency Strategic Plan: Secure and manage the flows of people and goods to enable prosperity and minimize risk.https://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/dhs-strategic-plan-fy-2012-2016.pdf

Presidential Direction: HSPD7 Critical Infrastructure Identification, Prioritization, and Protection. https://www.dhs.gov/homeland-security-presidential-directive-7#1.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: No significant changes.
Operational Analysis Results:
The Infrastructure investment continues to meet customer expectations of CBP and performs efficiently and effectively for end users and management.  The Infrastructure program measures program performance covering Customer Results, Strategic and Business results, Financial Performance, Innovation, Operational Performance Measures, and Risk Analysis. 
Customer Results: Satisfaction remains high. User assessment ongoing as part of routine business processes.
Strategic and Business/Mission Analysis: Shows the many benefits the Infrastructure provides to CBP/DHS include its ability to perform as the IT backbone that provides support for all of CBP’s applications and the rest of DHS. The IT infrastructure is the data network that supports among other things, the data storage, transmission, and delivery of all vetting/screening data from CBP and/other DHS data centers to CBP’s front line. 
Financial Performance: Financial performance remains steady with little variance in cost and schedule.
Innovation: Infrastructure will continue to maintain and meet expectations required of its customers and stakeholders.
Operational Performance Measures: Infrastructure is meeting or exceeding the targets for FY16 based on current measures for 7 out of 8 measures.  Maintain the Tier 1 Average Wait Time is the metric not meeting its goal of under one minute, however there is a plan of action in place to get the measure back on track.
Risk categories include Security, Reliability of Systems and Dependencies and Interoperability between this Investment and Others and - the probability and risk for impact are mostly high for each of these risks although there are mitigation plans in each instance.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Infrastructure Program is in the Support Lifecycle phase. Program cost and schedule variance are within OMB specified range. CBP Infrastructure generates system operations logs and performance data to prepare management performance reports. CBP Infrastructure is implementing a plan for Cloud deployment from mainframe computing. Cloud Full Operating Capability (FOC) is forecast for Q2 FY18. An Operational Analysis was published during Q4 FY16. It reports that the investment continues to meet CBP management and end user expectations. Key Performance Parameter goals are being surpassed for network availability, TECS Service, and Technical Service Desk operations. These measure the IT infrastructure benefits that support applications for data storage, transmission, query, and delivery of vetting/screening information between data centers and CBP’s front line. Insufficient program budget is preventing software product enhancements and network upgrades. These issues could cause negative effects on data and information handling if not addressed. The program is advocating at the Component and DHS levels for adequate funding. Systems operations and maintenance are meeting KPP required levels. All software and hardware licenses are being renewed per schedule for uninterrupted support. “Infrastructure? enables four other CBP Lines of Business comprised of 12 applications. The program reports significant risk exposure. Cost issues are being addressed through equipment modernization to decrease maintenance expense. Schedule is being addressed with staffing initiatives. Technical concerns are being mitigated with the Office of Information Technology for system availability. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) CIO assesses CBP Infrastructure as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
AFI’s purpose is to support the continued evolution of CBP as an intelligence-driven organization and improve the efficiency and effectiveness of intelligence lifecycle processes. AFI has evolved into a data analysis and intelligence product creation and dissemination platform that supports multiple DHS components, specifically CBP and ICE.  AFI's goal is to provide technology and tools that produce timely and actionable intelligence for DHS personnel protecting our borders, enhances collaboration across DHS intelligence analysts in a shared workspace, and more effectively shares threat information and intelligence to other Federal partners charged with securing our nation. AFI benefits  include shorter time and expense in disseminating intelligence products to intelligence analysts in the field because reports are posted in a main repository and distributed to pre-identified communities. AFI serves as the one-stop shop for CBP and ICE-produced intelligence products with access available to intelligence organizations throughout DHS. AFI leverages existing legacy systems and provides an enhanced query, analysis, production, collaboration, and dissemination tool.  AFI provides an automated function that integrates information from multiple systems into a single platform that reduces manual effort and saves users valuable time.  AFI benefits contribute to DHS QHSR goals and CBP goals. These goals include QHSR Mission 1 Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security  and QHSR Mission 2 Secure and Manage our Borders.  AFI focuses on identifying the tools and conveyances used by terrorists and apply knowledge to remain at the forefront of global law enforcement and counter-terrorism efforts. More information is provided in the Operational Analysis.
The principal customers and stakeholders of AFI are the end users of the system: officers, agents and intelligence analysts within CBP offices, such as the Office of Field Operations (OFO), Office of Border Patrol (OBP), Office of Air& Marine (OAM), Office of International Trade (OT), and Office of Intelligence (OI) and external offices (U.S. Coast Guard (USCG).Beneficiaries include the U.S. public, ICE analysts, and CBP officers and analysts.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description: The return on investment for AFI includes quantifiable and non-quantifiable factors.  This is primarily driven by  two quantifiable benefits: cost savings/cost avoidance, and services/products delivered to internal customers.  The first benefit derives from the value of not hiring additional intelligence analysts over the number required for AFI. The second benefit denotes the projected value of intelligence products created in AFI.  The AFI program creates efficiencies in collating and disseminating intelligence products, allowing for increased effectiveness and efficiency for CBP officers, Border Patrol and Air and Marine agents in utilizing strategic and practical intelligence at and between ports of entry.  AFI also includes non-quantifiable benefits.  Other benefits are positive contributions of the AFI program that cannot readily be categorized numerically, such as improving identification and targeting of potential terrorists and terrorist weapons through risk management and automated advanced and enhanced information, and preventing terrorists and terrorist weapons from entering the United States at ports of entry. The AFI program has led to the phase out of ICE Homeland Security Investigations (HIS) Fusion Program on September 2012 to promote cost saving measures and efficiency. Cost savings associated with the conversion to AFI equals about 1.85 million a year. AFI takes into consideration the projected value of benefits, new and previous O&M costs, and capital investment costs. The co-location of a variety of analytical tools will reduce the expenditure of separate offices purchasing multiple licenses and software packages by moving to an enterprise solution.  AFI continues to be on the forefront of intelligence driven information sharing.  This is critical to CBP intelligence gathering, analysis, user satisfaction.  Analysts utilize the AFI system to make critical decision based solutions based on automated information.  This is vital for collaboration between DHS components and multiple systems of use.
Investment Requirements:
House Report 110-862 DHS Appropriations Bill, 2009 authorized and appropriated $42.75M in funding for AFI. 
Further information can be found at the following link: http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CRPT-110hrpt862/pdf/CRPT-110hrpt862.pdf
 An OIG audit was performed on September 2nd 2015. OIG performed this audit " to determine the status of AFI implementation and whether effective controls have been applied to protect the sensitive information processed and stored by the system. OIG recommended CBP address deficiencies identified in AFI configuration settings and system documentation. CBP responded in concurrence with all seven recommendations and have implemented corrective actions to address the findings. OIG considers the recommendations resolved and closed“– (OIG-15-137).  Further information about the audit and CBP's response can be found at  the following link: https://www.oig.dhs.gov/assets/Mgmt/2015/OIG-15-137-Sep15.pdf  
AFI contributes to QHSR Mission 1 Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security and Mission 2 Secure and Manage Our Borders by providing intelligence analysts with technical capabilities that lead to securing and managing our borders. These capabilities include providing quicker access to multiple databases with information on persons and cargo entering or leaving the United States to assist in identifying trends in smuggling of illicit cargo, persons, or currency and monitoring activities of transnational criminal organizations. AFI allows analysts to quickly disseminate their intelligence findings and conclusions to users who can act in a tactical manner at US ports of entry or along the border on those findings.
https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/FY14-18%20Strategic%20Plan.PDF.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There has been no changes in funding levels. For FY 2017 and beyond, AFI funding levels are currently expected to be similar to that outlined in the President's Budget and consistent with the AFI O&M lifecycle.
Operational Analysis Results:
AFI supports multiple CBP and DHS missions and goals.  Specifically Preventing Terrorism and Enhancing Security.  The AFI program creates efficiencies in collating and disseminating intelligence products, allowing for increase effectiveness and efficiency for CBP officers, OBP and Air and Marine agents in utilizing strategic and practical intelligence at and between ports of entry. AFI provides technology and tools that produce timely and actionable intelligence to DHS personnel charged with protecting our nation from threats posed by the illegal cross-border movement of goods and people, to include threat of terrorist activity. 
AFI has evolved into a data analysis and intelligence product creation and dissemination platform that supports multiple DHS components, specifically Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).  This has led to other DHS components inquiring about having access to AFI.
Customer satisfaction remains high, financial performance remains steady with little variance in cost and schedule. AFI continues to meet expectations.
Financial Performance: AFI continues to add data sources that promote cost reduction throughout DHS. 
Strategic and Business Results: working with SMEs, AFI re-engineered search results to be more relevant to analyst user needs.  Excel export capabilities were enhanced to provide a richer set of export data. In FY16 AFI developed and deployed initial capabilities for embedded tools for link analysis, temporal analysis and geospatial rendering.
Customer satisfaction/results:  working closely with ICE, AFI improved Intelligence Product workflow capabilities, product descriptive data to support ICE metrics, implemented additional product types to support organizational needs.
Innovation: AFI continues to be on the forefront with intelligence gathering and user experience.  Users are able to analyze and make critical decisions from vast amount of interrelated data based on queries. In FY16 AFI has converted to Hadoop data services with Elastic search technology, expanding AFI’s ability to leverage large amounts of unstructured data for quickly and efficiently. AFI added 6 new data sources in FY16.
Performance Measures: AFI is meeting or exceeding the targets for FY16 based on current performance measures. Over 37 million query to system records were performed in FY16. 
Risk Analysis: Risks are being managed through agile scrums and stakeholder communication is very high.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP), Analytical Framework for Intelligence (AFI) program is in the Support life cycle phase. AFI is operating within acceptable OMB ranges for cost and schedule variances. AFI continues to successfully provide enhanced search and analytical capabilities to identify, apprehend, and prosecute potential threats. Since the last assessment, AFI implemented an ontology service that supports the CBP Commissioner’s Data Analysis and Visualization goals. This service generated 53M objects for display in AFI as well as other automatic targeting systems. Additionally, AFI deployed secure and auditable services that allow developers to produce analytical tools based on the underlying AFI infrastructure. This resulted in the deployment of a tool that automates the task of searching for crossings related to a vehicle and finding connections to all people that have crossed in it. As parts of its Operations and Maintenance (O&M) schedule, the program continues to successfully deploy quarterly maintenance releases. Additionally, AFI continues to effectively meet or exceed its performance metrics, such as the increase number of AFI queries to system records, and AFI system availability. The program continuously monitors both high and low risks and has defined mitigation strategies in place.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the Analytical Framework for Intelligence (AFI) program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: The Tactical Communications (TACCOM) Modernization investment purpose is to redesign existing Land Mobile Radio (LMR) systems, enhance/replace unsupportable legacy infrastructure, address National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) narrow-banding mandate, and anticipate future needs for increased capacity due to mandated growth in agent and officer staff, while aligning with future DHS-wide wireless systems. As stated in the 2014 Quadrennial Homeland Security Review Executive Summary-Secure and Manage our Borders, “We must continue to improve upon border security?–Tactical voice communication capabilities are fundamental tools that enable coordinated activities in campus and remote environments to secure the nation’s borders against illegal entry of people and goods while managing legitimate travel and trade. Investment goals–provide critical land mobile radio communication coverage; provide Advanced Encryption Standard; provide federal, state, local, tribal, territory, private sector, international law enforcement interoperability capabilities complying with NTIA P-25 mandates; modernize, replace unsupported, antiquated communication equipment. TACCOM benefits include enhanced mission safety for officers/agents protecting the U.S.–a three-fold coverage increase in previously deficient coverage areas–officer/agent radios are their lifelines; NTIA interoperability compliance to enable multi-stakeholder critical situation communications; encrypted communication to prevent criminal element listening, stealing, sensitive voice traffic; upgraded digital communication equipment requiring maintenance less often, reducing operational cost; and ultimately U.S. citizen protection from terrorist threat. TACCOM supports the DHS mission–Secure and Manage Our Borders. Key customers and stakeholders include over 46,000 agents and officers from CBP operational component organizations: U.S. Border Patrol, the Office of Field Operations, and the Office of Air and Marine. Other beneficiaries include the U. S. public; federal agencies such as the Department of Interior; Department of Agriculture; Drug Enforcement Administration; Federal Bureau of Investigation; Department of Transportation; interagency partners like U.S. Coast Guard; Immigration and Customs Enforcement; and partnerships with state, local, tribal, territory, private sector, international law enforcement agencies to share information and conduct coordinated/integrated operations.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description: TACCOM PMO developed an AoA that included a Return on Investment (ROI) analysis used to calculate the most cost effective modernization and implementation strategy that met all Program Office requirements. The detailed analysis included developing Life Cycle Cost Estimates (LCCEs) for the three viable alternatives–Conventional Vote Scan, Trunked, Simulcast–to compare to the Status Quo/Legacy LMR System to conduct a financial analysis. The financial analysis included ROI, Net Present Value, and Payback Period for each alternative using the Status Quo/Legacy LMR System as the baseline. Tools used to support analysis were Crystal Ball (for Monte Carlo simulations), the Automated Cost Estimating Integrated Tools Cost Estimating Relationship Library Tool, and MS Excel. The preferred alternative is the conventional vote scan system because it possesses the lowest acquisition cost, has the highest return on investment with 26.13%, and the lowest payback period. The government benefits are: 1) Improved communication capability for border protection and agent safety; 2) Improved operational availability (>90%)/reliability/maintainability (refreshing/updating obsolete equipment); 3) Increased system coverage (innovative technology/increased remote communications capabilities/more RF tower locations); 4) Increased network capacity (improved compliance with NTIA narrowband mandate, foundation for future data/video capability); 5) Increased security (advanced Encryption Standard (AES)); 6) Improved situational awareness (faster incident response); 7) Better interoperability (implementation of P25 standard enabling multi-agency communication capabilities). Externally, these benefits provide same-technology-level tactical communications between government law enforcement/emergency management and external partners, as many external partners currently employ (or plan to) modernized communication capabilities. This leads to quicker incident/emergency response times enabling efficientinformation dissemination to external government organizations, improved coordination between federal, state/province and local public safety agencies, increased government transparency and accountability. Externally, these benefits provide the ultimate value to U.S. citizens through increased citizen safety/border protection.
Investment Requirements: The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) of 2009 earmarked $60M for the modernization of Tactical Communications equipment at CBP.  In addition, $10M in BSFIT supplemental funds were dedicated to CBP Tactical Communications - http://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/recovery/CBP_Tactical_Communications_Modernization_Program_2009-05-15.pdf. TACCOM directly supports and continues to adhere to basic homeland security mission “Secure and Manage Our Borders? as revised in the 2014 QHSR Review. CBP is responsible for securing the nation’s borders against illegal entry of people and goods while facilitating legitimate travel and trade. To support this mission, CBP operates and maintains one of the largest Land Mobile Radio (LMR) tactical voice communications infrastructures in the Federal government. Tactical communications capabilities are essential to coordinating mission activities and protecting the safety of over 44,000 CBP law enforcement agents and officers. These agents and officers operate in remote areas where their radio is often their only communications channel to coordinate activities or summon assistance.  By improving coverage, capacity, reliability, and encryption, the modernization effort provides critical communications support to the agents and officers who secure the nation’s borders - http://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/2014-qhsr-final-508.pdf. TACCOM upgrades LMR to P25: Section 4.0 of DHS 4300A requires that all LMR systems comply with P25 security standards.  Interoperability between the wireless tactical systems of different DHS Components, as well as those of other federal, state, and local agencies, is essential to the homeland security mission - 4.6 Wireless Tactical Systems - https://www.dhs.gov/publication/dhs-4300a-sensitive-systems-handbook and TACCOM addresses the NTIA narrowband mandate – https://www.ntia.doc.gov/page/2011/manual-regulations-and-procedures-federal-radio-frequency-management-redbook. On March 11, 2015,the Department  of Homeland Security (DHS) responded to a Government Accountability Office (GAO) report, “Border Security: Additional Efforts Needed to Address Persistent Challenges in Achieving Radio Interoperability.? The report contained a recommendation that U.S CBP develop a plan to monitor the performance of its deployed radio systems. CBP concurred with this recommendation; an approved TACCOM Performance Monitoring Plan is in place. Currently, there are no outstanding audit findings.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: No changes.
Operational Analysis Results: FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE ANALYSIS: The program operates within financial baseline thresholds. The investment LCCE was approved in December 2015 and is reviewed on an annual schedule. The program has identified an Operation and Maintenance (O&M) funding shortfall for FY17; a mitigation strategy is in place. Additional O&M funding shortfall have also been identified for FY18-FY22. CUSTOMER SATISFACTION RESULTS: An independent organization conducted an Operational Assessment (Customer Survey) of operational effectiveness and suitability for the Houlton and Miami sectors. The Assessment concluded the Tactical Communications (TACCOM) System is operationally effective and operationally suitable with limitations. The assessment highlighted interoperability limitations with non-CBP agencies and the limitations on the ability to collect reliability, availability and maintainability data and a shortfall with respect to accessible user refresher training. BUSINESS AND STRATEGIC ANALYSIS RESULTS: The TACCOM program aligns directly with the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) strategic Goal 2.1 (Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches) and DHS Secure Border Strategic Plan Goal 1.1 (Develop and deploy the optimal mix of personnel, infrastructure, and technology and response capabilities to identify, classify, and interdict cross-border violators). The program has an approved acquisition program baseline and Life Cycle Cost Estimate (LCCE). An active performance monitoring plan is in place producing monthly reports. OPERATIONAL PERFORMANCE MEASURES: The TACCOM Modernizations program has one performance measure for financial performance, 3 measures for strategic and business results and one for customer satisfaction. The program is exceeding established goals on 4 of 5 measures; the 5th measure is being re-examined. INNOVATION: TACCOM actively investigates future technology including the next generation of broadband technology. Two innovative technologies being examined are Iridium satellite radios for employment in areas where there is no Land Mobile Radio (LMR) coverage and the Digital Vehicular Repeater System to improve overall LMR communications for officers in the field. RISK ANALYSIS: The TACCOM Modernization program has an active risk management program with participation from the leadership of the program office and supporting branches. Risks are identified in accordance with applicable references; each risk has a detailed mitigation plan.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Tactical Communications (TACCOM) Modernization program is in the Mixed life cycle. Schedule and Cost Variance (SV/CV) are within OMB specified range. The most recent Acquistion Review Board (ARB) obtained Under Secretary for Management (USM) approval for program Life Cycle Cost Estimate (LCCE), Integrated Logistic Support Plan (ILSP) and Acquisition Program Baseline (APB). Key Performance Parameters (KPPs) are meeting threshold values. The program Acquisition Plan (AP) was approved by the Office of Information & Technology (OIT) during Q2 FY17. The FY17 TACCOM budget is using Development, Modernization, and Enhancement (DME) carryover funds and Operations & Maintenace (O&M)  funds. The program will experience an outyear O&M funding shortfall. A funding mitigation strategy was approved at the CBP portfolio level that allows uninterrupted radio service. TACCOM restructured LCCE reporting to include development and technical refresh costs in response to CBP Component Acquisition Executive recommendations. This change improves reported investment data. Incorporation of the TACCOM Digital-In-Place (DIP) Radio Internet Protocol System (RIPS) will continue during FY17. This effort integrates multiple CBP radio systems into a single IP based network to enhance communications interoperability. The TACCOM Operational Analysis (OA) was approved during Q4 FY16. Findings for “improvement opportunities? guide TACCOM program direction. The recent “Customer Results Assessment? obtained positive results for operational effectiveness and equipment suitability. The “user perspective? survey data found that TACCOM meets “voice communications operational needs? and maintains “acceptable operational availability?. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the TACCOM Program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The main purpose of Block 1 System is increased situational awareness and persistence surveillance across the Tucson (TUS-1) and Ajo (AJO-1) areas of responsibility within the Tucson Sector. Block 1 supports U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agents and officers to effectively detect, identify, classify and resolve illegal incursions at the border. 

The goal of the Block 1 System is to improve the U.S. Border Patrol's (USBP) ability to detect, identify, and classify incursions at the border.
 
The Block 1 system provides improved safety benefits to USBP by providing better tactical advantages through: over-watch capabilities, which use geo-positioning information with visual verification of agent locations relative to threats; improved geo-synchronization actions for risk reduction through the use of landmarks and terrain references on the common operating picture (COP); geo-spatial tracking; visual verification; real time information on specific threats; and increased visual coverage through the use of sensors.  
  
The system contributes to mission delivery by providing technological tools throughout CBP, but specifically allows USBP to focus efforts border security and enforcement resources in areas other than Tucson and AJO, Arizona. This provides flexibility in deploying assets and personnel throughout the central and eastern Arizona region. The system has improved USBP's situational awareness of illegal cross-border activity, leading to increased narcotic seizures and apprehensions of undocumented aliens. There were approximately 2,338 apprehensions and approximately 152, 204 pounds of marijuana seized from Mar 2015 to Mar 2016. 
  
The USBP is the key customer of the Block 1 system and primary stakeholder. Other stakeholders include: the Office of Field Operations (OFO), which houses the detainees; the Office of Air & Marine (AMO), which provides aerial assistance with the apprehensions; and the Office of Information and Technology (OIT) and Facilities Management and Engineering (FM&E). The Block 1 program office interfaces with additional external stakeholders, including: industry (repair/support services contractors), public property custodians (Pima County Counsel and state, local and tribal governments).

The primary beneficiaries are US citizens that own land on the border and citizens that frequent the national parks within the Tucson sector.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description:
A traditional return on investment calculation for Block 1 is difficult to quantify given there is no means to measure “return? in terms of dollars for a system that produces increased situational awareness for USBP that results in increased apprehensions and drug seizures along the 53 mile section of the Arizona border with Mexico. Moreover, prior to the Block 1 system deployment, USBP did not possess a capability to accurately determine the amount of illegal traffic in the area currently covered by the Block 1 system. The ROI calculation shows -90% for the expected useful life of the Block 1 system. 

Compared to the baseline operating costs from which the ROI was calculated (1 border patrol agent, per one mile of border in AZ, 24/7), the operating costs for Block 1 system are estimated to be considerably lower. ROI was calculated by (Operating Costs without Block 1 - Operating Costs with Block 1) divided by the Capital Investment costs, providing the same level of surveillance. The internal benefit of improved situational awareness on the Arizona border has increased USBP’s ability to execute its mission elements and processes. These elements/processes include: predict, deter, detect, identify, classify, track, respond, and resolve. The Block 1 system integrates multiple sensor outputs into one COP and provides USBP with persistent coverage within the Block 1 sensor viewsheds (see definition – Supporting Comments). In addition, these sensors are able to provide USBP Agents with an increased visual coverage area and more opportunities for early identification and classification. 

Another internal benefit includes improving officer safety via providing BP with tactical advantages. The Block 1 system is able to provide the Border Patrol with better tactical advantages through: over watch capabilities which use geo-positioning information with visual verification of Agent locations relative to threats; better geo-synchronization actions for risk reduction through the use of landmarks and terrain references on the COP; geo-spatial tracking; visual verification; real time information on specific threats; and increased visual coverage through the use of sensors. 

Benefits external to the government include landowners within the Block 1 system coverage that have fewer claims from damaged fences and overall fewer property thefts. This also applies to citizen use of national wildlife refuges within the Block 1 system.
Investment Requirements: There are no legislative mandates, outstanding audit findings/material weaknesses, or Presidential Directives for the Block 1 investment.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: The funding levels did not involve any significant changes.
Operational Analysis Results:
The Block 1 system is a maturing system in operations and maintenance with an additional year of sustainment knowledge and continues to serve as an essential component in CBP’s arsenal to protect the nation’s borders.  
 
Strategic/Business: Block 1 met or exceeded strategic and business objectives for the PY. Block 1 succeeds in its mission to enable USBP agents to effectively detect, identify, classify, and resolve illegal incursions across the 53 miles of international border in Arizona by leveraging the suite of integrated day and night cameras, radars, unattended ground sensors, and a communications package. 

Customer satisfaction remains above average, operational performance remains steady and above the objectives with little variance in cost. Schedule delays have occurred with technical refresh activities due to shifting priorities and complex obsolescence issues. The system supports increased situational awareness, increased officer safety, improved operational effectiveness, decreased smuggling activity, fewer migrant deaths, and provides a manpower force multiplier.
 
Financial performance: The Block 1 Program Office has focused on reducing annual sustainment costs while not jeopardizing the operational performance of the system by transitioning logistics elements from contractor maintenance logistics support (CMLS) to organic Government support. 
 
Innovation: The Block 1 investment continued to explore opportunities to provide innovative approaches to border security. In collaboration with the Office of Information and Technology (OIT), the Block 1 PM is investigating the potential of integrating the Block 1 NOC/SOC within the OIT infrastructure.
 
Operational Performance Measures: The Block 1 system fell short of meeting the overall Operational Availability target of 95%, achieving an average availability of 93% in FY2016. The root cause of this shortfall is ongoing obsolescence and inoperability issues, and the Program Manager has implemented corrective actions to address the identified issues. 
 
Risk Analysis: The Block 1 PM maintains a Risk Management Plan that follows DHS/OMB best practices, including direction on how the program prioritizes and determines impact of risk and maintaining consistent mitigation strategies. The program utilizes the Active Risk Manager tool to assist with overall risk analysis, and regularly updates the program Risk Register to communicate risk status to the IPT and other stakeholders.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Block 1 program is an Operations & Maintenance (O&M) investment currently in the Support life cycle phase. Block 1 continues to operate within acceptable ranges for cost and schedule variances. The program continues to successfully meet its mission, enabling CBP agents to effectively detect, identify, classify, and resolve illegal incursions across the international border in Arizona. Since the last assessment, Block 1 continues to maintain its schedule to ensure timely technology refreshes and upgrades of all its systems. Block 1 has obtained approval from the United States Border Patrol (USBP) to replace Block 1 with the Integrated Fixed Towers (IFT) program. This replacement will decrease Operations and Maintenance costs and will increase performance with respect to the new and approved wider view radars and HD cameras. This effort is expected to be completed by 4QFY18.  Block 1 performance targets is slightly below the projected 85% threshold due to intermittent radar issues, however, other surveillance equipment, such as cameras, are utilized to continue USBP operations. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the Block 1 program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of Integrated Fixed Towers (IFT) Program is to provide automated and persistent wide-area surveillance to detect, track, identify and classify illegal entries through a series of integrated sensors and a common operating picture (COP). IFT supports the United States (U.S.) Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Strategic Goals articulated in the Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR) Report published by DHS in June 2014. The IFT program supports Mission 2 of the QHSR: "Secure and Manage our Borders". More specifically, the IFT Program addresses Goal 2.1: "Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches." The IFT Investment assists in the prevention of illegal entry of people, weapons, and contraband while at the same time not negatively impacting the safe and lawful flow of commerce and travel. 
 
Benefits include mission efficiency and effectiveness, as well as Border Patrol safety. More specifically, the IFT system provides the Border Patrol the capability of continuously detecting Items of Interest (IoIs) from a tested range of 6.2 miles and identifying/classifying each from a tested range of 6.8 miles from each fixed tower within a Border Patrol Station’s Area of Coverage (AoC). The system provides the Common Operating Picture (COP) operator(s) at the Border Patrol Station Command and Control Center with near real-time video of operator-selected IoIs of sufficient quality to enable a trained operator to identify and classify the IoI. IoI data from one or more IFT units across the AoC will be shown geospatially on one or more COP workstations that also display the video of operator-selected IoIs. This will allow the COP operator to track and communicate the location and number of IoIs to Border Patrol Agents in the field, thus allowing the USBP to monitor an Area of Interest (AoI) with fewer agents and equipment resources. 
  
Key Customers: The U.S. Border Patrol.  
Key Stakeholders: The U.S. Border Patrol, The Tohono O’odhamNation, The CBP Office of Technology Innovation and Acquisition, The CBP Office of Information Technology, The CBP Office of Administration, The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, the State of Arizona, various landowners in Arizona, and the citizens of the United States of America.
Key Beneficiaries: Landowners in Arizona and the citizens of the United States of America.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description: Compared to the baseline operating costs from which the ROI was calculated (1 border patrol agent, per one mile of border in AZ, 24/7), the operating costs for IFT system are estimated to be considerably lower (358.3M vs. 2,104.1M). ROI was calculated by (Operating Costs without IFT - Operating Costs with IFT) divided by the Capital Investment costs, providing the same level of surveillance. Ergo, the key benefit is that for a lower overall operating cost , the IFT system will provide the Border Patrol with a persistent surveillance capability, which will enable them to detect, identify, and track IoIs, thus enabling them to monitor an Area of Interest more efficiently and effectively. Other benefits include: it facilitates mission accomplishment; it allows agents to be realigned since it acts as a force multiplier; agents will be safer since fewer will be needed in the field for surveillance; it will be used only in areas in which it performs well; and improved data will be available (e.g., recorded video) for successful law enforcement accomplishment versus the baseline.
Investment Requirements: There are no legislative mandates, outstanding audit findings/material weakness, or Presidential Directive related to this investment.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There have been no changes.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Integrated Fixed Towers (IFT) program is in the Mixed life cycle phase. Of the six Areas of Responsibility (AoRs), Nogales and Douglas have been deployed and are in sustainment; system acceptance for Sonoita is on schedule for 1QFY18. Cost and schedule variances are within acceptable OMB thresholds. All system availability and downtime performance metrics continue to meet target objectives. While the program is executing to its approved Acquisition Program Baseline (APB), realized challenges and risks remain. New system modifications and upgrades (e.g., high-definition cameras) present a risk to current funding. The working Operational Requirements Document (ORD) is from 2011 and is not necessarily aligned with the current operational realities. Simultaneous deployment of the remaining three AoRs is possible, but not likely; the program is adequately staffed for a maximum of two concurrent deployments. Finally, the Ajo and Casa Grande AoR deployments cannot be executed until the Tohono O’odham Nation passes a resolution allowing construction of roads and towers for these two AoRs which are located on tribal lands. In order to achieve Full Operational Capability (FOC) per the current program baseline, the Tohono O’odham Nation must pass its resolution by 3QFY18. The program office and Arizona Technology Plan (ATP) Executive Steering Committee (ESC) continuously monitor, reevaluate, and update program and operational risks, and currently show moderate risk exposure. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the CBP IFT program as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of the Mobile Surveillance Capability (MSC) is to provide mobile area surveillance in remote rural areas over a range of 8 to 12 kilometers.  This allows CBP to adjust the location of its surveillance capabilities to keep pace with the ever changing border threat. The MSC consists of trucks outfitted with an array of sophisticated radar and sensing devices that aid United States Border Patrol (USBP) agents in the detection of illegal border crossings.  The MSC is an integrated suite of sensor equipment mounted on the flat cargo bed of a Government-furnished Ford F-450 truck, with an operator workstation located inside the truck cabin. 

The MSC goals are to increase the situational awareness of CBP by detecting, identifying, tracking, and classifying potential Items of Interest (IoIs).  These goals supports Mission 2 of the Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR): "Secure and Manage our Borders".  More specifically, the MSC Program addresses Goal 2.1: "Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches." 

Benefits of the MSC include: 1) Identifying and tracking numerous IoIs over a large area, the MSC allows for greater surveillance coverage then possible with an agent on foot. 2) Enhances USBP Agent safety by providing advanced warning of not only the existence of IoIs but the nature of that threat including whether the individuals are armed. 3) Allows for greater response coordination, thereby improving the likelihood of a successful law enforcement resolution as well as increased officer safety.  Radar capabilities provide two significant benefits over a camera-only system: advanced warning of the existence of IoIs, and tracking of numerous IoIs over a larger area.

Key stakeholders include US Border Patrol (USBP), Office of Field Operations (OFO), Office of Air and Marine (OAM), Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Department of Agriculture, Department of Interior, federal/state/local law enforcement, and US/Mexican border communities.  The key customer and beneficiaries of the MSC system are USBP agents, who currently rely on legacy capabilities such as sign cutting, which are time tested and proven, but place agents at high risk in difficult locations.  By detecting/identifying the threat from a safe distance, agents are able to determine the time, method, and location of an interdiction.  The long range ability of this technology provides ample time for agents to prepare for threats.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description: A traditional return on investment calculation is difficult to quantify given there is no means to measure “return? in terms of dollars for a system that produces increased situational awareness for the United States Border Patrol (USBP) that results in increased apprehensions and drug seizures.  Nonetheless, an ROI calculation was developed based on operating assumptions (i.e., status quo of an average of one Border Patrol agent per mile of border versus 12 full-time MSCs).  The ROI calculates the Base Case Operations and Maintenance (O&M) minus the New Program O&M (plus other benefits) and then dividing the value by the Planning, Initial Capital, and Non-Recurring (i.e., new program non-O&M or new investment) costs and then subtracting 1.  This calculates the value as a percentage.  There is a high cost for the status quo, and the MSC system requires a relatively low capital investment, resulting in a high ROI.  The purpose of the investment is to increase the probability of apprehension in an effort to reduce cross border crime.  Internal benefits are the increased probability of detection which increases the costs of attempting to enter the U.S. illegally, thereby reducing the illicit flows and crimes associated with smuggling at and between ports of entry.  U.S. border threats are opportunistic, adaptive and continuously probing to exploit any new or existing weaknesses observed, and they have near real-time situational awareness of USBP activities through the use of a vast network of scouts on both sides of the border.  MSC systems, with their mobile capabilities, can respond to threats in multiple areas, and can be fielded in the areas with the highest threats.  This mobile response capability is flexible; it can be adjusted to changes in IoI patterns.  In addition, MSC systems can be used to augment existing systems or substitute for currently deployed technology that is temporarily non-operational.  An external benefit is the deterrence effect of a deployedMSC.  The presence of an MSC can provide sufficient deterrence that IoIs choose alternative border crossings, reducing the impacts to the local MSC deployment area.  Note the actual ROI calculation result was 3,614 but is displayed as 1,000 due to format limitations.
Investment Requirements:
Secure Fence Act of 2006 (http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-109hr6061enr/pdf/BILLS-109hr6061enr.pdf) - The law authorizes more vehicle barriers, checkpoints, and lighting as well as authorizes the Department of Homeland Security to increase the use of advanced technology like cameras, satellites, and unmanned aerial vehicles to reinforce infrastructure at the border.  This project provides camera and radar technologies.  
GAO-12-22 and GAO-13-414T reports (http://www.gao.gov/assets/660/653037.pdf) outline GAOs findings on the Arizona Technology Deployment plan.  According to the GAO, opportunities exist to improve DHS's management of border security assets. In January 2011, in response to performance, cost, and schedule concerns, DHS canceled future procurements, and developed the Arizona Border Surveillance Technology Plan (Plan) for the remainder of the Arizona border (MSC is part of the plan).
PM Name: Dorion Watkins - Identified in IPT Charter as IPT/
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: With the completion of the purchase of the MSC units, the program will move towards sustainment and O&M funding will be increased from $8.6M in PY16 to $16.8M in CY17.  DME funding of $16M was added to PY16 for additional unit purchases, but there will be no DME funding in CY17.
Operational Analysis Results:
Customer Results: Overall, MSC is meeting standards with regards to customer satisfaction. Respondents agreed that the radar’s coverage provides sufficient situational awareness and commented that it is an improvement over the MSS. However, some respondents commented that there are still times when the MSC does not respond to known IoI activity. 
Strategic and Business Results:  The MSC is a critical element to the Arizona Technology Plan which incorporates the use of mobile and fixed assets in support of border security. MSC directly supports the Secure Fence Act of 2006.  The MSC program is the successor to the Mobile Surveillance System (MSS) and improves MSS capabilities through enhanced technologies.
Financial Performance:  The MSC investment continued to meet financial performance targets during the PY. Key stakeholders include US Border Patrol (USBP) and the CBP Office of Acquisition (OA).  The MSC program is leveraging internal maintenance support from the Office of Information & Technology (OIT). Analysis was conducted in support of a new FLIR contract action. This analysis was used to determine the required federal and contract FTEs in support of Contractor Maintenance Logistics Support (CMLS) and Contractor Depot Logistics Support (CDLS).
Innovation: In order to mitigate existing issues, research is being done to find improvements for vehicle tire maintenance and electronic data tracking/reporting. The team is exploring the following opportunities:
 - Foliage Penetrating (FOPEN) Radar to improve the radar functionality in locations with dense vegetation
 - Electronic Shift Reporting to improve data reporting and tracking for maintenance and operations
 - Perimeter Detection System to provide enhanced detection capabilities for the Tucson Sector
Operational Performance Measures: 
 - MSC performance is an improvement from the MSS
 - MSC radar exceeds the performance of any other mobile system’s radar
 - MSC mobility enables deployments to remote and rugged terrain
 - Operator workspace is comfortable and adequate to perform mission functions
 - MSC has exceeded the Operational Availability (Ao) requirement of 95%.  Measured Ao has consistently been above 99%.
Risk Analysis: 3 risks were cited in the Operational Analysis report, and are actively being mitigated by the MSC Program.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Mobile Surveillance Capabilities (MSC) program is in the Support life cycle phase. Cost (CV) and Schedule Variance (SV) for MSC are within OMB acceptable thresholds. The Component Acquisition Executive (CAE) approved the program for Acquisition Decision Event (ADE) 3 in a Q2 FY17 Acquisition Review Board (ARB). The program’s Life Cycle Cost Estimate (LCCE) and Acquisition Program Baseline were both updated to support this decision. Full Operating Capability (FOC) will follow during Q3 FY17 with final deployment of additional MSC units bringing the fleet total to 90 units. A system technical refresh is planned during FY19. The MSC Operational Analysis (OA) is current as of Q4 FY16. The OA reports primary positive findings that each support successful program metrics. These are for system performance and operator mission accomplishment. The OA recommends   minor operational improvements that can be implemented with a phased approach as funding becomes available. These improvements include “Innovation? to improve radar functionality and detection capabilities. Another area for enhancement is data collection to support maintenance and operations. The program has no development funds for FY17 yet financial targets for operational procurement are being met. The MSC program participates with the Arizona Technology Plan (ATP) Executive Steering Committee (ESC).  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the MSC program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Investment Title: CBP - Northern Border Remote Video Surveillance System (NBRVSS)
Brief Summary:
The purpose of the Northern Border Remote Video Surveillance System (NB RVSS) is to enhance surveillance capability by providing situational awareness of border activity through persistent surveillance and detection to facilitate proper law enforcement resolution. The goal of the NB RVSS program is to provide persistent ground and maritime surveillance needed by Border Patrol agents to effectively deter, detect, track, identify, classify, and respond to items of interest throughout the respective Area of Responsibility (AOR).  The investment continues to operate and maintain the NB RVSS located in Buffalo, NY and Detroit, MI. The NB RVSS towers have expanded the coverage on the northern border where high threat areas exist. The NB RVSS supports the 2014 Quadrennial Homeland Security Review by specifically supporting the security mission to Secure and Manage Our Borders.
 
The deployed system covers over 20 miles in Buffalo Sector on the Lower Niagara River and 65 miles in Detroit Sector spanning the St. Clair River, Lake St. Clair, and the Detroit River for a total of 85  miles of maritime border with the RVSS capability. According to ROI figures calculated below, NB RVSS reduces the need for approximately 50 agents covering the same area of the border. The deployed systems serve as force multipliers enabling CBP officers to effectively monitor the vast and complex border. The NBRVSS's ROI has achieved several quantitative benefits that are internal and external to the government:  
 
1. Over 85 miles of surveillance coverage along the northern border: 65 miles in Detroit Sector spanning the St. Clair River, Lake St. Clair, and the Detroit River, 20 miles in Buffalo Sector on the Lower Niagara River. 
2. Increased situational awareness through the deployment of RVSS in the northern border. 
3. The all-weather system is available for use and maintained an Operational Availability for over 4 years greater than 95%. 
 
The NB RVSS systems support the DHS mission to improve upon border security, to exclude terrorist threats, drug traffickers, and other threats to national security, economic security, and public safety. The key customer and primary stakeholder of this capability is the U.S. Border Patrol (USBP); other stakeholders/beneficiaries are the Office of Field Operations (OFO), Air and Marine Operations(AMO), Office of Intelligence (OI), and US Coast Guard (USCG), and federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description:
The Northern Border Remote Video Surveillance System (NB RVSS) investment's return on investment has achieved several quantitative benefits internal and external to the government: 
1. There are approximately 85 miles of surveillance coverage in the northern border with this investment, which provides increased situational awareness through the deployment of RVSS in the northern border.  
2. The system is available for use and operating dependably 96% of the time.
To further define the basis for the ROI, an ROI document was developed and updated July 2016. This ROI Memo is attached the Key Documents section in INVEST. 
The ROI computation of 123% was obtained using the following formula: 
ROI = (((Baseline Cost – Program O&M1 Cost) / (Project Initial Capital Cost))-1)*100%. Baseline cost was calculated based on northern border staffing levels of 2,200 Border Patrol Agents (BPAs) and 4,000 miles of northern border, resulting in an average of 0.55 agents per mile of border (2,200/4,000 = 0.55). 85 miles of NB RVSS coverage multiplied by average agent per mile of .55 results in 46.75 FTEs. The NB RVSS system allows 46.75 BPAs to focus on other USBP (United States Border Patrol) law enforcement priorities. The RVSS has removed a significant amount of human element to monitoring the border, thus allowing agents to be deployed into unmonitored areas to the north instead of concentrating all manpower and resources around the water border.

The ROI has increased 23% since last year due to a projected extension in lifecycle of the investment to 2022. This ROI increases every year the system stays deployed as the baseline costs exceed the O&M cost of the system. More specifically, due to capital investment staying constant, the increase in life-cycle duration has greatly increased the return on the investment.
 
In addition to the cost savings associated with the reduced number of BPAs, NB RVSS’ video storage capability contributes significantly toUSBP investigations and indictments of illegals across the Northern Border.
Investment Requirements: NBRVSS supports the 2014 Quadrennial Homeland Security Review. Strategic Goal: Mission 1, Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security; and Strategic Goal: Mission 2, Secure and Manage Our Borders by providing persistent ground and maritime surveillance needed by Border Patrol agents to effectively deter, detect, track, identify, classify, and respond to items of interest throughout the respective Area of Responsibility (AOR).
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no significant changes in funding levels for PY and CY.
Operational Analysis Results:
User Satisfaction: User satisfaction remained high in 2016, as reflected in the annual customer survey. The NBRVSS continues to have a positive impact on the USBP mission based on supervisor ratings and interview responses.

Financial Results: NB RVSS benefits continue to outweigh long-term sustainment costs, as reflected in the updated ROI. Current funding levels provide the needed capabilities to maintain the NBRVSS at an acceptable level to support USBP mission operations, and CBP leadership has affirmed the need for NB RVSS in various program reviews and discussions.

Business/Strategic Results: NBRVSS continues to support the DHS mission of Secure and Manage our Borders and the CBP Mission, Goal 2 of Advance Comprehensive Border Security and Management. In FY2016, NB RVSS continued to assist the USBP detect and track maritime conveyances that crossed the border, and, using the RVSS technology, served as a force multiplier to support the border security mission.
 
Innovation: The NBRVSS PM continued to explore innovative technologies or processes that could improve overall system effectiveness/efficiency in FY16. Exploring additional integration points across the CBP enterprise will continue in 2017, as the investment looks for additional opportunities to improve ROI and streamline business processes.
 
Op Performance Measures: NBRVSS has established performance parameters that are monitored and reported to demonstrate the investment is meeting the needs of the agency and delivering expected value. The investment measures strategic and business results (operational availability), customer satisfaction (corrective maintenance actions, downtime events, preventive maintenance actions, and effectiveness of sparing process) and financial performance (cost savings) at various frequencies (monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, or annually). The investment has met the defined metrics historically, and quickly conducted root-cause analysis and implement corrective actions when the system experienced shortfalls or performance degradation.
 
Risk Analysis: The NBRVSS PM maintains a Risk Management Plan that follows DHS/OMB best practices, including direction on how the program prioritizes and determines impact of risk and consistent mitigation strategies. The program utilizes the Active Risk Manager tool to assist with overall risk analysis, and regularly updates the program Risk Register to communicate risk status to the IPT and other stakeholders.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Northern Border Remote Video Surveillance System (NBRVSS) program is in the Support life cycle phase. NBRVSS has been fully-operational in the Buffalo and Detroit sectors since 2010. The Swanton sector expansion project has been initiated and the program will present to the CBP Component Acquisition Executive (CAE) as soon as resources are available. Site designs and an environmental assessment are scheduled to be completed in 3QFY17. The tentative full operational capability (FOC) for Swanton sector is 2QFY19. The program is operating within acceptable OMB cost and schedule thresholds and continues to meet all performance objectives including operational availability, preventative maintenance, corrective maintenance, and priority downtime events. An Operational Analysis (OA) conducted in 4QFY16 indicates that the system is meeting department and component operational needs and has achieved high levels of user satisfaction. Based on the subjective data from NBRVSS supervisors, operators and maintainers, the NBRVSS has enhanced the situational awareness within the area of coverage. Since the deployment of the system, it appears illegal traffic patterns have changed, and the system may be a deterrent to illegal incursions in the area. Exploring additional integration points across the CBP enterprise will continue in FY17, as the program continues to explore innovative technologies and best practices that could improve overall system effectiveness and efficiency.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess CBP-NBRVSS as a Low Risk investment.

Investment Title: CBP - Remote Video Surveillance System (RVSS) Upgrade Program
Brief Summary:
Purpose: To replace existing technology with newer, more readily available technology and increase border coverage of the RVSS systems across the Southwest border.

Goal: To provide upgraded camera suites with additional surveillance tools, replace the current analog system with a digital system necessary for Certification & Accreditation, and provide modern command and control (C2) facilities to incorporate additional situational awareness capabilities.

Current and Anticipated Benefits: To increase surveillance capabilities through a more secured digital system, improved video quality for C2 operations, and improved detection and situational awareness along wider land border areas.

Mission Delivery Contribution: The RVSS Upgrade Program supports the DHS Strategic Goal 2.1: “Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders? and CBP Strategic Goal 2: “Advance Comprehensive Border Security and Management.? This includes preventing the illegal entry of people, weapons, dangerous goods, and contraband, and protecting against cross-border threats to health, food, environment, and agriculture, while facilitating the safe flow of lawful travel and commerce, as well as preventing the illegal export of weapons, proceeds of crime, and other dangerous goods. The program will enhance the mission through early detection of border incursions, enhanced identification and classification of the threat, and the ability to track items of interest through a law enforcement resolution. The program will enhance agent and public safety through persistent surveillance in high enforcement areas.

Stakeholders: Internal Stakeholders include Office of Acquisition (OA), Office of Information and Technology (OIT), Office of Border Patrol (OBP), Office of Finance (OF).  External stakeholders include US Department of Interior (DOI); National Park Services (NPS); US Fish and Wild Services (USFWS); US Department of Agriculture (USDA)/US Forest Service; private and public landownersand various other regulatory agencies.

Customers and Other Beneficiaries: CBP US Border Patrol Agents, Intelligence Research Specialists, Sector Enforcement Specialists, Supervisors and Joint Field Command and the Office of Intelligence and Investigative Liaison (OIIL).
