External Customers and beneficiaries include State and Local law enforcement; Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE); Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA); and the general public.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description:
Return on Investment (ROI): The calculated ROI is 1092% but the tool will not allow an entry more than 1000%. Compared to the baseline operating costs from which the ROI was calculated (1 border patrol agent, per one mile of border in AZ, 24/7), the operating costs for RVSS system are estimated to be considerably lower. ROI was calculated as follows: Operating Costs without RVSS - Operating Costs with RVSS)/Capital Investment costs.

Internal Benefits: The RVSS Upgrade benefits U.S. Border Patrol operations through visual surveillance to facilitate apprehension of illegal intruders across U.S. borders, improved performance (detection and identification) of U.S. borders, addressing obsolescence issues of the legacy RVSS, and enhancing agent safety in comparison to the legacy system. Other benefits include technology upgrades, communication backhaul upgrades, command and control room modifications, physical security, and power upgrades for existing and new RVSS towers. The RVSS system will provide the Border Patrol with a persistent surveillance capabilities, which will enable them to detect, identify, and track Items of Interest (IoI).

Benefits External to the Government: The RVSS upgrade program could result in indirect and long-term beneficial impacts by reducing the adverse impacts of illegal cross-border violator activities in the project area.  The RVSS towers would enhance CBP’s detection and threat classification capabilities and increase the efficiency of operational activities within the area of tower coverage.  Over time the enhancement of detection capabilities and an increase in operational efficiency could increase the deterrence of illegal cross-border violator activity within the area of tower coverage.

Planned Outcomes: The intended mission outcomes of the RVSS Upgrade program is three-fold (1) Increase situational awareness provided on the Southwest Border while leveraging the added range potential of cameras systems where practical. (2) Replace the current analog system with a more secure digital system. (3) The RVSS Upgrade is expected to enhance the current mission through early detection of border incursions, through enhanced identification and classification of the threat, and through an improved ability to track items of interest.
Investment Requirements:
The RVSS Program supports the following two requirements (as cited in the 2014 Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (Link: https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/2014-qhsr-final-508.pdf);
Strategic Goal: Mission 1, Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security; and 
Strategic Goal: Mission 2, Secure and Manage Our Borders by providing persistent ground and maritime surveillance needed by Border Patrol agents to effectively deter, detect, track, identify, classify, and respond to items of interest throughout the respective Area of Responsibility (AOR).
Outstanding Audit Finding or Material Weakness: GAO reported in March 2014 and April 2015 that U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP), within the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), had made progress in deploying programs under the Arizona Border Surveillance Technology Plan (the Plan), but could take additional actions to strengthen its management of the Plan and its related programs. Specifically, in March 2014 GAO reported that CBP's schedules and life-cycle cost estimates for the Plan and its three highest-cost programs—which represented 97 percent of the Plan's total estimated cost—met some but not all best practices. GAO recommended that CBP ensure that its schedules and cost estimates more fully address best practices, such as validating cost estimates with independent estimates, and DHS concurred. As of May 2016, CBP has initiated or completed deployment of technology for each of the three highest-cost programs under the Plan, and reported updating some program schedules and cost estimates (Link: http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-16-671T).
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: The significant change in the funding levels is that there is no DME funding in the final FY2017 President's Budget for the RVSS Program. In addition, the O&M support funding level has increased in FY2017.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Remote Video Surveillance System (RVSS) Upgrade Program is in the Support life cycle phase. The purpose of RVSS is to replace existing technology with upgraded video surveillance technology to address capability gaps and increase coverage. RVSS was elevated to a Level 1 program in FY16 when the scope was expanded to include the Rio Grande Valley sector and the remaining six United States Border Patrol (USBP) Southwest border sectors. Updated acquisition documentation is being routed for final approval and an Acquisition Review Board (ARB) is anticipated by the end of the fiscal year. The original scope (Arizona) reached full operational capability (FOC) in FY17. System availability and other operational performance targets in the Arizona sector continue to be met or exceeded including the reduction of corrective actions, downtime events, and trouble tickets generated. In FY17 the program also continued approved deployments to the Rio Grande City and McAllen areas of responsibility (AoRs) under current funding. Program management continues to demonstrate and emphasize the value of getting relocatable towers into specific locations quickly. The program reviews risks at least bi-weekly with executive leadership and the Risk Review Board; current risk exposure is negligible. Staffing remains a risk due to the scope expansion and potentially supporting multiple, simultaneous deployments. The program is mitigating shortages through resource reassignment while hiring and onboarding efforts are accelerated. While the program continues to meet baselined objectives and metrics, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the CBP RVSS program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
TARS’ purpose is to provide persistent, long-range detection and monitoring (radar surveillance) capability for interdicting low-level air, maritime and surface smugglers and narcotics traffickers along the United States-Mexico border, the Florida Straits, and a portion of the Caribbean. TARS provides surveillance data to the CBP Office of Air and Marine (OAM) Operations Center (AMOC). TARS is an aerostat-borne surveillance system that is utilized by CBP's Air & Marine branch as its primary tool to identify and track suspect targets. Radar information from TARS is distributed to multiple operations centers run by CBP, U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) and Department of Defense (DOD). As a secondary mission, TARS supports the United States Northern Command’s (USNORTHCOM’s) and the United States Southern Command’s (USSOUTHCOM’s) air surveillance mission. In addition, TARS surveillance data also supports North American Aerospace Defense Command’s (NORAD’s) air sovereignty mission for the Continental United States.  

The strategic goal is to support the DHS QHSR mission 2, Secure and Manage Our Borders. TARS also strives to assist CBP to consistently detect, identify and classify illegal entries and determine the level of threat involved.  

Benefits include a unique look-down radar capability that allows CBP to detect aircraft that would not be detected through a ground based system due to its low altitude and/or terrain masking limitations. While operating at 10,000 feet, the TARS radar has been optimized to detect low (0 - 2,000 feet above sea level) and slow (0 - 1,000 knots) aircraft at a range of 200 nautical miles.

Customers are CBP’s Air Marine Operations Center (AMOC) and Caribbean Air Marine Operation Center (CAMOC). Other customers include: Eagle Pass South Border Patrol Station, USCG, USNORTHCOM/ USSOUTHCOM (Joint Interagency Task Force-South (JIATF-S)) and NORAD (Western Air Defense Sector (WADS) and Eastern Air Defense Sector (EADS)).

CBPStakeholders include Air and Marine Operations (AMO) (which manages the program), US Border Patrol, Office of Administration, Office of Information Technology, Office of Acquisition, and Office of the Commissioner. Non-CBP stakeholders include EADS/WADS, DHS HQ and Science &Technology (S&T), JIATF South, Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), USCG, and the Mexican Government.

Beneficiaries include AMO, DOD, FAA, USCG and international partners, which all benefit from sharing information to manage airspace.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description:
CBP assumed management of this steady state O&M program after transfer from the USAF at the start of FY 2014. As a result, an AoA/CBA (including ROI) was not required. However, theoretically, TARS' ROI is primarily related to increased interdiction and seizure of contraband. Additionally, it would cost CBP more money per flight hour to use alternative surveillance system(s) instead of TARS. CBP operators rely on TARS today, and likely will for the foreseeable future, to fulfill primary domain awareness missions and responsibilities along the SWB, Florida Straits and the Caribbean.  
 
TARS consistently sources 80-90% of suspicious air tracks along the SWB logged at the Air & Marine Operations Center (AMOC), including ultralight and short-lander aircraft threats. The below descriptions highlight specific threat activity along the southwest border for which TARS is particularly useful.  
   
The TARS investment provides benefits internal and external to the government by reducing ultralight and short-lander aircraft threats as follows: (beneficiaries included in parenthesis) 
- TARS is able to detect ultralights aircraft by being at altitude, and with the radar “surface? channel set for such slow moving targets. (FAA, OAM, USCG, DOD) 
- TARS is able to facilitate identification and interdiction of short lander threats. (OAM, DOD)  
- CBP has initiated several law enforcement coordination efforts, to include real-time sharing of this radar data, with the Government of Mexico to improve our combined effectiveness against these threats. (international)  
- TARS also supports international law enforcement cooperative initiatives with Mexican police and security forces.
Investment Requirements: TARS doesn't currently address any legislative mandate, outstanding audit finding, material weakness or presidential directive.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no significant changes from the 2017 President’s Budget for PY and CY funding levels.
Operational Analysis Results:
Customer Satisfaction – TARS operators continued to state that TARS systems provided valuable data that improved overall situational awareness along the border, helping meet CBP mission goals and objectives. Overall, TARS customers are satisfied with the system’s performance,  reliability, availability, functionality, ease of use, and maintenance processes (e.g., Help Desk, Corrective/Preventive Maintenance, etc.), and consider the TARS system an asset that helps meet the challenges of securing our border against dynamic 21st century threats and adversaries.
 
Strategic/business results -TARS continued to support DHS Strategic Goals articulated in the QHSR as well as the goals in the DHS Strategic Plan 2014-2018. TARS, when combined with other sensors and our effective air interdiction capabilities, has dramatically reduced the airborne smuggling threat from approximately 10000 border crossings to 10-20 border crossings per year. DHS observed a record low number of approximately 630 suspicious “short landing? aircraft in Mexico and 70 ultra-light aircraft attempts to cross into the US.

Financial Performance - TARS benefits, both tangible and intangible, continue to outweigh long-term operations and maintenance costs. The PM has established and regularly monitors several financial metrics aimed at assessing the program's cost effectiveness. TARS continues to cost DHS less than $1K per surveillance flight hour, meeting all financial metric targets as identified in the annual Business Case to OMB. 

Operational Performance Metrics - TARS but did experience a shortfall regarding Radar Quality. The root cause of this shortfall was adverse weather conditions, which continue to pose the greatest threat to TARS operational performance.
 
Risk Analysis - External stakeholder resource limitations negatively affected TARS operations. The PM will continue to discuss and escalate resource risks and to both AMO and CBP leadership in order to identify a corrective action that will minimize impact to TARS operations. 

Innovation - TARS PM continued to explore innovative technologies or processes that could improve overall system effectiveness and efficiency. Exploring additional integration points across the CBP and DHS enterprise will continue in 2017, as the investment looks for additional opportunities to improve ROI and streamline business processes.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Tethered Aerostat Radar System (TARS) Program is in the Support life cycle phase. TARS is a well-managed program operating with OMB acceptable cost and schedule thresholds. Since the last assessment, TARS has been conducting a formal Analysis of Alternatives (AoA) to investigate future capabilities to fulfill TARS mission for the next decade. The Executive Steering Committee (ESC) consisting of CBP, Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Department of Defense (DoD) stakeholders approved the AoA efforts and progress to date. The program will conduct a final results brief in the 3QFY17. TARS released a Request for Proposal (RFP) for aerial surveillance for the United States Border Patrol (USBP) and enhance multi-mission capability of the TARS platform.  The program executed Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) 4 for a site radar conversion, which will add a spare L-88A radar to the program. Structural modifications are 90% complete. Factory acceptance Test (FAT) is scheduled to be completed in 3QFY17 and Site Acceptance Test (SAT) in 4QFY17. TARS program presents a moderate risk exposure while it continues to monitor risks and provide solid mitigation strategies. Additionally, TARS exercised Option 1 of the bridge contracts to sustain Operations & Maintenance (O&M) services through FY18, while the competitive, full-and-open TARS O&M future contract is being prepared.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the CBP TARS Program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Investment Title: CBP - Arrival and Departure Information System (ADIS)
Brief Summary:
Purpose of ADIS is to support activities to prevent illegal entry, exit, & overstay of foreign nationals. ADIS accomplishes this by matching automated entry & exit records of foreign nationals into a consolidated travel history, and provide biographic identity & overstay status services to customers & stakeholders. ADIS’ goals to prevent illegal entry, exit, and overstay directly support the 2014 Quadrennial Homeland Security Review’s Mission Goals 2.1 Effective Control of U.S. Air, Land, Sea Borders and Approaches, 2.2 Safeguard Lawful Trade and Travel, and 3.2 Prevent Unlawful Immigration. ADIS collects & maintains arrival/departure information on non-US citizens traveling to the US, and matches this information to a person, thereby creating a complete person-centric record of events compliant with visa admissibility & issuance provisions. 

ADIS benefits include assistance in determining admissibility, law enforcement action, Visa approval/denial and Visa Waiver Program eligibility. Investment benefits users by matching travel events with changes in immigration status to provide an overstay status. Benefits also include support for anticipated immigration reform & expansion of biographic & biometric exit activities. ADIS contributes to DHS Missions 2 Secure & Manage Our Borders and 3 Enforce and Administer Our Immigration Laws by looking at arrival & departure data collectively from multiple sources to determine whether a person departed the US on time or if they legally extended their immigration status. 

Internal DHS customers, who are also stakeholders, are CBP, OBIM, ICE, USCIS, TSA, & USCG. External customers, who are also stakeholders, include Department of State (DOS) and the intelligence community. ADIS incorporates data elements & transactions associated with CBP systems & other immigration systems to create & maintain complete histories on about 330M travelers & processes more than 2.6M transactions a day. ADIS services are growing in usageand includes a 24/7 help desk, and system uptime of 98% or greater. ADIS enables DHS to comply with Congressional, legislative, operational, and executive mandates by helping to determine if foreign nationals have overstayed terms of admission; enhances homeland security by providing a cost-effective response to the entry-exit statutory mandate to determine whether foreign nationals are legally in the US.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3259 - Goal 2.2:  Safeguard and Expedite Lawful Trade and Travel
ROI Description:
ADIS is an inherited system in operational steady state, and as such does not have an identified “return on investment.? However, ADIS does produce significant benefits to society that include enhanced border security and enforcement of U.S. immigration laws through the implementation of the following DHS missions, goals, and objectives:

-       DHS Mission 2 – Secure and Manage Our Borders
o   Goal 2.1 – Secure U.S. Air, Land, Sea Borders and Approaches
§  Objective 2.1.1 – Prevent Illegal Import and Entry
§  Objective 2.1.2 – Prevent Illegal Export and Exit
o   Goal 2.2 - Safeguard Lawful Trade and Travel
§  Objective 2.2.3 – Manage the Risk of People and Goods in Transit

-       DHS Mission 3 – Enforce and Administer our Immigration Laws
o   Goal 3.2 - Prevent Unlawful Immigration
§  Objective 3.2.3 – Prevent Unlawful Entry or Admission

ADIS supports these missions, goals, and objectives by serving as the Department’s primary provider of overstay status and biographic identity services. These services represent an invaluable contribution to our nation’s security. Furthermore, discussions are underway to provide ADIS data to new stakeholders within the U.S. government (and possibly beyond) that may benefit from ADIS data (and are determined to have the authority to receive it). For example, Social Security Administration may use ADIS data to help prevent fraudulent disbursement of social security retirement or survivor benefits.
Investment Requirements:
ADIS supports DHS in meet the below legislative mandates by demonstrating the capabilities requested by enabling the release of the Entry/Exit Overstay Report for FY15 (https://www.dhs.gov/news/2016/01/19/dhs-releases-entryexit-overstay-report-fiscal-year-2015). 


-- P.L. 104-208, Division C, Title I, Subtitle A, Sec. 110. Requires the development of an automated entry and exit system to collect/match records of departure. The URL to this requirement is https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-104publ208/pdf/PLAW-104publ208.pdf
 
-- P.L. 106-215, Sec. 110. Requires that the entry and exit data system integrate all “authorized or required? alien arrival and departure data and use available data to match an alien’s arrival and departure; identify overstays; and use available data to produce a report of arriving and departing aliens. The URL to this requirement is, https://www.congress.gov/106/plaws/publ215/PLAW-106publ215.pdf.
 
-- P.L. 106-396, Title II, Sec 205. Requires that the entry and exit data system record every alien admitted under the VWP; use data to report to Congress the numbers of departing aliens. The URL to this requirement is https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-106publ396/pdf/PLAW-106publ396.pdf.
 
-- P.L. 106-396, Title II, Sec 205. Requires that the entry and exit data system record every alien admitted under the VWP; use data to report to Congress the numbers of departing aliens. The URL to this requirement is https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-106publ396/pdf/PLAW-106publ396.pdf.  
 
ADIS aggregates and compile data from multiple sources in developing the overstay report for the department to support meeting these legislative mandates.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: No significant changes in funding levels.
Operational Analysis Results:
ADIS used the DHS OA template in completing the analysis.
Customer Satisfaction:  Measured by the system’s ability to meet performance standards monitored via monthly evaluation of performance metrics. ADIS continues to adhere to performance targets by meeting or surpassing performance metrics during increasing customer requirements & transaction volume. 

Strategic & Business:  ADIS is the primary information system in Federal Government that can provide overstay status. Through ADIS, a master list of overstays is identified for DHS both for end-of-year DHS statistics & for weekly ICE priorities targeting a subset of the overstay population. ADIS continues to align with the appropriate missions & objectives from the 2014 Quadrennial Homeland Security Review Report. 

Financial Performance:  Continues to align with the OMB model. ADIS transferred to OBIM/NPPD and subsequently to CBP as a steady-state investment & did not require a formal CBA. Nevertheless, ADIS is financially justified in terms of the benefits to society & national security provided by the investment in supporting the DHS border security & enforcement of U.S. immigration laws missions & goals set forth in the 2014 Quadrennial Homeland Security Review Report. CBP OIT plans to evaluate overall status of ADIS within CBP beyond its existing IT configuration based on successful completion of TECS & other IT modernization efforts anticipated around FY 2020. 

Innovation:  Projected accomplishments representing technological innovation include:  1)  ADIS Reporting Environment (ADIS-R),  2)  Person ID (PID) Cleaning Analysis & Implementation, 3)  ADIS Web GUI, 4)  ADIS-R; Open Arrival Update, and 5)  ADIS Wrap-Back Services Update.

Operational Performance:  All performance targets can be significantly impacted because of failures in system availability. If ADIS is unavailable due to technical reasons, maintenance issues, or natural disasters, all of the remaining performance metrics will decline. Percentage of exit records matched to entry records is most vulnerable; performance of that specific metric is directly dependent on system availability.

Risk Analysis:  Reported risks match the risks reported to the OMB IT Dashboard, as updated through the Department’s Investment Management System. Risks owners, risk practitioners, and the CBP EXT Risk Management Team review and update risks on a monthly basis.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP), Arrival and Departure Information System (ADIS) program is in the Support life cycle phase.  Since the last assessment, ADIS released its FY 2016  Entry/Exit Overstay Report to Congress, as well as deploying initial capability to email overstays or refer them to public websites. Additionally, the program completed its annual reviews and updates of the Life Cycle Cost Estimate (LCCE), Investment Integrated Project Team Charter and its Operational Analysis Report (OA). The OA addressed the following areas: financial performance, customer results, business and strategic results, operational performance, innovation, and risks. The OA did not identify any program deficiency, but it mentions that ADIS continues to meet performance metrics that monitor the system’s ability to provide biographic identification services and fulfill the business needs of users and stakeholders. The program continues to operate within OMB’s recommended thresholds for cost and schedule.  In addition, ADIS continues to conduct regularly scheduled maintenance releases designed to improve reporting performance, data exchange, web application GUI and new search capabilities. Ongoing perfective maintenance included deploying releases 5.5 through 5.7.1 with updates to overstay notifications and student visa information systems. The program’s near-term scheduled releases (5.8 through 6.2) are targeted for Q4FY18. ADIS continues to monitor risks, meeting mission goals and customer expectations while maintaining a moderate risk exposure. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assess the Arrival and Departure Information System (ADIS) program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
TRIRIGA’s purpose is to provide Office of Facilities and Asset Management (OFAM) personnel with integrated capabilities to manage, maintain, and coordinate funding for all CBP-owned and leased facilities and property, and the construction and leasing of new facilities. Before TRIRIGA, OFAM used multiple localized tools, which led to disparate data sets.  Furthermore, these tools did not offer the Geographic Information System (GIS), environmental planning/compliance, energy management, dashboard reporting or earned value management capabilities essential to the effective management of a complex real property portfolio.  CBP is responsible for over 5,000 facilities and 4,979 acres of land in the U.S. and internationally, including CBP owned and leased, General Services Administration (GSA) owned and leased, and free space agreements. This diverse real property portfolio includes ports of entry (POE), Border Patrol stations, aircraft hangers, and border security fences.  The TRIRIGA system provides an enterprise-level solution with real property portfolio, facilities maintenance, and project management, ad hoc reporting capability, and the ability to interface with Computer Aided Drafting (CAD) programs and GIS.  TRIRIGA also provides the capability for invoice reporting, cultural resources management, self-service, and annual budget formulation.

TRIRIGA supports QHSR Goal 2.1–Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches by providing support for the management and maintenance of CBP's vast portfolio of facilities, providing one location for everything for FM&E to successfully manage facilities-related projects, maintenance, and repairs.  OFAM supports real property, engineering, acquisition, and energy and environmental management at more than 5,000 operational and administrative CBP facilities nationwide. The benefits of TRIRIGA are it helps OFAM foster the facilitation of legitimate trade and travel through the official POEs; secure our Nation’s borders between the POEs via land, air, and maritime patrols, and; house and support frontline and administrative personnel in the fulfillment of CBP’s mission. Key customers are the major CBP enforcement components (Office of Border Patrol, Office of Air and Marine, and Office of Field Operations). Stakeholders include a user community of over 1,000 users. Beneficiaries are foremost the law enforcement community and American citizens, in the form of safe and modern land ports of entry and facilities.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3241 - M&S Goal 6.1: Integrate Intelligence, Information Sharing, and Operations, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description:
TRIRIGA’s return on investment occurred with the initial implementation of the system by eliminating multiple, disparate tools and increasing the efficiency of real property management processes.  Before TRIRIGA was implemented, CBP Office of Facilities and Asset Management (OFAM) did not possess a tool to accurately record all of CBP’s facilities, to include the capabilities of conducting assessments.  There were multiple, disparate systems collecting data on facilities, assessments, and projects.  TRIRIGA addresses the current business needs of CBP and the program performs efficiently and effectively for end users and management.  Continuous improvements to the federal reporting capabilities of TRIRIGA enable OFAM to more effectively and efficiently provide facilities portfolio information to DHS.  
 
Since its transition to O&M in 2012, TRIRIGA has benefited OFAM by providing the source data for CBP reporting to the Federal Real Property Profile (FRPP) and DHS’s Real Property Data Warehouse (DHS-RPDW), providing the critical facilities data for CBP’s geospatial information systems and improved processes for managing operation and maintenance.  In addition, TRIRIGA provides OFAM the capability to properly budget for repair and maintenance for facilities, thereby enabling the proper allocation of funding.  Before TRIRIGA, critical facilities information was stored in SAP (which didn’t provide robust capabilities) and myriad Excel spreadsheets and Access databases.  By implementing TRIRIGA, OFAM is now able, for the first time, to collect and store all FCA data for all CBP-owned facilities in a centralized system.  TRIRIGA also calculates the facilities condition index (FCI), which provides a snapshot of CBP facilities’ health, thereby allowing leadership to plan maintenance and repairs of facilities.  As the agency moves towards maintenance of the existing portfolio, and less new construction, the FCI will be critical in determining required funding, as wellas prioritizing need.
 
Although there are limited data points, TRIRIGA is generally well-received by the user community, as is demonstrated by the results of three annual user satisfaction surveys.  Overall satisfaction has increased every year, with the past survey resulting in 76% (3.79/5.00) overall satisfaction.  While the increase is not significant it is fairly representative of the growth of a newly implemented system.  We anticipate an even higher score in the next survey.
Investment Requirements: TRIRIGA directly supports CBP and DHS in managing and auditing CBP real property, and in meeting the Federal Real Property Portfolio (FRPP) reporting requirements set by the Federal Real Property Council (FRPC). The FRPC and OMB require all federal agencies to maintain and annually report on their real property profile. The FRPC was created according to provisions in Executive Order 13327, "Federal Real Property Asset Management," signed by President George W. Bush on February 4, 2004. Executive Order 13327 states: “The policy of the United States is to promote efficient and economical use of America's real property assets and to assure management accountability for implementing federal real property management reforms."  URL: http://www.gsa.gov/portal/content/104918.  There are no outstanding audit findings or material weaknesses identified for TRIRIGA.  This program also supports CBP's Vision and Strategy Mission 2: Secure and Manage Our Borders.  TRIRIGA also supports QHSR Goal 2.1: Secure US Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches and CBP Strategic Goal 2: Advance Comprehensive Border Security and Management.  URLs:  http://www.cbp.gov/document/publications/vision-and-strategy-2020 and https://www.dhs.gov/quadrennial-homeland-security-review.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no significant changes in PY and CY funding levels when compared to final FY 2017 President’s Budget for those same years.
Operational Analysis Results:
CUSTOMER RESULTS
The TRIRIGA investment is providing relatively satisfactory Customer Results.  The system provides a single source for facilities-related data for the entire Customs and Border Protection (CBP) real property portfolio.  TRIRIGA has been operational since May 2012 customer satisfaction continues to be borderline as user become accustomed to it.  There was not a single system for the real property portfolio before this system so it is taking time for Facilities Management and Engineering (FM&E) users to make the complete transition to TRIRIGA for all facilities-related transactions.  Through innovated system improvements, user education, and senior leader support, customer satisfaction is expected to continue to increase.  The program continues to meet operational performance measures.
 
STRATEGIC AND BUSINESS RESULTS
The TRIRIGA program is meeting strategic and business results, and has proven to be consistently reliable in terms of system availability and synchronized responses, routinely satisfying them on a daily and monthly basis. 

FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE
The program meets Financial Performance goals by performing at or under budget during the entire fiscal year.  Currently the program is operating under budget, based on savings from the DHS data center. 

INNOVATION
TRIRIGA is a modern IT system, but continues to be improved to support the business operations of FM&E.  Some improvements included the updated Federal Real Property Portfolio (FRPP) reporting requirements, updating of the annual budget formulation process, and incorporating CBP invoice reporting capabilities. 

RISKS
Risks to the program include resource risks (functional and technical) and technology-related (platform and application versions and engineering solution for fixes).
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs Border Protection (CBP) TRIRIGA program is in the Support life cycle phase. TRIRIGA has been fully-operational since 2012 and provides asset lifecycle management for the CBP real property portfolio. In an effort to become a Level 3 program of record and comply with the intent of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Management Directive (MD) 102-01, the program now has an approved Acquisition Program Baseline (APB). Three key performance parameters (KPPs) have been identified: system availability, user satisfaction, and effective tracking of the Federal Real Property Profile data elements. TRIRIGA also has operational performance metrics such as increasing users, maintaining web-based training courses, and maintaining help desk tickets resolved by Tier 1 personnel. All KPPs and metrics are being met or exceeded. The next acquisition documentation milestone is the Integrated Logistics Support Plan (ILSP) which is anticipated to be completed in 3QFY17. The program is within acceptable OMB range for cost and schedule variance. All projects and initiatives are reviewed and approved by the TRIRIGA Steering Committee (TSC).  While the risk exposure score is moderate, the program office continues to work with the CBP Office of Information Technology (OIT) on technical and functional staffing support. CBP TRIRGA continues to meet all objectives and performance requirements, and the DHS Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The CBP Mobile Program purpose is to fulfill the need to add “mobility? to critical CBP operations and processes through the deployment of appropriate real-time technology, removing the constraints of time and location facing CBP front line personnel in the performance of their duties and the execution of CBP’s mission.  CBP Mobile goals are to procure and deploy mobile technology to frontline personnel in support of the QHSR strategic priority to secure U.S. air, land and sea borders and approaches and prevent terrorist attacks.  
Benefits include:  

Vehicle - mobile devices have led directly to over 1000 successful CBP enforcement actions by OFO and OBP, including identification of subjects of NCIC warrants, and the interdiction of undocumented aliens, narcotics interdiction, unreported currency and weapons violations.  
 
Rail - mobile devices are used to provide rail clearance services to the largest privately-owned passenger rail service in North America. Mobile devices provide an innovative and transformative solution for processing the train and its passengers where a CBP inspection facility does not exist.  This customer-service focused approach increased the US economic benefit while maintaining national security and set a new model for providing excellent customer service while maintaining security in a commercial environment.  
 
Maritime - mobile devices addressed a GAO recommendation to electronically verify crew members and passengers on cargo and cruise ships.  Mobile devices are used to conduct cargo and cruise ship admissibility inspections (identity and immigration status) on board vessels. 
 
Cargo - Agriculture Specialists with mobile inspection processing capability have immediate access to the applications, databases and reference material which enable real-time query, processing and verification capability.  
Outbound land - mobile devices provide valuable intelligence, enhance partnerships and assist with firearms and currency outbound interdiction operations. 
 
The CBP Mobile mission outcome is meeting the need to add mobile capability through technology which enables officers, agents and specialists to perform inspections of travelers and cargo, and identify and process undocumented aliens to improve security and enhance intelligence gathering in all locations. 
 
Key customers, stakeholders and beneficiaries include CBP officers, Border Patrol agents, the traveling public and the trade community.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3241 - M&S Goal 6.1: Integrate Intelligence, Information Sharing, and Operations, 3247 - Goal 5.1: Enhance National Preparedness, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks, 5442 - Goal 4.1:  Strengthen the Security and Resilience of Critical Infrastructure against cyber attacks and other hazards
ROI Description: CBP Mobile is in the Support Lifecycle Phase.  An economic analysis was performed to determine program impact. Agriculture Programs and Trade Liaison (APTL), was the focus of the economic analysis.  Over 2400 tablets were deployed to Agriculture Specialists nationwide.  In a fast paced, interconnected global economy, uniform and predictable decision-making is critical to creating the business certainty necessary to support America's economic competiveness.  This requires reducing barriers to the efficient flow of trade and travel, streamlining and unifying processes and procedures, and managing the volume of cargo and passengers by separating goods and travelers according to the risks they pose.  The economic analysis yielded that the time between the completion of the physical inspection and the release of the cargo at the POE directly impacts trade goods speed to market.  The mobile device deployment decreased the release time by 98% when compared to a systems release.  Observations, POE interviews, and trade interviews yielded that a tablet release takes 1-3 minutes in real time.  POE interviews indicated that a systems release averages 2-4 hours.  Elimination of lag time between inspection end and cargo release translates to less dwell time for cargo in the POE. Analysis showed that the trade community has access to their cargo 5-24 hours faster when the tablet is used to release cargo.  This reduction of dwell time translates to the closing of critical performance gaps.  CBP experienced increased efficiency ultimately reducing manpower resource costs.  APTL Port Everglades was the economic analysis site. This deployment’s informal return on investment (ROI) calculation was based on potential reductions in release time and their impact on the trades additional landed costs in a given fiscal year. According to trade community interviews, the use of the tablet for the 21,000 tailgate inspections in 2015 resulted in an approximately $20M savings in additional landed costs (reduction of overtime for equipment and local warehouse personnel, late gate fees, truck related costs, and other non-CBP costs that commonly occur in 20% of agriculture shipments.) When compared to the initial investment of $226k, CBP Mobile has delivered a significant ROI at just a single port. CBP Mobile has: Improved cargo and passenger processing; greatly improved sea passenger/crew admissibility processing; all without compromising security, officer or traveler safety.
Investment Requirements:
There was no legislative mandate of GAO audit to initiate the establishment of CBP Mobile.  In June 2011, the CBP Mobile Program Strategic Vision document was drafted to define the scope of the mobile effort by defining, at the summary level, the CBP strategic vision of how mobile technology would be used and how the program would be implemented.  CBP senior leadership established the CBP Mobile Program to provide enterprise wide solutions designed to enhance the mission by enabling operational components to meet the need to add mobility to mission critical operations. The November 15, 2012 Program Announcement memorandum named the Land Border Integration Program Management Office (LBI PMO as the CBP Mobile Program business lead.  CBP Mobile is an overarching entity for CBP-wide mobile device requests.  CBP Mobile aligns directly with two DHS missions and goals as specified in the DHS Strategic Plan; two strategic goals in the CBP Strategic Plan; the Commissioner’s Statement of CBP’s Missions, Goals and Priorities. CBP Mobile accomplishes goals and objectives detailed in the DHS Strategic Plan:  Goal 1: Secure the Nation’s borders to protect America from the entry of dangerous people and goods and prevent unlawful trade and travel.  Objective 1.3:  Identification of subjects wherever encountered will improve CBP’s ability to identify persons of interest and enhance intelligence gathering capabilities. Goal 2:  Ensure the efficient flow of legitimate trade and travel across U.S. borders. Expedite legitimate trade and travel. Objective 2.1: Through the use of accurate advance information and more efficient processing of cargo using mobile technology, CBP will expedite the processing of people, products, and conveyances at land border ports, airports, and seaports. Objective 2.2: Fully employ the use of risk management and targeting to detect and deter trade noncompliance and apply consistent enforcement actions wherever travelers and cargo are encountered.  Goal 2.2:Safeguard and Expedite Lawful Trade and Travel. 
·         DHS Strategic Plan - https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/FY14-18%20Strategic%20Plan.PDF
·         Commissioner’s Statement of CBP’s Missions, Goals and Priorities https://www.cbp.gov/sites/default/files/documents/CBP-Vision-Strategy-2020.pdf .
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There have been no changes between PY and CY to the final FY 2016 President’s Budget for those same years.
Operational Analysis Results:
Customer Results: Deployed tablets, smart phones with biometric capture and jump kits. Officers and Agents continue to provide positive feedback on device reliability and process improvement.  The trade community reports faster hold release time improving time to market.  
Strategic & Business Results: Aligns with two DHS missions and goals in the Feb 10/11 QHSR and two CBP strategic goals  in the FY09 –14 CBP Strategic Plan and the FY11-13 Commissioner’s Statement of CBP’s Missions, Goals and Priorities. Meets the business requirement to perform inspections of travelers and cargo, and identify and process undocumented aliens to improve security and enhance intelligence gathering without being bound to a physical location. 
Financial Performance:  Effective force multiplier to CBP’s staff resources across all mission operational environments.  Benefits are: Trade enhancement - the ability to release travelers and cargo immediately upon completion of an inspection/examination has resulted in more efficiency, translating to cost savings to the trade and the public. Increase Staff Efficiencies and Reduce Overtime - the ability to release travelers and cargo without having to return to a fixed location has enabled officers/agents/ agriculture specialists to spend more time conducting inspections/examinations resulting in reduced overtime requirements. 
Innovation: Centered on continued optimization of deployed devices through technology upgrades and refresh. 
Operational Performance Measures:  Monitoring/measuring mobile deployments for: User Satisfaction (semi-annually); Process Improvement (quarterly); and Device Reliability (monthly). 
Risk Analysis: Risks and associated mitigation strategies are being tracked for device accountability; training; roaming & international fees; and WiFi infrastructure.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Mobile Program (MP) is in the Support life cycle phase. MP is a technology acquisition investment, not a system. Performance is measured by device deployment quantities and evaluation of fielded capability. MP was chartered reporting to the CBP Land Border Integration (LBI) Program. The CBP Component Acquisition Executive (CAE) directed that the investment have its own formal DHS Acquisition Lifecycle Framework (ALF). MP is thus completing development of cost, acquisition and other program documentation to meet this requirement. During CY17 the program plans to releases a Life Cycle Cost Estimate (LCCE) and Acquisition Program Baseline (APB). These will report required financial and performance metrics. The two primary program goals are to: 1. Acquire commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) communication devices and 2. Pay for device data and services. The program has succeed in distributing hand-held devices to a majority of its user population. A current Operational Analysis (OA) was reported in Q4 FY16. The Program investment continues to meet financial, customer, business & strategic, operational performance, and innovation expectations. Multiple surveys and evaluations document customer satisfaction with the effectiveness, quality, and efficiency of deployed capabilities. The published program risk register is consistent with the Chief Information Officer (CIO) moderately low risk rating.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS), CIO assesses the Mobile Program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Investment Title: CBP - Air and Marine Operations Surveillance System (AMOSS)
Brief Summary: The purpose of the AMOSS investment is to provide a real-time picture of air activity over a wide portion of North America, which allows system operators to discriminate between “normal? and “suspicious? aircraft, vessels, vehicles and other forms of conveyance.  Data sources include, but are not limited to global positioning system(s) (GPS), datasets from various sensors to include plot data, track data, and air movement data. These systems provide the benefit of allowing the Air and Marine Operations Center (AMOC) Detection Enforcement Officers (DEO) to identify suspicious activity in the area of the U.S. Air, Land and Sea Borders and as additional sensors are added to the AMOSS, the detection capability of the system increases. The goals of the AMOSS investment are to provide air and maritime domain awareness along with limited ground domain to support law enforcement and intelligence operations in support of DHS and CBP goals to counter terrorist activity and transnational crime, including goals 1.1 (Prevent Terrorist Attacks), 2.1 (Secure US Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches), 2.3 (Disrupt and Dismantle Transnational Criminal Organizations) and 3.2 (Prevent Unlawful Immigration). Key customers, who are also key stakeholders and beneficiaries, include the 15 DOD partners, 44 DHS partners and 5 other Federal partners for which AMOSS is the sole provider of critical air and maritime domain awareness data to over 165 workstations. An example of how mission partners utilize AMOSS is the VCN-R workstation deployed to JFC Arizona where it is utilized to improve situational awareness within the JFC AO. Additionally, AMOSS is utilized by personnel during National Special Security Events and SEAR 1 and 2 level events to support specialized airspace security, for example there were two AMOSS VCN-Rs configured and provided for the Super Bowl and Presidential Inauguration to support situational awareness and air security. AMOSS directly support security efforts beyond the physical borders of the United States and is currently utilized by the Government of Mexico (Federal Police, SEDENA/SIVA and SEMAR) to create a joint, interagency common operating picture (COP), which assists the United States and Government of Mexico conduct aviation security operations by enabling the viewing of primary suspect air tracks along Mexico’s northern border through shared US southwest border radars and flight plans approved by the FAA along the contiguous U.S./Mexico border.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3241 - M&S Goal 6.1: Integrate Intelligence, Information Sharing, and Operations, 3243 - M&S Goal 6.3:  Strengthen the DHS International Affairs Enterprise In Support of Homeland Security Missions, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3260 - Goal 2.3:  Disrupt and Dismantle Transnational Criminal Organizations and Other Illicit Actors, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks, 30982 - Goal 3.2: Prevent Unlawful Immigration, 46751 - Enhance Disaster Preparedness and Response
ROI Description: No formal Return on Investment calculation was completed prior to IOC/FOC in 1988.  There have been many benefits accrued, however, since its implementation. The early years the system was in pure O&M mainly due to the fact that the software was proprietary. In 1994, we let a new contract for a spiral development to develop a 2nd generation system which was wholly government owned and has remained that way since. That upgrade which went operational December 1998 increased the AMOSS capability to ingest additional radar/sensors and tracking capability from the 1988 original capability of 40 radars and 3,000 tracks to 128 radars and 12,000 tracks and provided an entire new user interface. We then had another major jump in capability when we did a hardware refresh in 2004 to 450 radar and 24,000 tracks and then again in 2011 to we moved away from SGI (Silicon Graphics) Hardware to Dell PCs and Servers which upgraded AMOSS to 700 sensors and 50,000 tracks and a major cost savings in hardware. AMOSS can now ingest 700 sensors and 50,000 tracks. Each sensor and track upgrade gave AMOSS the ability to have greater detection coverage. The original 40 radars and 3000 tracks only gave us coverage of the southwestern United States and we now have a good portion of the western hemisphere. This is critical to not only give more stand-off identification of targets approaching the U.S. but also allows us to better track the transnational threat. Also since 2000, we do two software upgrades a year. These software upgrades can be technical upgrades to make the systems more efficient and upgrade such things such as the surveillance tracker algorithms to better detect low, slow targets, such as ultra-lights or maritime targets, it may be to better display processor outputs and network connections to the system administers so they can better monitor the AMOSS SOC/NOC or bandwidth management. The updates also provide such items as enhanced flight plan correlations in Canada to allow forgreater stand-off and identification of aircraft arriving into the U.S., added force-tell of tracks and markers to other systems, i.e. AFNORTH Mex AMOSS and Federal Police AMOSS. We also added the capability to ingest and process military Link 11/16 data and various maritime sensors and data types. We have moved away from Oracle Forms to GTK Forms which gives us more flexibility.
Investment Requirements:
The following legislation includes specific requirements addressed by the AMOC and AMOSS Investment: National Strategy for Aviation Security (NSPD-47/HSPD-16) https://www.dhs.gov/hspd-16-aviation-security-policy : Acting through Customs and Border Protection (CBP), conducting aviation law enforcement operations, including detecting, identifying, and interdicting potential air threats to national security. 
The Homeland Security Act of 2002, Section 402  https://www.dhs.gov/homeland-security-act-2002 : Assigns primary responsibility to DHS for (1) preventing entry of terrorists and the instruments of terrorism into the U.S.; (2) securing borders, territorial waters, ports, terminals, waterways, air, land, and sea transportation systems of the U.S.; and (3) ensuring speedy, orderly, and efficient flow of lawful traffic and commerce while carrying out these responsibilities.
The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 (H.R. 644), Section 802 https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/644/text : Establishes Air and Marine Operations (AMO) within CBP, giving it the authority to serve as the law enforcement office within U.S. Customs and Border Protection with primary responsibility to detect, interdict, and prevent acts of terrorism and the unlawful movement of people, illicit drugs, and other contraband across the borders of the United States in the air and maritime environment and conduct aviation and marine operations with relevant law enforcement agencies such as Federal, State, local, tribal, international, public, and private (FSLTIPP) as appropriate. Establishes the AMOC within AMO, giving it the responsibility to detect, identify, and coordinate a response to threats to national security in the air domain.
AMOSS provides anticipate illicit incursions across maritime borders in a timely manner.  AMOSS provides the capability to detect and localize illegal flow of contraband and people across CBP’s mission space in a timely manner.  AMOSS provides thecapability to encounter and maintain positive control of targets of interest entering into and crossing CBP’s mission space.  AMOSS provides the capability to determine the level of threat and intent of illicit activity within a conveyance in order to facilitate the appropriate law enforcement response in a timely manner.
PM Qualificiations: 9 - No certification, but with less than two years PM experience (within the last five years)
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: This is OAM funded year to year. However the contract is firm fixed price with the base year being FY12 with the 4 option years ending FY16. FY17 the contract will be re-competed.
Operational Analysis Results: Financial Performance Analysis:  The Office of Air and Marine is by far the majority stake holder in AMOSS as it is the sole funding source for AMOSS; however, CBP, DHS, DOD and specifically our Air Force Northern Command partners are mission stake holders in AMOSS. We have currently 680 users with the capability of ingesting 700 sensors and displaying a minimum of 50,000 tracks and 1000 air movement data message per minute. The systems has been operational since August 22, 1988.  Customer Results:  Our Customers are very satisfied with AMOSS with a 97.5% user satisfaction rate.  Our user survey did show that we as the IT Managers should better advertise new features of the AMOSS. The survey focused on availability of systems to perform mission and system personnel competency and level of service. Business and Strategic Analysis: This investment supports QHSR Mission 2.1.1 Securing and Managing Our Borders; and Goal: Effectively Control U.S. Air, Land and Sea Borders. The investment supports multiple objectives under 2.1.1 as the AMOSS provides a real-time picture of air activity over a wide portion of North America, by processing a collection of external data imposed over a scalable display which allows system operators to discriminate between “normal? and “suspicious? aircraft, vessels, vehicles and other forms of conveyance. Operational Performance Measures:  AMOSS currently meets or exceeds all metric baselines:  Border Incursion Resolution (Target % 98 Actual % 99.4), Detected Suspects (Target 180 Actual 505), Customer survey satisfaction (Target % 90 Actual % 96.3), Suspect Short Landings (Target 50 Actual 150), Budget Execution (Target % 90 Actual % 92), Total Detections (Target 100,000. Actual 241,141). Innovation: The AMOSS User Working Group maintains a prioritized list of user required changes to AMOSS. As part of the Change Management process these changes are prioritized into the “next software release.? Major changes/additions to AMOSS that is currently being examined is additional maritime sensor capability and expanded capability to detect the non-cooperating target. AMOC partnerships often with DHS Science & Technology to bring new capabilities and sensors into AMOSS. Risk Analysis: We have identified 3 investment risks and 6 operational risks for the AMOSS investment.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Air and Marine Operations Surveillance System (AMOSS) is in the Support life cycle phase. The program continues to meet its mission to by automating radar/sensor coverage that enhances the United States borders. AMOSS continues its border protection to meet mission and user objectives, AMOSS has planned a minimum of two user interface upgrades for FY17 and FY18. AMOSS is in the sustainment life cycle, and an Acquisition Program Baseline (APB) is not mandatory. The program just awarded a new contract. The contract will support  AMOSS’ telecommunication systems. AMOSS tracks their life cycle cost via firm fixed price contract, cost and schedule variance data not collected. AMOSS continues to exercise mature risk management practice, and as a result, the program carries a moderate risk exposure score. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the CBP AMOSS program as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of the Border Security Deployment Program (BSDP) is to provide U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) with a comprehensive and expanded secure operational environment through an integrated surveillance and intrusion detection system that delivers critical security, motion detection, remote monitoring, and situational awareness for all Land Ports of Entry (LPOEs).  BSDP is a mission critical tool that CBP has relied on to sustain officer and agent safety, and integrity, while also ensuring border security within and around all LPOEs. 
     
The goal for BSDP is to achieve more efficient and effective use of CBP resources and personnel, improved operational control and situation awareness, increased contraband seizures, enhanced CBP personnel safety and security and reinforced CBP personnel integrity.

As per the August 2016 Operational Analysis, BSDP quantitative benefits include the cost avoidance for officers, agents or guards not needed to provide persistent surveillance at and around LPOEs on a 24/7/365 basis. The cost avoidance was estimated at $94M/year. Qualitative benefits derived from the surveillance capability provided by BSDP  include: increased CBP personnel safety at LPOEs, improved emergency response times at LPOEs, reinforced CBP personnel integrity, reduced risk of CBP exposure to unsubstantiated claims at LPOEs, reduced burden on the public due to more efficient processing at LPOEs, increased efficiency and effective use of CBP resources and personnel at LPOEs, increased contraband seizures at all LPOEs, increased border security and control, improved flow of legitimate trade/travel at all LPOEs, enhanced situational awareness at LPOEs, improved officer safety in and around LPOEs, enhances visibility into the security and operational integrity at LPOEs, remote monitoring capabilities for automated border crossings, surveillance recordings used for evidence to support prosecution of criminal activity and officer integrity investigations.

Key customers include the Office of Field Operations (OFO), Office of Border Patrol (OBP), Office of Intelligence (OI), Internal Affairs (IA), Office of the Chief Council (OCC).

Key stakeholders includes the Office of Information and Technology (OIT), and Office of Acquisition (OA) from CBP and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the Department of Justice (DOJ), State and local governments along the border, the traveling public, all US citizens.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description:
In the 2004 Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA), a comprehensive financial assessment was conducted on BSDP covering the years from FY2002 to FY2011.  During the development of the 2014 Operational Analysis (OA), the BSDP CBA was updated and compared against the financial projection estimated in the 2004 CBA. In the original CBA, BSDP was expected to provide a ROI of 589% by the year 2011. Two updated Return on Investment (ROI) scenarios were developed for the 2014 OA and in both cases the original external benefits were excluded from the calculation leaving only internal the cost avoidance benefit (reduced need for additional officers or overtime pay). The external benefit from 2004 was based on the benefit of preventing a terrorist attack on the order of 9/11 which is extremely sensitive to the probability of occurrence. In the first case described in the OA (Case 1), the benefit calculation was applied against the projected deployment scale used in the 2004 analysis. The second case (Case 2) measures the ROI against the actual deployment that occurred providing a more realistic assessment of the benefits derived and ROI achieved. (actual LPOEs and other locations utilizing BSDP). In both of the 2014 OA scenarios, the same actual costs were applied to the calculation. The result of the ROI update using actual costs showed that between 2004- 2011 BSDP ROI resulted in 479% for Case 1 (original deployment plan), and 745% for Case 2 (today’s actual deployment). As stated these calculation are exclusive of external benefits. The 479% ROI for today internal benefits compares well with the 2004 projection of 589% which also included external benefits.

The ROI calculations do not include the quantification of non-quantitative benefits for BSDP. The surveillance capability provided by BSDP delivers benefits such as:  increased personnel safety, improved emergency response, reduced risk against unsubstantiated false claims against officers, situational awareness across the enterprise, faster processing at LPOEs, better productivity of CBP officers,  increased contraband seizures, and improved border security posture. All of the described benefits are just as important in the current environment as  they were when the Program was initiated and even more so. Border security, officer safety and integrity, and efficient LPOE operations are critical to the CBP mission.
Investment Requirements:
In response to the 2002 Homeland Security Act Title IV, Section 445 (http://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/hr_5005_enr.pdf), the CBP Commissioner detailed a plan on how CBP planned to comprehensively, effectively and fairly address the enforcement provisions stated in the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1101 et seq.). During this period the CBP Commissioner presented BSDP as the proposed solution to harden U.S. ports of entry. Congress provided initial funding in 2002 and 2003 to initiate the Program.             
In supporting the Strategic Objective from the Performance Reference Model for Securing and Managing our Borders, BSDP supports both the Objective’s for securing U.S. Land Borders (P41024026) and safeguarding lawful trade and travel (P42024026). BSDP surveillance provides CBP situational awareness across every LPOE. BSDP surveillance safeguards officer security as well as border security throughout the LPOE.  BSDP aligns with two strategic goals outlined in the CBP Vision and Strategy 2020 Strategic Plan including Goal 2 to Advance Comprehensive Border Security and Management and Goal 3 to Enhance U.S. Competitiveness by Enabling Lawful Trade and Travel. 
In the DHS 2014 Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR) BSDP significantly supports the DHS mission to Secure and manage our Nations Border. Primarily BSDP supports two of the goals listed under this mission area including Goal 2.1: Securing U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Goal 2.2: Safeguard and Expedite Lawful Trade and Travel. BSDP does this by providing the U.S. physical security for all CBP land border ports and ensuring the safety and integrity of CBP officers, staff and the traveling public.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: BSDP was not submitted by CBP as an Investment until the Presidents FY2017 Budget. Very late in the FY2016 CPIC cycle OMB added funding for BSDP in CBP's budget but it was after business cases for FY2016 were complete. Prior to FY2016 CBP funded BSDP through internal unfunded requests to sustain the Program. Funding for pre FY2016 is not yet in FYHSP but will be added at a later date by the CBP Office of Administration.
Operational Analysis Results:
Customer Results: BSDP met or exceeded expectations in each of targeted areas of performance for: Increased efficiency, improved operational control and situation awareness, enhanced CBP personnel safety and officer integrity. One stakeholder comment stated that the benefits of the BSDP have been so successful that they established a “mini-CASC? to monitor the cameras at several crossings which significantly reduced the need for officers for each crossing.
 
Strategic and Business Results: BSDP aligns directly with the DHS missions and goals as specified in the Department of Homeland Security Strategic Plan FY 2014 - 2018.  BSDP addresses Goal 2.2 to Safeguard and Expedite Lawful Trade and Travel by providing situational awareness across all land border Ports of Entry (POEs) and protecting them from threats. BSDP aligns with two CBP strategic goals outlined in the CBP Vision and Strategy 2020 Strategic Plan. BSDP also addresses Goal 2 to Advance Comprehensive Border Security and Management by acting as a force multiplier at land border POEs monitoring all high threat areas. BSDP recording have also been used several times to exonerate officers from false complaints.

Financial Performance: Costs for BSDP have been tracked and reviewed on a monthly basis and compared against the Program metrics to assure overall performance. In terms of ROI, BSDP continues to provide CBP significant cost avoidance by significantly reducing the manpower required to provide physical security at land border POEs estimated to be on the order of $94M/yr.

Innovation: BSDP is tailoring surveillance capabilities at a Buffalo Land Port to identify port runners and facilitate the apprehension of violators. Further, cameras have been deployed in Cargo lanes to provide better situational awareness including a view of the license plates. Cameras are also being deployed in El Paso to provide real time visibility of wait times at the Port. BSDP is also beginning to address airport security needs.

Operational Performance Measures: BSDP monitors operational performance through various metrics as reported to the IT dashboard.  In FY16 BSDP exceeded targets and continued identify areas for performance improvement.

Risk Analysis: BSDP follows the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and associated risk register to manage and mitigate risks to the program. The program successfully mitigated an identified high impact program risk and continues to monitor active risks as defined in the RMP.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Border Security Deployment Program (BSDP) is currently in the Support life cycle phase. The program continues to operate within acceptable OMB thresholds for cost and schedule variance. In the past months, BSDP has been heavily involved in Executive Order and Jane Doe Sanctions that both emphasize preservation and retention of multimedia data. The most critical attribute for BSDP as a mission critical system is maintaining high overall system availability, which consistently measures above target and objective thresholds. Going forward, BSDP will expand and build upon its successful deployments as the chosen provider of video surveillance for CBP. The program continues to monitor and evaluate innovative and emerging surveillance and storage technologies as potential replacement for legacy surveillance technologies. From a technical capability perspective, the program is considering internet protocol (IP) based cameras, microphones, and recording devices, as well as cloud storage. The most quantifiable benefit of the BSDP surveillance system is the cost avoidance by not having to utilize CBP officers for security at land border Ports of Entry (POE). In the 1QFY17 Operational Analysis (OA) other notable benefits included increased efficiency and effective use of CBP resources and personnel, improved operational control and situational awareness, increased contraband seizures, enhanced CBP personnel safety and security, and reinforced CBP personnel integrity. Program and operational risks are reviewed and prioritized weekly, and the investment currently has negligible risk exposure. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses CBP BSDP as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of Border Patrol Enforcement Systems (BPES) is to assist the U.S. Border Patrol (USBP) detect, deter, identify, classify, and resolve illegal border activity and effectively manage Border Patrol resources. The IT systems, services and equipment that compose BPES were formerly managed and implemented in smaller, discrete non-major programs, making it difficult to implement and deliver mission capability and plan for future development and modernization. In FY15, these programs were consolidated into BPES because of their direct support to the USBP mission and because of their technical and functional relationships. 

BPES’ objective is to help meet the DHS, CBP, and USBP mission of protecting the U.S. from various 21st century threats and adversaries by enabling capabilities that address challenges in data management, threat response, and resource support through the use of technologies. 

Current benefits of BPES: 1) Improved Information Sharing and Management–enables the automatic collection, dissemination and analysis of critical asset and personnel data, improving USBP’s situational awareness and the identification of resources to improve border enforcement and security through resource prioritization. 2) Improved System and Process Integration–supports new innovative approaches to exchange information and integrate USBP technology. These efforts help USBP develop efficient day-to-day processes for agents, and reduce operational costs by providing timely information across various CBP systems. 3) Rapid Response Ability–enables USBP to gain greater situational awareness, using sensors along the border, to support rapid response to interdict those crossing the border illegally.  

Key stakeholders/customers/beneficiaries: 1) Internal CBP: USBP, Office of Field Operations (OFO), Office of Acquisition (OA), Air and Marine Operations (AMO), and Office of Intelligence (OI); 2) Within DHS: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Coast Guard (USCG),Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), Science and Technology (S&T), Office of Immigration Statistics (OIS); 3) External to DHS: US Department of Justice (DOJ), US Department of Defense (DOD), Department of State (DOS), White House, Congress, Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Government Accountability Office (GAO), Inspectors General (IG); 4) External to the federal government: general public, state and local governments, foreign governments (e.g, Canadian and Mexican governments).
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches
ROI Description:
USBP, CBP, other DHS Components (e.g., ICE, CIS, USCG, FEMA, S&T), other federal agencies (e.g., DOJ, DOS and DOD), state, local and foreign governments benefit from BPES by having access to shared information that heighten situational awareness and risk-based decision-making, thereby reducing operational costs while addressing their missions quickly and effectively. BPES captures information on criminal prosecution activities, facilitating court submissions to DOJ. It also provides real-time border surveillance and monitoring of agent activity and officer safety used by law enforcement. BPES provides workforce staffing information and tracks operational metrics linked with DHS, the FBI and ICE. This integration improves decision-making and supports the rapid deployment of USBP resources while reducing operational costs. BPES provides statistical reports that CBP and multiple DHS components (e.g., FEMA, ICE, CIS) use for strategic and tactical decision-making. It enables USBP to provide reliable statistical information in response to White House, Congress, OMB, GAO, IG, IA and other federal agency requirements, including those of the Departments of State and Justice. State governments, such as the State of Texas, and foreign governments, such as the Governments of Canada, Mexico, Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala also use information. 
 
BPES is a consolidated investment in the sustainment phase, so a CBA--which would contain a return on investment (ROI)--is not required.
Investment Requirements:
BPES fulfills the requirements of the following laws: 
1) Immigration and Nationality Act (1965) which bases immigration rules to a preference system focused on immigrants' skills and family relationships. BPES supports this act by providing ICE access to databases to ensure legal border entries. http://library.uwb.edu/static/usimmigration/1965_immigration_and_nationality_act.html 
2) Border Protection Agent Pay Reform Act (BPAPRA) (2014) which provides a new method of compensating USBP agents for overtime work. This law affects only USBP agents in CBP. BPES complied with BPAPRA in January 2016, enabling USBP agents to enter their overtime pay and obtain compensation based on the new approach. https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/113/s1691/text 
3) Flores Agreement (1997) provides guidance on the treatment of Unaccompanied Children (UAC). E3, a BPES system that manages processing and prosecution of all apprehended subjects, ensures compliance to stated guidelines. https://lirs.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Flores-Family-Detention-Backgrounder-LIRS-WRC-KIND-FINAL1.pdf 
4) FITARA (2014) requires increased CIO visibility in budget formulation, planning, acquisition and execution. BPES is working on ensuring alignment with the federal budget process and providing more detailed and accurate data, as required. BPES complied with the recent DHS CIO data call on planned IT Expenditure Reporting. BPES recently completed a detailed Current Program Estimate (CPE), built from the ground up and with inputs from a vast array of BPES stakeholders. The CPE is an important input to the BY18 BPES Business Case. Moreover, it will be a living document from which future BPES Resource Allocation Plans will be developed. https://www.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/1232 

BPES does not have material weaknesses to address.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no changes.
Operational Analysis Results:
Customer Satisfaction: BPES conducted its second customer survey in February 2016. Overall satisfaction for BPES, at 3.5/5.0, remains above average, although it declined from 2015. Network issues and training are opportunities for improvement. BPES is addressing these areas by conducting a follow-up survey to understand training types users seek and ways to reduce network outage risks. BPES included training budgets in the recently completed Current Program Estimate (CPE) and the program is piloting a new application to monitor network traffic.

Strategic/Business: BPES strategic and business metrics continue to reflect above average ratings in its ability to capture data that help detect, identify, classify and resolve illegal border activity (3.4/5.0), and its ability in effectively managing resources (3.3/5.0).  BPES remains a DHS priority as it provides critical Border Patrol technology that effectively assist USBP agents perform the mission.
 
Innovation: BPES continues to support USBP by providing innovative technologies that help meet the challenges of changing border security needs. Tracking Sign-Cutting and Modeling (TSM) is a national geospatial tracking system that provides real-time representation of agent activity and operations, with the ability to pass unresolved activity to adjacent Sectors, Stations or relief shift agents.  Once TSM is integrated into mobile-based tracking, the new technology will enable field agents to access and share information, enhancing situational awareness and officer safety.

Financial: BPES system users increased by 28% to 78,582 in the last year and the program is on target to meet its budget. Total Planned Cost for FY16 equal $36.918M and FY16 Total Expenditures amount to $36.816M, a .28% variance.

Operational Metrics: BPES continues to operate beyond the monthly uptime target level of 99%.

Risk: BPES is a medium risk investment continually monitored and managed, employing sound riskmanagement practices across the investment. Changing priorities may lead to unplanned program costs; Agile is employed to minimize risks. A CPE was developed to improve long-term planning and forecasting. Open staffing positions may lead to schedule delays. BPES communicates staffing needs regularly and shares resources as appropriate across projects.  Finally, reliability on external systems may prevent BPES from delivering operational capabilities. BPES is piloting a new application to monitor network performance.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Border Patrol Enforcement System (BPES) is in the Support life cycle phase. BPES continues to work with the CBP Office of Acquisitions (OA) to develop a path forward on becoming an acquisition program of record. Documentation requirements were agreed upon with a target completion in 3QFY17. In 3QFY17, the program will complete the annual review of the Risk Management Plan (RMP), complete the annual Operational Analysis (OA), and participate in the CBP component program review. BPES has four projects in-progress that are all operating within acceptable OMB range for cost and schedule variance. Continued BPES benefits include improved information sharing, improved system and process integration, and rapid response ability. BPES only has one monthly operational performance metric, and continues to exceed the target of uptime percentage of system applications that captures business and operational effectiveness. BPES conducted the first iteration of its bi-annual customer satisfaction survey in 2QFY17, as planned.  Survey results, which will include user satisfaction and strategic/business metrics, are being analyzed and will be available in 3QFY17. Program risks and issues are discussed in daily scrum meetings and integrated project team (IPT) meetings to identify potential cost and schedule slippages and performance shortfalls. This allows the program manager and project leads to implement mitigation strategies to minimize probability and potential impact.
