After assessing BPES for five cycles, the program continues to effectively manage the consolidated system and exceed all technical, operational, and programmatic requirements.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) now assesses CBP BPES as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of the Revenue Modernization (Rev Mod) program is to consolidate, automate, and streamline fragmented and manual revenue collections processes by leveraging modern technology to safeguard over $45 billion in annual collections, position the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) with technology to meet emerging revenue program requirements, and transform how CBP interacts financially with the Trade and Travel industry partners.
The goal is to introduce efficiencies in mission delivery and agency support functions by modernizing and automating revenue processes, resulting in a significant savings in time spent on revenue collection activities by CBP Officers (CBPOs) and support staff. Rev Mod estimates that full implementation will result in a decrease of up to 75% of the time spent by CBP’s uniformed personnel, and 80% by non-uniformed personnel, in revenue collection activities.  In addition to decreasing the resource time spent on revenue collections CBP plans to consolidate, automate, and streamline documentation and procedures, improve payment options and reporting capabilities, streamline facility inefficiencies and improve the legal framework with the modernized revenue processes. 
Of the approximately $45B (21 million transactions) CBP collections in duties, taxes, and fees annually, nearly $1.5B and 4 million individual transactions are processed in the field by CBPOs and support staff. Rev Mod is targeted to allow nearly 180 CBP Officers and 136 non-uniformed CBP personnel to refocus the time currently spent engaged in collection activities to focus on trade and travel enforcement and facilitation duties when transactions are moved to electronic platforms. In addition to CBP savings and efficiencies, the trade and travel industries will benefit from the offering of modernized options for transacting business with CBP.  Lastly, there are direct correlations to economic benefit associated with the effort.  According to the University of Southern California “CREATE? study, for each additional CBP Officer the estimated economic impact includes a $2 million increase in Gross Domestic Product meaning that the reallocation of CBPO time to facilitating trade and travel will potentially have a $360 million economic impact. Key customers, beneficiaries and stakeholders include Office of Finance (OF), Office of Field Operations (OFO), Office of International Trade (OT) and Trade and Travel Communities.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3242 - M&S Goal 6.2: Enhance Partnerships and Outreach, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3259 - Goal 2.2:  Safeguard and Expedite Lawful Trade and Travel
Investment Requirements:
Revenue Modernization links to the following strategies, directives, and legal requirements:
Executive Order 13659:  Calls for completing “single window? through which businesses will transmit data required by participating agencies for importation and exportation of cargo, including the transition from paper-based requirements and procedures to faster and more cost-effective electronic submissions to, and communications with, agencies.  Rev Mod will expand payment options;  https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/02/19/executive-order-streamlining-exportimport-process-america-s-businesses 
Executive Order 13571: Necessitating the use of innovative technologies to streamline agency processes to reduce costs, accelerate delivery, and improve the customer experience; https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2011/04/27/executive-order-13571-streamlining-service-delivery-and-improving-custom 
The 2016 Department of Homeland Security Appropriation Bill expectation to “eliminate the need for CBP Officers to accept cash for any transactions at the POEs by 2020?; https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/114th-congress/house-report/215/1
The Department of the Treasury’s electronic collections goals and its ongoing initiatives to promote the use of a wide variety of cutting-edge technology to collect revenue.
Revenue Modernization will address a longstanding financial statement audit finding citing CBP for non-compliance with Federal Financial Management Improvement Act (FFMIA) requirements for fully integrated financial systems
Revenue Modernization supports the following CBP Commissioner’s FY17 Priority: Goal 2, Deliverable 12: Enhance current technology deployments along the southern border through upgrades and improvements of existing systems and GOAL 3, Deliverable 23: Continue process improvements and refining of CBP system capabilities to achieve account-based processing, deliver enhanced account.  This may include creation of a new revenue modernization program office, transitioning to a modern information technology platform that can automate processes, and development of short andlong term plans and policies for simplified processes and account-basedtransactions for the Trade community.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Not applicable because this is the first budget submission.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Patrol (CBP) Revenue Modernization (RevMod) program is in the Analyze/Select and Obtain life cycle phase. The program is operating within acceptable OMB ranges for cost and schedule variances. The program has initiated three pilot projects as proof of concept to consolidate the revenue collections to the current CBP financial system and evaluate how it will close the RevMod capability gaps. These pilot projects will also lead to the development of an Alternative Analysis for the consolidation of CBP’s revenue collections. The schedule completion of the pilot projects is 2QFY18. Since last assessment the program completed the migration of the Transition of Global Entry Online Enrollment System (GOES), Decal/Transponder Online Payment System (DTOPS) to CBP financial system and Phase 1 of the Mobile Collections & Receipt Pilot projects.  An Acquisition Review Board (ARB) is scheduled 4QFY17 for approval to conduct the Acquisition Decision Event (ADE) 2A/2B. The program continues to manage risk by prioritizing the most imminent risk and putting the mitigation strategy in place according to the risk management plan. The program currently has a negligible risk exposure score.  Until the program achieves ADE 2A/2B and completes the pilot projects, The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continue to assess the CBP RevMod program as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The purpose of EVUS is to enable DHS to require covered aliens to provide periodic updates of certain biographical information prior to travelling to the U.S. A key goal of EVUS is to receive, capture, and adjudicate enrollees in near-real time, 24 hours a day, and 365 days a year, greatly enhancing CBP’s ability to deliver on its mission to safeguard America’s borders. 
 
EVUS’ specific contribution to mission delivery, is articulated in QHSR Mission 1: Prevent Terrorism and Enhance Security . Outdated data may inhibit CBP from identifying aliens who represent risks to our national security, including terrorists.  EVUS will ensure that vetting processes utilize the most complete data available. Further, EVUS capabilities will allow OFO to advance the department and agency goals articulated in the CBP Strategic Plan, Vision and Strategy 2020, by securing U.S. borders by pushing the zone of security outward.  Development of EVUS will align with the Commissioner’s Strategic Goals for the current fiscal year:

Goal 1: Counter Terrorism and Transnational Crime by leveraging technology through its web-based system that determines eligibility of visitors to travel to the U.S., EVUS will demonstrate synergy through the intelligence and targeting efforts of the intelligence community by utilizing their capabilities and networks to conduct queries amongst law enforcement databases.   
 
Goal 3: Enhance U.S. Economic Competitiveness by Enabling Lawful Trade and Travel, Programming Guidance LOB 3: Securing and Expediting Travel.  EVUS will facilitate receiving visa holder’s updated biographical data in advance of travel, resulting in enhanced vetting.
 
Customers of EVUS include covered aliens possessing 10-year B1/B2 visas, travel agents acting on behalf of travelers, and common carriers responsible for ensuring that travelers to the U.S. possess proper travel documents prior to boarding and departure. 
Stakeholders include CBP officers responsiblefor vetting/admitting covered aliens, the U.S. State Department, who issues and manage visa applications, as well as U.S. business interests who depend on international trade, travel, and tourism.
 
Beneficiaries of EVUS include the general public, who are better protected from dangerous persons entering the U.S., covered aliens who are provided a reliable and convenient way to update their biographical information while obviating personal visits to U.S. embassies and consulates.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3259 - Goal 2.2:  Safeguard and Expedite Lawful Trade and Travel
ROI Description:
ROI cannot yet be calculated for EVUS, a newly-operational program. However, EVUS has delivered significant national security benefits since IOC was deployed.  Biographical information collected by EVUS resulted in the revocation of over 20 10-year visas. Since EVUS now requires the PRC to report lost/stolen PRC-issued passports, over 2 million have been reported, and over 200 EVUS enrollments have been denied on that basis.  Each denial/revocation represents a significant risk to national security that has been avoided by preventing these visa-holders from traveling to the U.S.

EVUS’ internal benefits includes reduced administrative and personnel costs resulting from replacing many millions of 1-year visas with 10-year visas, obviating government expense caused by multiple 1-year renewals. EVUS will also benefit the government by greatly improving the timeliness and accuracy of biographic and other information used for vetting. External benefits include benefits to covered aliens, who will benefit by avoiding significantly higher costs for each new 1-year visa. Since covered aliens must comply with EVUS in order to maintain the validity of their visas, the mandate is self-enforcing. Since EVUS will be fully funded program through collection of user fees, these benefits (more current vetting data, security beyond the border, reduced administrative costs) will be achieved without taxpayer expense.
Investment Requirements: The Secretary of State and the Secretary of Homeland Security have statutory authority under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) [https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/STATUTE-79/pdf/STATUTE-79-Pg911.pdf] related to visa issuance, revocation and conditions of admission and entry for aliens seeking to enter the United States, and have mandated that CBP develop and deploy an electronic system as described in Sections 2.a. – 2.e above . DHS and DOS are establishing EVUS primarily under the authorities granted in INA sections 103 (8 U.S.C. 1103), 214 (8 U.S.C. 1184), 215 (8 U.S.C. 1185), 221 (8 U.S.C. 1201); and section 402(4) of the Homeland Security Act (“HSA?), 6 U.S.C. 202(4). INA section 221(a)(1)(B) authorizes DOS to issue nonimmigrant visas to foreign nationals. This rule amends 8 CFR by renaming Part 215 [https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/granule/CFR-2016-title8-vol1/CFR-2016-title8-vol1-part215] “Controls of Aliens Departing from the United States; Electronic Visa Update System,? placing the existing sections 215.1 through 215.9 into a Subpart A entitled “Controls of Aliens Departing from the United States? and adding new sections in a Subpart B, entitled “Electronic Visa Update System.? [https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2016-10-20/pdf/2016-25326.pdf] There are currently 145 business requirements that are held in the EVUS Concepts of Operations and Operational Requirements Document which, when deployed will meet or exceed all legislative and regulatory requirements.  After considering various options, the DHS Secretary mandated, in the interest of time and national security, that the EVUS approach be developed and deployed.  This decision obviated developing a cost-benefit analysis (CBA) or an Analysis of Alternatives (AoA).
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: FY2017 President’s Budget did not anticipate security concerns raised by issuance of 10-year visas to citizens of PRC.  DHS mandated development, deployment, and sustainment of EVUS after FY17 budget was finalized.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Electronic Visa Update System (EVUS) is in the Support life cycle phase. EVUS is in the process of becoming fee funded, and is a web-based system that determines eligibility of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) visitors with a 10-year B1/B2 Visa to travel to the United States; and whether such travel poses a law enforcement or security risk. EVUS is using the PRC as a pilot country to facilitate periodic online updates of biographical information similar to the CBP Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) program/form. EVUS completed development and reached full operational capability (FOC) in 1QFY17 by incorporating agile development based on the existing ESTA system. In addition to reaching FOC, current year objectives include collection of fee revenue and ensuring the overall quality of traveler data retained by the government for vetting EVUS enrollees. The funding request for the budget year and out-years do not currently reflect expansion of program scope to additional countries that might be identified in the future by the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Secretary of State. The program is operating within acceptable OMB range for cost and schedule variance. The program has not been in operations and maintenance (O&M) long enough for an Operational Analysis (OA) to be completed. A post-implementation review (PIR) is expected by the end of 2QFY17. Those results, as well as key performance parameters (KPP) will be addressed in the next assessment.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the EVUS program as a Moderately-Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: Direct Access is a Military HR and Payroll system that uses COTS products. It is the authoritative source for all USCG HR and personnel management data. It is a cost efficient and effective investment that meets business owner expectations and is in alignment with USCG/DHS and USPHS/HHS missions and visions. Direct Access provides HR and payroll services to two non-DoD uniformed services - NOAA CC and USPHS CC.  All three services follow HR and payroll requirements as mandated by the annual National Defense Authorization Act and Direct Access fulfills the requirements for the 3 services. The goals of the system are to maintain state of the art HR and Payroll applications that are reliable, sustainable and secure; meet the business & mission requirements; sustain HR and payroll functions; and provide cost-effective, dependable, and accurate HR and payroll data used by CG and PHS for mission execution planning. Benefits include the consolidation of over 5 CG HR and payroll applications and 6 PHS HR applications, including the legacy Joint Uniform Military Payroll System (JUMPS). USPHS has gained new functions that help manage their workforce, and improve accountability and efficiency in support of their missions. On 4/1/2008, the USCG Retiree and Annuitant payroll processing system was formally migrated from a legacy, custom-built, mainframe based system into the Direct Access application. In 4QFY07, USPHS CC was directed by OMB to investigate the CG’s success in implementing a commercial HR and Payroll product. This demonstrates that the USCG is a Center of Excellence as a provider of outsourced Military HR services. Direct Access has achieved significant cost savings through system and application migrations in compliance with: FITARA, FMIA and FMFIA, & the guidance to maximize the use of COTS and Agile development. This investment is required to meet personnel tracking and military payroll requirements documented in Titles 10 & 14 of the U.S. Code.  It enables real-time data for ready deployment of USCG and USPHS personnel in response to planned and unplanned mission events. Direct Access provides a tool that captures officer skillsets and position requirements in an integrated and standardized way, allowing hiring officials and deployment staff to match officers with the attributes needed for the role at hand. Key Stakeholders: USCG and USPHS active duty & retiree personnel, USCG & USPHS managers, and payroll processing, finance, & HR personnel.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3241 - M&S Goal 6.1: Integrate Intelligence, Information Sharing, and Operations, 5502 - M&S Goal 6.6: Strengthen Service Delivery and Manage DHS Resources
ROI Description:
Direct Access consolidated over five CG HR and payroll applications and six PHS HR applications. It is a cost effective Operations and Maintenance (O&M) IT investment that exceeds business owner expectations. As evidenced by the data below, the Direct Access investment continues to prove to be extremely beneficial for stakeholders both internal and external to USCG. The migration of each of the systems into Direct Access has resulted in over $4M in annual cost savings in terms of hardware, software, and administrative support. The system pays huge dividends by integrating all aspects of HR to allow for a true Talent Management System. Through integrating PeopleSoft’s payroll system, Global Pay, lines of accounting controls have been greatly enhanced for Active Duty (AD) and Reserve personnel. It ensures improved and accurate lines of accounting in Direct Access, which has allowed USCG’s Pay and Personnel Center (PPC) to discontinue two backend manual accounting processes. 
  
External benefits have increased with this consolidation in that users can access a single payroll application in one place. Additionally, prior to Direct Access, the Service Personnel Office (SPO) had to process every individual leave transaction manually.  Through the functionality of Absence Requests, the number of requests to be manually processed by SPO was reduced by 260,000 annually. This translates into eliminating approximately 13,500 man-hours of data entry work, a total cost savings of $548,166 per year. Direct Access also resulted in the elimination of 115 Yeoman billets in 2000, a $12M annual recurring savings every year since.   Additionally, from 2004 to 2014, the implementation of Direct Access has proven a 20% increase in customer satisfaction for completing individual personnel transactions.  
   
The ROI is calculated by the savings from Yeoman billets ($12M) plus the savings from automating absence request processing ($0.548M) plus the FY13 savings from systems transitioned into Direct Access (Orders and Accessions) and decommissioning of RATS ($1.200M) divided by FY13 costs ($10.270M).
Investment Requirements:
Direct Access directly aligns to legislative mandates, including Titles 10 and 14 of the U.S. Code and the Coast Guard 11 Statutory Missions (found at: http://uscode.house.gov/download/download.shtml) by closing the requirement gap in meeting USCG delivery and management of personnel tracking and military payroll requirements. 

Direct Access’ integration of five separate CG applications and six PHS applications into one allows for more cross functional use while reducing data errors by eliminating interfaces.  The consolidation of multiple systems into Direct Access allows for reduction in the costs associated with configuration management, change management, security certification and accreditation, IT governance, and Earned Value Management (EVM).   Use of a Commercial off the Shelf (COTS) solution with outsourced hosting has also provided significant long-term cost savings in terms of technology refresh costs for hardware and application upgrades. Through these efforts, Direct Access directly aligns to the following Presidential Directives: 

*Shared Service Strategy (https://cio.gov/it-shared-services)
* Implement the Campaign to Cut Waste (CCW), Executive order 13520 - Reducing Improper Payments (http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/omb/financial/campaign-to-cut-waste.pdf) 
*Building at 21st Century Government by Cutting Duplication, Fragmentation, and Waste (http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/building_a_21st_century_government.pdf) 
* Implementation Plan to Reform IT (25 Point Plan) - (https://www.cio.gov/documents/25-Point-Implementation-Plan-to-Reform-Federal%20IT.pdf).
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: The summary of funding has increased due to extending into FY2022.
Operational Analysis Results:
Financial Performance - The benefits of consolidating legacy CG systems and PHS HR systems into Direct Access/Global Pay has continued to provide significant cost savings including the elimination of costly legacy systems at PHS. Additional consolidation efforts will continue into FY17, further reducing costs. 

Customer Satisfaction -   As part of the performance metrics reported in the IT Business Case and to the Federal IT Dashboard, Overall Customer Service Quality scale of 1 (low) to 5 (high) is evaluated quarterly with a target of 4 and an actual result as of 6/30/2016 of 4.10. 

Strategic and Business Results - Direct Access aligns to the Quadrennial Homeland Security Review (QHSR) Mission theme: "Mature and Strengthen Homeland Security" by "Strengthening the Service delivery and Managing DHS Resources." Direct Access directly supports "Recruit, hire, retain, and develop a highly qualified, diverse, effective, mission-focused, and resilient workforce" which is required to for USCG to meet its and DHS mission areas. Direct Access manages a member and their HR and payroll information from cradle to grave to include: Staff position types, organization/department, and location; Skill sets and competency/accomplishment data; Pay rates, schedules, and mechanisms. 

Operational Performance Measures - Direct Access has 4 operational performance measures: Overall Customer Service Quality, System Availability, Average Audit Response Time, and Maintain Budget Within 5% Variance. As of 6/30/2016, all performance measures exceed expectations.

Innovation - Direct Access replaced five USCG legacy systems allowing for more cross functional, reducing data errors by eliminating interfaces. With the inclusion of Global Payroll, two more costly legacy systems, RATS and JUMPS, have been retired as well. Hardware and software support costs associated with the legacy and outdated IBM mainframe will be eliminated. These benefits will be extended throughout FY-17 - FY-19 through the consolidation of other HR related functions and systems into the Direct Access architecture further adding to the cost reductions and improved efficiencies stated above. Direct Access also helps reduce Gov’t IT infrastructure presence and costs by consolidating USPHS HR and Pay apps into Direct Access. 

Risk Analysis - Significant Operational and Project Risks continue to be tracked, managed, and mitigated. There are no significant changes to the program's risks at this time.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Coast Guard (USCG) Direct Access program is in the Support life cycle phase. The program is currently operating within OMB recommended threshold for cost and schedule variance. Since the last assessment, the program completed Phase 1 upgrade from 9.1 to 9.2 Application & Tool and Integration of Mobilization Readiness and Tracking Tool (MRTT) into the Direct Access System. These upgrades enable to keep the implementation up to date with security, PII, business process improvements. The program has conducted an Operational Analysis on March 2017, which indicates the program is meeting all targeted performance metrics in the area of Customer Satisfaction, Innovation, Strategic and Business goals, and financial performance. The program continues to manage risk by prioritizing the most imminent risk and putting the mitigation strategy in place according to the risk management plan. The program currently has Negligible Risk Exposure score. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the Direct Access program as a Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
Purpose: The R21 system is an advanced command, control, and communications system that greatly enhance the Coast Guard’s ability to execute missions in the coastal zone; the system is essential by meeting the Coast Guards Search and Rescue (SAR) mission-program performance goals.  The investment is contributing in a positive manner by better locating mariners in distress & saving lives & property at sea by providing increased communications coverage and incorporating advanced Direction Finding (DF) and Very High Frequency (VHF) radio Digital Selective Calling (DSC) capabilities.   R21 significantly increases the ability to detect and respond to marine distress calls in the coastal zone, resulting in marine safety benefits to all stakeholders (Internal/External); U.S. public, CG operators, boating public, DHS Undersecretary for Management, U.S. Congress, & other federal, state & local maritime operators, emergency response & law enforcement units/agencies are the key customers and significant beneficiaries of this system.  
 
Benefits/Stakeholders: The Program stakeholders include Coast Guard operators, the boating public, DHS Undersecretary for Management, the U.S. Congress, and other federal, state and local maritime operators, emergency response and law enforcement units/agencies.  As of June 2016, the deployed R21 coastal system has supported over 89,000 SAR cases and has allowed the nation to fulfill Global Maritime Distress and Safety System requirements. 
  
As of June 30, 2016, the R21 system is deployed and operational over approximately 260,000 square miles of coverage in 32 of 37 Coast Guard Sectors, which were delivered by the prime contractor.  The Coast Guard is the lead system integrator for the remaining 5 sectors (Western Rivers and Alaska).   
  
R21 Coastal has completed Final Acceptance in all 32 of 32 Coast Guard Sectors. Continue system implementation in 3 Western Rivers Sectors & 2 Alaska Sectors, including new remote radio communication consoles, DSC capability and 6 new RFFs (3 in WR/3 in AK); Continue system testing  and deployments; Transition to full sustainment operations.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 46751 - Enhance Disaster Preparedness and Response
ROI Description:
The R21 Return on Investment (ROI) was determined by a Cost Analysis dtd March 2005; the cost analysis demonstrated a ROI of 3.05 and a payback period of 13 years. In determining the ROI, the R21 Key Decision Point (KDP) 1 was completed in Jul 1995 and authorized entry into the program’s Concept and Technology Demonstration phase under the authority of DOT. In Aug 1999, KDP2 authorized the program to proceed into the Capability Development and Demonstration phase. In Aug 2001, the Coast Guard awarded three R21 Phase I contracts to competing contractors to develop proposed system designs. The Phase I proposals were reviewed in late 2001 and the Phase II production contract RFP was issued in Feb 2002. Following a formal source selection process, the USCG’s Source Selection Official (SSO) awarded the R21 Phase II production contract to General Dynamics C4 Systems in Sep 2002. In Jul 2005, DHS authorized the R21 program to proceed into the Production and Deployment phase and full rate production subsequently commenced in Sep 2005. 
 
Internal Benefits: R21 is used to tailor CG response (including coordinating with local first responders and federal coordinators), significantly reducing response time to mariners in distress. The R21 system enhances the CG’s ability to detect & respond to distress calls in the coastal zone, which directly benefits the U.S. public’s marine safety & saves lives. Benefits also include system disaster recovery capabilities that have supported coordination in numerous federals regional response and remediation efforts by providing a critical communication backbone in the disaster regions. For example, the R21 system provided a communication system that supported efforts to re-open ports in NY and NJ after hurricane Sandy. 
 
External Benefits of the R21 system: Provides capabilities to help ensure the successful outcome of Search and Rescue (SAR) missions. To date, R21 has been used in more than 89,000 SAR cases. Advanced DF whichmore accurately identifies the location of callers with lines of bearing to the VHF radio transmission source which reduces response time & search area; Continuous, enhanced VHF-FM marine radio coverage out to 20 nautical miles from shore; improved ability to identify suspected hoax calls; Increases the number of voice channels; Digital voice recording w/ immediate playback; Timely flow of info between CG & other stakeholders. 
 
The R21 investment is slated to reach the breakeven point in 2018.
Investment Requirements:
MTSA of 2002 (Pub L 107-295) Section 346: The R21 investment is derived from the Maritime Transportation Security ACT (MTSA) of 2002(Pub. L. 107-295) Section 346. R21 is a DHS Level 1 Command, Control, & Communications (C3) system capital investment that replaced the CGs antiquated legacy National Distress and Response Systems (NDRS) and greatly enhances the CGs ability to execute missions in the coastal zone and is essential to meet the Service's search and rescue mission-program performance goals.

Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA): R21 is FISMA compliant and has programs planned or in progress to maintain the confidentiality, integrity & availability of the information system.  FISMA driven programs include an operating system upgrade, VSAT/4G wide area network redundancy and ongoing obsolescence management.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no fundamental or substantive changes.
Operational Analysis Results: Total O&M costs since portions of R21 moved into sust was 84M in 2013,78M in 2014,78M in 2015,&105M in 2016.The deltas between actual costs & LCCE data are a result of lower than expected lease & facility costs.OE costs will increase as the remaining portions of R21 are deployed & moved into sust.The sponsor & sust organization routinely interact with R21 stakeholders & customers via integrated product teams & monthly Field User meetings to manage goals & obtain field level feedback.Sponsor provided Sectors with a survey allowing watchstanders to provide feedback that is shared among stakeholders for future potential performance enhancements.R21 is in alignment with the CG mission programs & support DHS goals & objectives to communicate with mariners in distress,who can assist others in distress,reporting safety & security threats,CG boats,cutters & aircraft, & partner agency emergency response assets to protect the coastal areas of the US.R21 strategic & business results successfully attained include:R21 is fully operational in 32/37 sectors;Covers approx 42K nautical miles of US coastline&296K square nautical miles of coastal area;R21 connected mariners in distress to the CG during more than 90K SAR cases.The R21 program uses 10 specific system functions as shown in the OA & elsewhere in INVEST. The recent monthly results are included in INVEST while the OA summarizes performance for the FY.R21 performance is meeting or exceeding Ao across all 10 Key Performance Parameters with 0.997 composite Ao.The CG has completed 3 significant initiatives since the last OA period;Deployed Federal Interoperability & Interoperability Advanced Encryption Standard capability to enable comm& centers to communicate securely with federal, state, local, & tribal partner;Replaced all CH16 Guard radios with IP-based radios allowing CH16 to remain operational during security patches/updates.This eliminated the need to deploy costly assets to cover the CH16 Guard;Virtualized hardware digital interface units thereby eliminating the hardware footprint.This also improved COOP flexibility for Sectors as it allows all sites to be monitored from other locations more easily.The most current risks are listed in INVEST.Significant risks to R21 include insufficient sust funding due to resource proposal reductions that were applied proportionally across all C4IT programs. WR & AK deployments being moved into sust will require the full $100 million Congress has allocated for R21.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The US Coast Guard (USCG) Rescue 21 (R21) Program is in the Mixed life cycle phase. R21 is operating within acceptable OMB thresholds for cost and schedule variance. The R21 system offers enhanced maritime domain awareness and significantly improved interoperability with other federal, state, and local agencies. The program will transition to full-sustainment when the remaining sectors in the Alaska and Western Rivers phases reach full-operational capability (FOC) in 4QFY17. An Operational Analysis (OA) was completed in 4QFY16 for the performance and cost of the steady-state Coastal sector. The OA concludes that R21 provides the most cost efficient way for USCG to invest in communications improvements and support overall mission objectives. R21 continues to meet or exceed operational availability requirements and increase the number of search and rescue cases where the R21 system is used. A User Assessment/Evaluation conducted in 4QFY16 demonstrated complete satisfaction by users, and the system is currently meeting their needs. Risks are being carefully monitored, updated, and mitigated. The program remains engaged with USCG and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to ensure compliance with compatibility designs and security standards. Weather and technical delays in Alaska could slow final efforts to finalize power plant and network connectivity operations. A component acquisition review board (ARB) and DHS Chief Information Officer (CIO) program health assessment are scheduled for 4QFY17 to review progress and the potential realization of risks.  The DHS CIO continues to assess the USCG Rescue 21 program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
CGBI provides reporting, analysis, data discovery, and data visualization services to enterprise decision makers, managers, unit leaders, and individuals. CGBI is used in all mission and support areas. CGBI supports effective Enterprise Data Management via the Enterprise Data Warehouse that cross-references data for speed of reporting and data sharing and provides information from over 40 authoritative data sources. The goal is to align decision making with the Commandant’s direction - to protect those on the sea, protect against threats delivered by the sea, and protect the sea itself - by providing decision makers with the right data at the right time, with a system availability of 98% or better.  
CGBI benefits our 90,000 users/stakeholders by providing these services reliably, ensuring more accurate and timely data, in a user friendly environment providing visibility across all functional areas of the Coast Guard based on established data and metrics. CGBI provides reporting capability for personnel readiness and performance management needs. CGBI benefits leadership by replacing “gut instinct? with decisions driven by hard data. CGBI directly supports all USCG units - ashore, afloat, and air – with Business Intelligence capabilities used for daily operations and planning. Benefits also include providing the metrics and statistical data to support HQ budgetary, personnel, and operational analysis. 
The key CG customers of CGBI are decision makers (managers and process owners) representing the human resources, operations, finance, IT, mission support and field units. Major CG stakeholders include the Mission Support, Operations, Resource, and Command Control staffs; Senior Leadership Council; and field units, CG Auxiliary, and DoD.
CGBI contributes to mission delivery by supporting unit commanders directly through operational reporting (crew readiness, training, billet fill, medical, deployability, and other readiness metrics), tracking crew competency and proficiency. CGBI supports financial, personnel and other HQ audit remediation actions and reconciliation processes by consolidating and relating data from across all mission areas to provide mandated reporting and analysis capabilities. 
Please see the Investment attachment (CGBI_MissionAndFunctionalAlignment_AUG2016.pdf) for QHSR Mission/Goals Objectives alignment and DHS Functional/Capability/Activity alignment. There is insufficient space available in this field to detail this alignment.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3241 - M&S Goal 6.1: Integrate Intelligence, Information Sharing, and Operations, 3249 - Goal 5.3: Ensure Effective Emergency Response, 5492 - M&S Goal 6.5  Ensure Readiness of Frontline Operators and First Responders, 5502 - M&S Goal 6.6: Strengthen Service Delivery and Manage DHS Resources
ROI Description:
Return on Investment: 
Of the $9.6 billion dollars appropriated to the USCG in FY15, CGBI positively influenced the use of $163 million or 1.7% of those dollars. For a yearly investment of $4.3 million, CGBI’s influence of this investment was approximately 3000%. (Note: According to industry, a well run BI system can have an ROI up to 4000% within a large organization.) CGBI positively influenced the effectiveness of over 3 million hours of user time. This equates to every Coast Guard employee and contractor using CGBI saving at least 13 minutes, every day of every year. Although this investment cannot be measured in returned profits, its value is demonstrated in its ability to positively influence the use of user’s time allowing for effective use of the Coast Guard’s investment.
 
Benefits: 
Data Sharing – Provide “one version of the truth? by providing a centralized capability for reporting and analysis
Cost Avoidance – Efficiencies related to saving users time for performance management and reporting needs increasing opportunity cost for the organization allowing users to effective use their time. 
Reduction of IT Redundancy – Consolidating reporting into one centrally managed location rather than building this capability for several missions
 
Outcomes: Constant improvement of unit readiness and management by timely integrated reporting, analysis, and performance management.
Investment Requirements:
This investment serves reporting, performance management and analysis support functions for most Coast Guard mandates.  As the Coast Guard’s investment for enterprise business intelligence capability, the investment maintains several cross functional data sources to fulfill most auditing, reporting, and legislative mandates for the organization.  

1. GAO-16-379: Published: May 24, 2016, Actions Needed to Improve Strategic Allocation of Assets and Determine Workforce Requirements  (www.gao.gov/products/GAO-16-379). CGBI is a key component of the Operational Planning and Assessment Reporting (OPAR) process and human workforce allocations analyses processes providing reporting and dashboard analysis for decision makers.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: No significant changes.
Operational Analysis Results: OA was conducted in compliance with OMB Circ. A-11 in order to assure alignment of the system with desired operational outcomes by answering specific questions regarding Customer Results, Strategic and Business Results, Financial Performance, Innovation, and Operational Performance Measures, and Risk Analysis. Customer results metrics are well defined and managed through automated surveys and reporting known as the customer relationship management (CRM). Results average over 74% customer satisfaction and approximately 82% customer ease of use determinations. Strategic and business results are measured using CRM results for specific CGBI products within each USCG functional area aligned by the Federal Enterprise Architecture Business Reference Model (FEA BRM). Financial Performance is monitored by the program against documented project plans and the investment has operated within budget. Innovation is continually assessed, monitored and implemented by taking into consideration CRM, customer feedback and requests for new products and capabilities. Future plans to implement tools to aid in more data analysis and discovery. Operational Performance is measured using standardized BI and performance management metrics such as time saved by using the CGBI system. The CGBI system continues to show a strong, positive influence on investment of over 100%. The CGBI system exceeded system availability target of 99%. Risk Analysis is conducted by the program on a quarterly basis to include technical, cost, and schedule risks. The CGBI program mitigated all risks with no impact on benefit and performance of the investment. CGBI continues to exceed expectations and is fully aligned with USCG mission and business support needs. CGBI is fully integrated into the USCG and DHS enterprise architectures with widespread support from users and leadership. It is fully anticipated that the investment will continue to provide crucial capabilities to USCG and other users in an effective and cost efficient manner.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Coast Guard (USCG), Coast Guard Business Intelligence (CGBI) program is in the Support life cycle phase.  CGBI continues to operate within acceptable OMB ranges for cost and schedule variance. Program leadership continue to explore emerging technologies and capabilities to meet mission needs. A technical component of the current system used under Business Intelligence Infrastructure has a new version pending. The program is analyzing the new version for changes that could impact current business processes and capabilities. CGBI is a well-managed program that is successfully using hybrid agile development and maintenance methodology to meet and exceed its operational performance measures, such as system availability, user satisfaction, and ease of use of its system. The risks are actively monitored and have good mitigation strategies, giving the overall program a negligible risk exposure. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the Coast Guard Business Intelligence (CGBI) program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Investment Title: USCG - Asset Logistics Management Information System (ALMIS)
Brief Summary:
The purpose of the Asset Logistics Management information System (ALMIS) is to provide complete aviation and naval logistics support in operations, mission scheduling, asset configuration, asset maintenance, supply, procurement, and financial business processes.  ALMIS is a centralized system that captures programmatic information that is used at all levels of the Coast Guard..
 
The goal is to align ourselves with the Commandant’s direction to protect those on the sea and protect the nation from threats delivered by the sea and protect the sea itself by providing mission ready crews and assets and to support ALMIS users with system availability of 98% or better.  
 
ALMIS benefits our 22,000 customers and stakeholders by providing an electronic system which is reliable, ensures safe and mission ready assets, captures mission events accurately, is user friendly, and provides total asset status visibility.  ALMIS provides operational oversight capability for mission scheduling and execution. ALMIS benefits operational leadership by providing the tools to maintain OPCON/TACON oversight of our missions and assets. ALMIS directly supports our aviation and naval units to include 341 aircraft, 1996 Small Boats, 260 Cutters and 139 DGPS Towers. ALMIS benefits also include the metrics and statistics to support HQ operational budgetary requirements.
 
ALMIS contributes to Coast Guard mission delivery by supporting data entry from the start of an operational mission, recording the mission execution and tracking crew competencies and proficiency. The system maintains aircraft and naval asset maintenance along with standardization, supply, part replacements, and warehouse activities in order to provide safe and mission ready assets.  ALMIS supports core financial procurement actions, and the reconciliation necessary for current business processes. ALMIS contributes to the four key components of the circle of logistics, which are: mission, configuration, maintenance, and supply.
 
The key customers of ALMIS are the Configuration Control Board (CCB) membership representing the logistics centers, operational leadership and those providing the actual asset logistics support.
 
Our major stakeholders include CG-4, CG-7 and C4IT-SC along with the logistics centers to include SFLC, SILC and ALC.
Our country is a beneficiary as evidenced last year when the Coast Guard prosecuted 37,215 SAR cases resulting in many lives saved.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 5442 - Goal 4.1:  Strengthen the Security and Resilience of Critical Infrastructure against cyber attacks and other hazards, 46751 - Enhance Disaster Preparedness and Response
ROI Description:
The Asset Logistics Management Information System (ALMIS) directly integrates with aviation and naval core business processes for operations, configuration, maintenance, and supply which directly aligns and supports the three roles of the Coast Guard; Protect those on the sea; Protect the U.S. from threats delivered by sea; and Protect the sea itself.   
Return on Investment is a performance measure which evaluates the gain from investment divided by the cost. In our organization this return on investment is measured by meeting the key goals and missions of the Coast Guard which ALMIS directly supports.  

The benefits from aviation are reflected in the following highlights:  The Coast Guard responded to over 37,000 potential cases, benefiting the public by saving more than 3,000 lives in FY15/16.  Additionally there were over 6,000 sorties supporting Living Marine Resources, 3,300 sorties for Drug Interdiction and 1,900 Migrant Interdiction sorties that directly benefit all citizens. Coast Guard aviation's 341 aircraft and their crews played a significant part in these accomplishments.  ALC’s unwavering air station support ensured the operational unit readiness, measured by operational availability met the needs of the public.  The benefit of Coast Guard mission success is the result of key operational/engineering support and documentation systems which ALMIS provides.  ALMIS is the foundation for mission scheduling, asset permission and servicing, mission records, documentation of scheduled and unscheduled maintenance, asset configuration, maintenance due lists to maintain all operational assets, key financial and supply support systems which when combined, keep our asset availability rate so high.  
ALC continues to add both vessels and aircraft into ALMIS and is becoming the asset status system of record for most of the Coast Guard.  In 2016, ALC added the all large cutters into ALMIS, achieving total asset visibility.
Investment Requirements:
ISD is guided by the objectives, goals and values contained in the USCG Strategic Goals, and the Department of Homeland Security’s (DHS) vision. ISD is under the command of the ALC Commanding Officer. ALC is subordinate to the command of Commandant, Engineering and Logistics (CG-4) under the Deputy Commandant for Mission Support (DCMS). As a System Owner, System Development Agent (SDA), OSC is in transition and will be  System Support Agent (SSA) for major logistics information systems, ISD is required to meet and comply with federal guidelines and regulations, and Command, Control, Communications, Computers and Information Technology (CG-6) plans and policies for C4IT assets. ISD services all ALC divisions, 26 Coast Guard aviation units, 378 naval units, and other units through matrix relationships and provides oversight for Headquarters’ sponsored projects which may include a designated project officer residing in ISD. The “other units? category represents several key relationships noted below:
 
Commandant (CG-11) – Health & Safety Directorate 
 
Commandant (CG-44) – Office of Logistics 
 
Commandant (CG-711) - Office of Aviation Forces
 
Commandant (CG-731) - Office of Boat Forces

Commandant (CG-741) - Office of Shore Forces
 
Commandant (CG-751) - Office of Cutter Forces
 
Commandant (CG-8) – Resources/CFO
 
CG Finance Center (FINCEN) – Financial Reporting 

Telecommunications and Information Systems Command (TISCOM) – Standard Workstation/CGDN 
 
ESU Portsmouth – Standard Workstation III Support
 
Operations Systems Center (OSC) – Data Center/Disaster Recovery.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no fundamental or substantive changes.
Operational Analysis Results:
Customer Results: For every ALMIS Work Request completed an email is sent to the customer requesting their feedback.  For every email correspondence sent to ALMIS users, it contains a link for the user to submit feedback to us. As part of ALC’s ISO 9000 certifications, failed surveys result in a Corrective/Preventative Action Report. 
Internal Business: ALMIS remains in alignment with DHS and Coast Guard strategic plans by providing “mission critical? logistical support to all aviation and surface assets in a cost efficient and transparent manner that is open for all to use and to see. ALMIS continues to meet its user’s expectations and needs by being available for use 98% of the time. Strategic Impact and Effectiveness: ALMIS supports data entry from the start of an operational mission, recording the mission execution, tracking crew events, asset aging, aircraft and boat configuration, aircraft and naval maintenance requirements, asset part replacements, warehouse activities, procurement actions, financial payments, and reconciliation. ALMIS addresses the processes surrounding the four key components of logistics, which are: mission, configuration, maintenance, and supply. Innovation: ALMIS is scheduled for the initial phase of replacement by CG-LIMS in FY16 and continuing through FY20.  As such, there are no new innovations planned for ALMIS. Financial Performance: ALMIS continues to consistently meet its financial performance goals. ALMIS is a CFO Compliant system and continues to adapt to new CFO requirements. This investments cost variance has not exceeded +/-10%. Potentially more cost effective alternatives to ALMIS have been considered and accepted. ALMIS is at its End of Life and is currently in the latter stages of being replaced by the Coast Guard’s new logistics system, CG-LIMS.  CG-LIMS will be a COTS product resulting in significant costs avoidance. Risk: Risks will be analyzed using likelihood, magnitude and preventative measures. The combination ofthese attributes will be used in determining the overall risk to the program. While every effort will be made to standardize the computation of overall risk, flexibility will be necessary for a more accurate analysis. Operational Performance: The ALMIS System Architecture is compliant with the Federal Enterprise Architecture Framework, being based on a client-server design with global connectivity that is provided through Internet-based interfaces and/or dedicated Wide Area Network Connectivity.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Coast Guard (USCG), Asset Logistics Management Information Systems (ALMIS) program is in the Support life cycle phase. The program is currently operating within OMB acceptable thresholds for cost and schedule variance. Since the last assessment the program continue to deliver maintenance releases and break fixes utilizing agile methodology. The program remains to be replaced by CG-LIMS. The subsystem of ALMIS, the Asset Computerized Maintenance System (ACMS) scheduled for the initial phase of replacement by CG-LIMS in FY18. The next subsystem of ALMIS, the Asset Maintenance Management Information System (AMMIS) scheduled to be replaced by 2019. The other two subsystems of ALMIS Electronic Asset Logbook (EAL) and Decision Support System (DSS) are scheduled to be migrated into the CG-LIMS application by 2020. ALMIS is expected to be completely replaced and "turned off" by 2022. The program conducted its Operational Analysis (OA) in March 2017, which indicates ALMIS is meeting their targeted performance metrics in the area of Customer Satisfaction, Strategic and Business goals, and financial performance. The program currently has a negligible risk exposure score and continues to manage risk by prioritizing the most imminent risk and putting the mitigation strategy in place according to the risk management plan. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the Asset Logistics Management Information Systems (ALMIS) program as a Low Risk investment.

Investment Title: USCG - Marine Information for Safety and Law Enforcement (MISLE)
Brief Summary:
Purpose: MISLE documents most USCG mission activities, support mission activity targeting and enables emergency response management in a way not currently available from other USCG, DHS, or COTS systems. 
Goals: MISLE facilitates vessel boardings, vessel and facility inspections, vessel and facility investigations, port and vessel security, waterways management, bridge management, pollution prevention, incident response, civil penalty processing, vessel documentation and targeting histories for vessels, facilities and parties. .
Benefits: MISLE is a highly integrated system and exchanges data with over 17 other government information systems, generating efficiency in operations as well as reducing overall IT cost.  Directly support to mission delivery for the Port State Control, Domestic Vessel Inspections, Port Security, Incident Management, Marine Safety, Marine Environmental Response and Law Enforcement missions.
Key stakeholders: are all operational programs in the Coast Guard, from field units to Headquarters.  Field units use MISLE to target their activities to vessels that haven’t been visited recently, resulting in significant efficiencies over random boardings.  The Marine Inspection program uses MISLE to schedule inspections as they are needed without extensive research among the vessel population.  The Search and Rescue (SAR) community uses MISLE to prosecute SAR cases.  Coast Guard Headquarters uses MISLE to measure field unit activity/workload; thus MISLE is a primary source for Coast Guard resource decisions.
Other Beneficiaries: Other than the stakeholders which are typically customers as well, MISLE customers include the Intelligence community (CG-2)  which receives information on Coast Guard activities.  MISLE also provides benefits directly to the public through the CGMIX site which provides information on vessels, investigations, MARPOL facilities, and approved equipment.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3249 - Goal 5.3: Ensure Effective Emergency Response, 3255 - Goal 3.1:  Strengthen and Effectively Administer the Immigration System, 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3259 - Goal 2.2:  Safeguard and Expedite Lawful Trade and Travel, 30982 - Goal 3.2: Prevent Unlawful Immigration, 46751 - Enhance Disaster Preparedness and Response
ROI Description: Investment is in Steady State and continues to provide benefits to the Coast Guard and the public by reducing the cost of performing missions, reducing the personnel and assets (aircraft, boats, cutters) needed to carry out missions, and reducing administrative costs by reducing duplicate entry of data into multiple systems.
Investment Requirements: MISLE meets the requirement in 46 USC 3717 to develop and maintain a Marine Safety Information System that tracks the history of vessels, including: owners, financial responsibility, registration, casualties, deficiencies, inspections and examinations.  MISLE also meet the requirement in 46 USC 12501 to establish a Vessel Identification System to track the ownership of documented, numbered and titled U.S. vessels.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no fundamental or substantive changes.
Operational Analysis Results:
Financial Performance:  MISLE has provided a postive return on investment to the USCG.  The system continues to provide benefits to stakeholders both within and outside the USCG.  The program office is continuing to make the system more efficient and effective through technology upgrades.
 
Customer Results:  Surveys of stakeholders and analysis of help desk tickets indicates that the system still effectively supports USCG missions and meets stakeholder expectations.
 
Business and Strategic Analysis:  MISLE aligns with both DHS and USCG strategic plans and priorities.  It continues to meet USCG business needs.
 
Operational Performance:  MISLE is currently meeting or exceeding targets for all performance measures.  The mobility performance measure was dropped due to the decision to drop the mobile capability from the investment.

Availability:  The system is well within availability requirements, with an average availability of 99.9%.
 
Risk Analysis:  All risks have been addressed through mitigation measures.

Innovation:  The MISLE 5.0 rewrite release represents a major innovation milestone for the United States Coast Guard's largest enterprise mission support system.  MISLE 5.0, based on Microsoft’s .Net framework, is a web based - internet/world wide web (wc3) standards compliant application/system architecture providing the chief benefits of cross platform compatibility including a web service application program interface, more manageable installation (i.e. it is only installed on the server placing minimal requirements on the end user workstation),  highly deployable via secure website address URL, increased scalability via hardware virtualization and horizontal  clustering - load balancing, and reduced support and maintenance costs due to MISLE’s component based-software design.  Innovation is discussed more in-depth in the MISLE Operational Analysis Report 2016 uploaded to the key documents tab.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Coast Guard (USCG) Marine Information for Safety and Law Enforcement (MISLE) is a mature and well-managed program in the Support life cycle phase. MISLE continues to meet its mission objective resulting in a reduction of overall IT cost through the integrated data exchange handled by 17 other USCG information systems. MISLE activities include, law enforcement boardings, vessel sightings, marine inspections, marine safety investigations, response actions, search and rescue operations, operational controls, and enforcement actions. Tech Refresh - MISLE 5.1 remains the sole project in-progress and is within acceptable OMB range for cost and schedule variance. Current tasks includes bug fixes and software patches addressing potential security vulnerabilities. The program continues to meet the monthly and quarterly performance objective of cases entered into the MISLE system for safety and law enforcement business areas. User satisfaction has fluctuated due to limited funding and the inability to adapt to changing business requirements, however the last semi-annual survey after 1QFY17 was above target. Semi-annual performance metrics are anticipated after 2QFY17 for system response time and data errors. The program continues to effectively track and mitigate program risks. Resources are applied to high-impact cases and the program continues to demonstrate its strong support of department and component strategic goals.  The DHS Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the MISLE program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
Purpose:
NAIS is a data collection, processing and distribution system that provides international Maritime Organization (IMO)-adopted Automatic Identification System (AIS) information to enhance safety of navigation and our Marine Transportation System (MTS), and improve Maritime Domain Awareness (MDA).  The project provides the necessary capability to ensure the effective exchange of information  between AIS-equipped vessels, aircraft, ATON, and shore stations within all major U.S. ports, waterways, and coastal zones.  It integrates a network of AIS receivers and transmitters, data processing and storage centers, and user interface services that capture, exchange, and analyze data of critical interest for maritime safety and security.  Data collected supports the nation's maritime interest, from the safety of vessels and ports through collision avoidance, to the safety of the nation through detection, traffic identification, and classification of vessels.
Benefits/Stakeholders:
The data collected by NAIS will be shared with other pertinent stakeholders and decision makers in support of maritime security at critical ports.  NAIS supports a layered defense and requirements for Advanced Notice of Arrival by correlating AIS data with target vessel reporting and other maritime awareness data to focus resources on higher interest vessels.  The key customers and primary beneficiaries of NAIS include: USCG, CBP, Navy, Army Corps of Engineers, NOAA, IRS, indirectly to the international community through MSSIS, and port partners.  Maritime Operational Threat Response benefits in achieving a coordinated U.S. Government response to threats to the US in the maritime domain.  NAIS will facilitate the Coast Guard response to threats in the maritime domain by enabling better visibility of suspect vessels as well as other vessels in the vicinity.  NAIS will allow for visibility and tracking of U.S. Government vessel assets for improved overall coordination of resources.  Maritime Communications benefits are associated with improved USCG ability to communicate with vessels in support of various USCG missions.  These benefits include the enhanced exchange of navigation information, improved communications interoperability with foreign vessels and other Government agencies' vessels, and backup capability to the Rescue 21 voice systems via AIS messaging.  The following USCG systems are dependent upon NAIS: IOC,  WebCOP, eGIS, MISLE, and MAGNet.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3258 - Goal 2.1:  Secure U.S. Air, Land, and Sea Borders and Approaches, 3262 - Goal 1.1:  Prevent Terrorist Attacks
ROI Description:
NAIS improves maritime domain awareness and offers improvements in collision avoidance, maritime safety, environmental protection and national security through the detection, classification and tracking of vessels whether they are in national water or still thousands of miles off shore.  

The ROI of 7.94, as calculated in the NAIS Alternatives Analysis of Dec 29, 2006, was calculated by determining the sum of the present value of all benefits and dividing it by the sum of the present value of all costs of each capability.  The benefits of security risk reduction (such as detection of large commercial vessel introduces WMD into US port and fishing vessel has a crew member onboard suspected of being a terrorist) are included in the ROI calculation.  The benefits of operational performance (such as improved Search and Rescue detection and response and collision detection and enforcement) have not been included because the confidence in those calculations was low; however if they were to be included, the ROI would be even higher.  The benefits were calculated for the following capabilities provided by NAIS: coastal receive, coastal transmit, long range receive, advanced data capability, and inland waters receive and transmit.  For each capability a variety of scenarios were evaluated using probabilities of occurrence and consequence costs to demonstrate the improvement in security risk by implementing NAIS.  

The present value of all costs of each capability was calculated using the LCCE produced as part of the NAIS Alternatives Analysis document.  The total benefit was calculated as $5,704,345,592; the total LCC was calculated as $718,062,000; the ROI was calculated as 7.94.  

While 7.94 is the ROI for the whole NAIS system, each Increment offers improvements in each capability to differing degrees.  Increment 1 primarily benefits coastal receive.  After recapitalization of Increment 1 with Increment 2, the return on investment is significant improvement of marine safety and security by increasing receive coverage from 24nm to 50 nm, the addition of transmit capability out to 24 nm, and advanced data capability.  Increment 3 primarily benefits long range receive.
Investment Requirements:
NAIS derives from the U.S. obligations under Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) 1974,  an international treaty, calls for automatic identification system of vessels; Maritime Transportation Safety Act (MTSA) Act of 2002 which is CG efforts in improving its knowledge of the ships calling at U.S. ports as “Maritime Domain Awareness? (MDA). Congressional Security and Accountability for Every Port (SAFE Port) Act of 2006.

DHS Strategic and IT Strategic Plans; USCG Strategic and C4ISR Plans, and to meet mission gap as defined in the MNS, ORD and by DHS Maritime Domain Awareness needs.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: FY2016 Cost estimates have been included in the current CIP; no other changes on previously reported fiscal years have been made.
Operational Analysis Results: NAIS I-1 is operating as expected, is fully supportive of CG & DHS mission ops, & successfully enhancing end users’ Maritime Domain Awareness. (OA Sec 2) To realize cst savings, NAIS used existing US assets:  I-1 & later I-2 installs were collocated on R21 tower sites where practicable.Data mgmt capabilities incldng data prcessing, recrding, & warehousing are at central location.End user access to AIS data is accmplished via existing data display systms. (OA Sec 3) Operational users were included in systm test & eval.User satisfaction is monitored via support requests made to NAIS SOC, dialog w/ NAIS project sponsor, & working grp meetings w/users & managers of related programs throughout CG. NAIS Pgrm Office dstrbtd an NAIS questionnaire to usrs & recved favorable results regarding AIS data use.User reported customer satisfaction exceeds 90%. An Aug 2015 re-survey was sent to internal/external NAIS usrs & results were in line w/ 2014 srvy which was favorable w/ some expressed desire for addtl training. (OA Sec 4) NAIS capbilities are in algnmnt w/ CG mission prgrms & support DHS goals/objctvs for prtecting crit infra, & building a nimble, effective emrgncy response systm & culture of preparedness. NAIS stratgic & busnss results successfully attained include: 35 CG Comm&Centers have been prvided w/ NAIS fnctionality, 51 Ports/10 wtrways have AIS receive & transmit capabilities , 1 Port&1 waterway will receive AIS receive & transmit capbilities. (OA Sec 5)NAIS prgrm uses 6 operation metrics (five mnthly & 1 qtrly) shwn in OA & elsewhere in INVEST.NAIS perf is mtg/exceeding trgets for all 6 metrics. Most recent mnthly & qtrly results are in INVEST while OA summarizes perf for FY. (OA Sec 6) NAIS I-1 prvides initial shore-based cpability to receive info trnsmtted by vessels that operate AIS equip. I-1 achvd 100% operational capability in ports& waterways as defined in ORD. I-2 will recpitlize I-1 w/ full trnsmt & receive capability in ports &waterways as defined in ORD.Suffcnt runtime data has been accmultd to cnfirm systm meets/exceeds thrshold for Ao of >= 96% (current Ao = 99.62%). CG is exploring new wys of measuring AIS perf using msg  (packet) err rate anlys. CG is also considering new uses for AIS data including electronic aids to navigation. (OA Sec 7) OA was drafted & routed internally using 4/18/16 risk register, but subsequent updts to register clsed rsks 3, 6, 7, 9.Oprtnal risks 1 & 2 are in INVEST as rsks 12 & 13. Most current rsks are in INVEST.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United States Coast Guard (USCG) Nationwide Automatic Identification System (NAIS) program is in the Mixed life cycle phase. The program is performing within acceptable OMB schedule thresholds; however, the program’s high positive cost variance is due to the recent schedule rebaseline. Program is scheduled to complete the deployment of the equipment in the Alaska and Western River region to achieve the Increment-2 Full Operational Capability (FOC) by 4QFY18. The program has sufficient funding to complete the deployment; no additional fund will be required due to schedule change to complete the deployment. New schedule is beyond the Rescue 21 FOC schedule threshold of 4QFY17, which is the external dependency of the NAIS implementation. The program is scheduled to meet with the Acquisition Review Board for approval to conduct its Acquisition Decision Event (ADE)-3 in 1QFY18. The program is meeting their objectives and exceeding the expectation of the stakeholders. NAIS Systems receives an average of 118M Automatic Identification System (AIS) messages per day approx., 14,000 unique vessels in 58 critical ports and 11 coastal waterways and provides 97+ live data feeds to the stakeholders. The program continues to analyze and manage risk by prioritizing the most imminent risk as well as identifying thorough mitigation strategies. Program currently has a moderate risk exposure score.   The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the NAIS program as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The Vessel Logistics System (VLS) is used for logistics management in support of Coast Guard (CG) surface, C4IT and civil operational assets. VLS consists of two component systems:  the Fleet Logistics System (FLS), and the Naval and Electronics Supply Support System (NESSS).  FLS provides an integrated logistics system for configuration management, financial and procurement management, maintenance information, and supply support data for over 240 cutters, 1000 standard boats, C4IT equipment, and buoys.  FLS provides NESSS with supply data using maintenance information.  FLS also enables field units to create and send Military Standard Requisitioning and Issue Procedures (MILSTRIP) transactions and generate obligation accounting data.  NESSS supports all supply activities needed for the naval and electronics program and provides supply data for use by FLS.  NESSS also supports the financial management system for the CG Yard.
The purpose of VLS is to continue providing a suite of tools to the CG’s surface logistics community to perform management of configuration, maintenance, supply chain, and finance and procurement data. There are approximately 2389 VLS users. VLS has approximately 755 concurrent users during a normal business day, and approximately 14,000 logins per quarter. The CG is in the process of transforming/aligning business processes for logistics. Logistics will use a single set of business processes referred to as the Mission Support Business Model (MSBM) and the 4 cornerstones of that model: Configuration Management, Total Asset Visibility, Bi-Level Maintenance, and a single point of accountability through Product Line Managers.
Goals for VLS are primarily short term and are focused on ensuring sustainability from a technical standpoint until it is replaced by the Coast Guard Logistics Information Management System (CG-LIMS).  CG-LIMS is a Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) system being configured to replace multiple legacy systems and is intendedto be a single enterprise asset management system for the CG.
Stakeholders, customers, and other beneficiaries of VLS include CG Headquarters directorates and offices, Logistics Centers, C4IT Service Center and its asset lines, Naval Engineering/Electronic Support Units, Product Line Managers, Asset Materiel Managers, Coast Guard Yard, Asset Project Offices, Finance Center, Cutters and boats, other government activities, contractors, and vendors.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3241 - M&S Goal 6.1: Integrate Intelligence, Information Sharing, and Operations, 5502 - M&S Goal 6.6: Strengthen Service Delivery and Manage DHS Resources
ROI Description: VLS supports business processes for the CG surface logistics community, directly supporting DHS Strategic Goals of Prevention, Protection, Response, Recovery and Service.  VLS continues to logistically support the day-to-day operations of the surface community of assets while the new enterprise COTS system (CG-LIMS) is being developed. Components of VLS have been in operation for almost 20 years.  Initial ROI for VLS was realized well before the 7-year mark.  VLS is one of the current legacy logistics IT investments in the CG targeted for consolidation and replacement by CG-LIMS. Capability requirements of VLS will be fully considered in the requirements phase of CG-LIMS development.
Investment Requirements: VLS is required for the USCG to comply with the CFO Act of 1990 and the Federal Financial Management Improvement Act of 1996.
PM Qualificiations: 8 - No certification, but with between 2 and 4 years PM experience (within the last five years)
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: There are no fundamental or substantive changes.
Operational Analysis Results: VLS customer satisfaction was verified during the most recent operational analysis for the system.  3520 customer satisfaction surveys were analyzed from Coast Guard Logistics Centers, C4IT Service Center, Naval Engineering/Electronic Support Units, Product Line Managers, Asset Materiel Managers, YARD, Asset Project Offices over 18 months. Overall customer satisfaction was measured at approximately 97%.  Strategic and Business Results: VLS remains in alignment with DHS and Coast Guard strategic plans by supporting the Coast Guard’s strategy to move to a single logistics system (CG-LIMS). Because CG-LIMS is being supported by the same logistics team as VLS at our enterprise data center, there is an opportunity for reuse of modular development done to support VLS to support those same aspects of CG-LIMS. Financial Performance is best demonstrated in the form of a cost benefit analysis conducted as part of a business case written to support a technical refresh of VLS. There will be both savings and cost avoidances as a result of the refresh.  The break-even point on the refresh occurs in 2.5 years (mid- FY 2015).  The existing support staff is being used to do the refresh, with only one additional FTE required over the development period. Savings will be realized in certification and accreditation (due to only two systems requiring C&A after the refresh. The tech refresh thus far has been completed on budget, as demonstrated by details provided in the projects and activities tabs. Innovation is being demonstrated throughout the technical refresh of VLS.  Examples include: Moving the application and relational database management system to a modern, supportable development platform based upon technologies commonly supported at Coast Guard Operations Systems Center (OSC) and included in the Technology Reference Model. The refreshed system will employ the latest techniques and technology for securing the application addressing all of the latest as well as emerging security threats and providing a modern intuitive user interface.  It will utilize OSC’s SOA/ESB capability to deliver data to and from current and envisioned system components. This facilitates the ability to deliver functionality now and replace systems later without impacting delivered capabilities.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The United Coast Guard (USCG) Vessel Logistics System (VLS) is a suite of legacy logistics applications. As a legacy program VLS does not follow all current DHS level guidance. The VLS portfolio now contains two primary applications: 1. Fleet Logistics System (FLS), and 2. Naval and Electronics Supply Support System (NESSS). Current projects are on-going for FLS and NESSS. These initiatives increase platform stability, make minor user enhancements, further connectivity with Coast Guard Logistics Information Management Systems (CG-LIMS), incorporate Chief Financial Officer (CFO) requirements, refresh software & hardware and install security vulnerability patches. The FLS supports over 240 cutters and 1000 standard boats, IT equipment and buoys. The system has some 14,000 logins per quarter. The program is within OMB acceptable range for Cost Variance (CV). Schedule Variance (SV) is slightly out of range due to historical reporting from FY14. SV reported since that time is within range. The Operational Analysis (OA) states that VLS is being retired by FY21 and replaced by CG-LIMS. The program continues to take actions to cover capability gaps to enable VLS operations. Over the last two years, VLS completed five maintenance releases and two enhancement projects: 1. Single Sign-On and 2. Electronic Asset Logbook (EAL) Integration. These actions enable VLS with modernized business processes and improved data quality. The program reports significant risk exposure.  The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer assesses the USCG VLS program as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
Purpose: The purpose of the Core Accounting System (CAS) suite is to serve as the primary accounting, asset management, and procurement system for the U.S. Coast Guard and Transportation Security Agency.  All financial transactions are consolidated in the CAS suite so that information can be reported to the Department of Homeland Security. This system handles an annual average of 36 million transactions.
 
Goal: The goal of the CAS suite is to process financial data and generate reports and statements to meet federal requirements.  The CAS suite includes: Oracle Federal Financials (OFF) (a commercial off-the-shelf, product that includes - accounts receivable, assets, projects, inventory, accounts payable, purchasing, and general ledger), Sunflower (property management system used by the Transportation Security Agency), Finance and Procurement Desktop (FPD) (enterprise-wide accounting and procurement system assigned to assist in funds and procurement management), Workflow Imaging Network System (WINS) (imaging and document processing system), and Contract Information Management System (CIMS) (contract management using PRISM).
 
Benefit: The benefits of the CAS suite involves the analytical evaluation of projects and programs quantitatively, which improves project and program efficiencies and effectiveness; integrating all aspects of accounting and budget requirements for projects and programs.  The CAS suite tracks the financial cost of purchases, delivers, payments, and expenditures, making data management more efficient and report inquires readily available to users and managers.
Investment: The investment in the CAS suite supports all the critical operational activities of three major components within the Department of Homeland Security by recording and accounting for transactions.
