IPAWS adjusted FTE costs to reflect the latest Salary and Benefit data;  IPAWS adjusted its allocation plan for the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act for Defense, the Global War on Terror, and Hurricane Recovery, 2006 (Public Law 109-234) fund (Fund 78 -no year funds).
Operational Analysis Results:
The IPAWS OA shows that the program is effective in delivering unique, mission-critical system capabilities across customer, business, financial, and innovation. 
Financial: IPAWS provides the only integrated access to multiple private sector communications networks for the distribution of alert/warning and emergency information to people across the nation. Financial analytics indicate that the Program's selected alternative increases benefits to society such that the initial investment is recovered, and a return is incurred.
Customer: User Assessment/Evaluation results indicate overall satisfaction from participants, and IPAWS continues to enhance the coverage and value of its services by making improvements to NPWS and IPAWS-OPEN.
Business: IPAWS aligns to DHS' Strategic Mission 5, Goal 5.3, Objectives 5.3.1 and 5.3.4, along with FEMA's Strategic Priority 1, Objective 1.3, Strategy 1.3.2. IPAWS also fulfills the business needs in accordance with Executive Order 13407.
Operational Performance: IPAWS meets all except one of its Operational Performance metrics, which is being addressed by implementing the findings from a Feasibility Alternatives Analysis to migrate IPAWS-OPEN to a Cloud Solution that is projected for completion in FY20.
Innovation: The Program continues ongoing efforts to enhance system capabilities and resiliency to address the goals of E.O.13407, including enhancing delivery of alert and warning messages to people with disabilities and access and functional needs. Specifically, IPAWS has undertaken an initiative to utilize symbology in an effort to better communicate alerts to those with functional needs or limited English proficiency.
Risk: IPAWS tracks 10 project and 14 operational risks, many of which have been mitigated through the acquisition lifecycle processes. Specifically, the Program mitigated the risks associated with budget cuts and delayed capability deployment by splitting into two discrete segments. Additionally, the IPAWS Program continues a Risk Management process to address risks related to meeting and maintaining program performance. This includes annual revisions to the Risk Management Plan, proactive maintenance of the Risk Register, monthly meetings to review and address project-level risks, and quarterly Program-level Risk Reviews to identify, assess, and mitigate risks.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Integrated Public Alert Warning System (IPAWS) is in the Mixed life cycle phase. The program is operating within OMB recommended threshold for cost and schedule variances. Since the last assessment, the program held its Acquisition Review Team (ART) Out-brief for Acquisition Decision Event (ADE) 2B for Discrete Segment 2 (DS-2) May 2017. The ART meeting concluded that the program is ready to proceed to the Acquisition Review Board (ARB), which is tentatively planned for early July 2017. The program is expecting to achieve the ADE-2B by end June, in order to remain on schedule and utilize their allocated budget for FY17. The Discrete Segment 1(DS-1) portion of the program is currently maintaining IPAWS Open and the 77 PEP stations (repair, maintenance, fuel spill recovery, decommissioning and moving, etc.). The program has a current Operational Analysis (OA) as of 4QFY16, which indicates IPAWS is effectively delivering mission-critical systems capability across the core performance areas: Customer Results, Strategic and Business Results, Financial Performance and Innovation. But not meeting KPP of 99.9% availability. The program continues to manage risk by prioritizing the most imminent risk and putting the mitigation strategy in place according to the risk management plan. The program currently has Moderate Risk Exposure Score. Until program successfully achieves ADE-2B, The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess the FEMA IPAWS program as a Medium Risk investment.

Investment Title: FEMA - NFIP Information Technology Systems and Services
Brief Summary:
The purpose of the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) Information Technology Systems and Services (IT S&S) investment is to support the business operations of the NFIP.  This investment includes: 
1) The Legacy Support System (LSS), a mainframe application that processes all the Write-Your-Own (WYO) insurance company flood policy and claims transactions;
2) The Bureau and Statistical Agent, which supports the iService system and the business services of the NFIP, by providing financial and statistical control, training materials for over 80 participating insurance companies, and multiple other business functions for the NFIP.
3) The NFIP Virtual Information Technology System (NVITS), which is the environment that hosts the FloodSmart and Underwriting & Claims Operation Review Tool (UCORT).
 
Without the capability embodied by the IT S&S investment, the NFIP would be unable to process flood insurance policies and claims for more than 5.3 million flood policies.   
 
As NFIP’s System of Record, IT S&S investment is critical to mission attainment, helping facilitate flood insurance transactions like policy issuance and claims payments to flood survivors.   IT S&S supports the following DHS and FEMA missions: DHS Mission 5 (Strengthen National Preparedness and Resilience), FEMA Strategic Priority 4 (Enable Disaster Risk Reduction Nationally), and Federal Insurance and Mitigation Administration (FIMA) Goal 2, Obj. 2.1 (Enhance Credibility/Effective Program Delivery). The key benefit of this investment is the continued operation of the NFIP and implementation of critical legislative reforms resulting from Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform and Modernization Act of 2012 and the Homeowners Flood Insurance Affordability Act of 2014.  
 
Key investment stakeholders include: policyholders, FEMA components, FIMA, the Direct Servicing Agent, WYO Insurance companies, insurance vendors, adjusters, insurance agents, communities, and others.In order to leverage technology advances, FEMA is in the process of migrating these systems from Contractor Owned Contractor Operated facilities to Government Owned Government Operated facilities. FEMA has partnered with US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Information Technology Center (NITC) to provide hosting services. This investment is also slated for disposal to be replaced by a modernized solution referred to as the Phoenix solution; described in its' own investment with UII 07128.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3247 - Goal 5.1: Enhance National Preparedness, 5422 - Goal 5.4:  Enable Rapid Recovery
ROI Description:
The IT S&S is an investment in sustainment that has been operational since 1983.  As such, no ROI has been formally quantified.  The NFIP IT S&S has been in production for over 30 years.  Given this length of time, it is likely that this system has provided a very favorable return on its original investment.  Additionally, this system allows the NFIP to sell flood insurance and pay claims to U.S. persons in a time of flooding disaster. 
 
As described in responses to questions 9a and 9b, the continued operation of the Legacy Support System (the IT system within the IT S&S investment) is critical to the day-to-day operation of the NFIP, just as the support functions provided by the continued work funded under the BSA contract is critical to NFIP’s ability to update program documentation; respond to flooding disasters by opening Flood Response Offices (FRO), and providing training to key stakeholders, including claims adjusters.
Investment Requirements: See the table below for the list and URL's describing the legislative mandate, published agency strategic plan and Presidential Direction that apply to the Phoenix Program.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: FEMA - NFIP IT Systems and Services no longer includes planning activities for the replacement investment, FEMA - NFIP IT Phoenix. At IOC, FEMA - IT Systems and Service will begin transition of program services and functional shutdown.
Operational Analysis Results:
Customer Results: Needs articulated by stakeholders were identified, along with corresponding NFIP impact and action items.
Strategic and Business Results: Strategic goals were identified along with appropriate perfomance measurements.
Financial Performance: Tactical objectives were identified along with appropriate measurements
Innovation: New NFIP IT PMO organized in December 2015 in order to determine new path forward for replacing the NFIP Legacy System.
Operational Performance Measures: Necessary operational measures were identified and were reported on monthly, and did not exceed prescribed thresholds.
Risk Analysis: Risks are reported monthly or as new risks arise in the risk register. 


Please refer to OA documentation attached in the KEY DOCUMENTS tab for more general information.  
Please refer to the OPERATIONAL DATA tab for specific performance metrics and associated details.
CIO Evaluation Comments: FEMA’s National Flood Insurance (NFIP) legacy Information Technology Systems and Services (ITSS) program, and its modernization effort NFIP Phoenix, are now two distinct programs. Each program has submitted its own business case and will be assessed separately. This assessment reviews the Information Technology Systems and Services (ITSS) program, currently in the Support life cycle phase. The program continues to make steady progress in its efforts to ready ITSS for a successful transition to the Phoenix modernization program.  The transition plan has been finalized and prioritization has been given to the execution of the transition plan to move the existing hosting environment to the new government owned government operated (GOGO) facility by 3Q 2017.  This move will provide flexibility to manage the ongoing operations of the ITSS within a federally owned facility, reduce costs, and ensure greater government oversight of contractor activities while lowering the risk profile for the Phoenix modernization effort.  The program is operating within acceptable OMB ranges for cost and schedule, and continues to meet customer expectations and achieve baseline performance measures. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the Information Technology Systems and Services (ITSS) program as a Moderately Low Risk investment.

Brief Summary: FEMA’s IT Infrastructure is comprised of "ten" “business areas? as defined in the Infrastructure Investment Charter in compliance with DHS Infrastructure requirements-each providing a critical element to the essential whole that enables an assurance of a secure and resilient IT infrastructure and the supporting systems as a  “A Nation Prepared and Last Man Standing.? This investment is to support FEMA’s Aging Infrastructure technology. Aging information technology (IT) systems refers not only to a FEMA system’s age in years but also to issues that affect its sustainability over the long term, such as the availability of software and hardware support and of people with the necessary knowledge and skills to service these systems. The term also relates to a system’s ability to adequately support changing mission needs or emerging technologies, such as 24/7 online availability. FEMA’s Aging IT Infrastructure poses Significant Risk to the FEMA Mission. The goal of the investment is to be in partnership with the Lines of Business and Regional Administrators to plan and fund periodic IT system and application upgrades which are critical to ensure that IT can support FEMA’s disaster response mission operations in a timely and effective manner. (OIG-11-69, “Federal Emergency Management Agency Faces Challenges in Modernizing Information Technology.?)FEMA is not the team, but part of a team to include all first responders in the U.S. and the public preparers and survivors; and FEMA’s IT Infrastructure investment ensures the communication, coordination, and integration that enables America to prepare for, prevent against, respond to, and recover from disasters that happen in today’s fixed, mobile, broad-based and technology-driven environment. FEMA’s IT Infrastructure accomplishes this through the inclusion of enhanced/emerging technologies, as well as the acquisition, integration, operations and maintenance of FEMA’s wide-area, local-area, and wireless networks; voice and video communications systems; helpdesk, desktop, site support and FEMA virtualized data centers. Our customers and stakeholders consists of an expansive team that includes Federal partners, State, local, and tribal communities, the private sector, non-profits, and faith-based groups and the general public. FEMA’s IT Infrastructure investment is the backbone investment which directly supports FEMA’s mission and facilitates coordinated support for the DHS's mission.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3249 - Goal 5.3: Ensure Effective Emergency Response, 5422 - Goal 5.4:  Enable Rapid Recovery, 46751 - Enhance Disaster Preparedness and Response
ROI Description: This investment enables FEMA to accomplish its mission. This was achieved during Hurricane Sandy where faster response to the public and survivors was evidenced, as opposed to Hurricane Katrina. The estimated ROI were the minimum loss of life and property during recent disasters. The ROI is through enabling our program offices and their systems/applications providing the right information, to the right people, at the right time-all in a mobile environment with 100% availability.
Investment Requirements:
Legislative Mandate: Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief & Emergency Assistance Act (Public Law 93-288-April 2013): http://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/1383153669955-21f970b19e8eaa67087b7da9f4af706e/stafford_act_booklet_042213_508e.pdf.
Since Hurricane Katrina in 2005, FEMA & Congress have identified the requirement for FEMA to modernize its technology & Whole of Community practices to improve disaster response. This investment comply with (1)Post Katrina Emergency Management Reform Act Public Law 109-295-Oct 4, 2006 (2)Clinger-Cohen Act of 1996 (3)Federal Information Security Management Act 2002 (4)Federal IT Acquisition Reform Act Dec 14, 2014 and other Acts. This investment helps deliver the following:
-DHS Quadrennial Homeland Security Review QHSR #5 Mission of "Strengthen National Preparedness and Reliance".  
-DHS QHSR "Goal 5.3: Ensure Effective Emergency Response". All objectives in 5.3 are delivered by Infrastructure: Provide timely & accurate information; Conduct effective, unified incident response operations; Provide timely & appropriate disaster assistance; Ensure effective emergency communication, Support employees & emergency workers.
-DHS QHSR Goal 5.4: Enable Rapid Recovery, both objectives: Ensure continuity & restoration of essential services & functions; Support and enable communities to rebuild stronger, smarter, & safer. 
-FEMA’s Strategic Priority 1,  identifies mission requirement of being survivor-centric in program delivery. A key qualitative outcome of this priority is to ensure FEMA employees & the partners we serve;( state, local, and tribal officials) are better prepared & positioned for effective recovery & mitigation. This effort supports our requirement by providing a secure, reliable IT network infrastructure that underpins FEMA’s core mission. 
This investment plan/implement FEMA IT Modernization Plan Cyber high prioritized projects: FEMA EaaS, upgrade aging infrastructure, data center consolidation/modernization.
-FEMA Strategic Plan 2014-18: http://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/1405716454795-3abe60aec989ecce518c4cdba67722b8/July18FEMAStratPlanDigital508HiResFINALh.pdf.
  Project conforms to agency plan including Data Center & Telecommunications. -FEMA Pub 1 is FEMA capstone doctrine: http://www.fema.gov/media-library/assets/documents/25272.
-Presidential Direction: http://www.dhs.gov/homeland-security-presidential-directive-12.
Infrastructure projects assist with logical access to information systems.
Public URLs: https://esw.fema.net/esw/md/cio/cio-ops/operations/servicedelivery/progmgmt/ifema/shared documents/forms/allitems.aspx.|https://intranet.fema.net/org/ms/ocio/collab/sas/tiger team review and findings/forms/allitems.aspx?rootfolder=/org/ms/ocio/collab/sas/tiger team review and findings/program offices/mission support (ms)/msd 2014 visit/fema email business case
PM Qualificiations: 8 - No certification, but with between 2 and 4 years PM experience (within the last five years)
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Increase from PY (2014) to CY (2015) in Govt FTE . Increased FTEs from CY (2015) to BY (FY 2016) both program funds and FTEs.
Operational Analysis Results:
The program completed the yearly Operational Analysis (OA) by conducting an OA assessment. There are positive results identified below (Detailed in the approved FY16 Infrastructure OA) based on the consolidated approach to FEMA's Infrastructure Investment. Having a strong PMO with leadership & partnerships support & reporting has helped in the provision of an overall Infrastructure Strategy.
1. Customer Results: Customer service is on target & better, one business area (Wireless) is 99%+ positive. Helpdesk and Site Services user assessment results show the program is meeting users’ business needs.
2.Strategic & Business Results: Improved service delivery & support to meet Mission requirements. One business area showed that as service increases, cost savings increase.
3. Financial Performance: The investment is in mixed & maximizing its allocated funds, on budget despite minimal cut in budgets.
    (a)Network & Voice evaluated the 34 FEMA fixed sites proposed for the leased equipment option, the lease option with a total cost of $52M over 5 years plan(FY16 – FY20). Whereas, the DHS Winter Study conducted in Dec. 2015 shows a total cost of $79M to refresh all aging infrastructure equipment (Network/Voice/Video). This shows a saving of $27M. 
    (b)EaaS project will replace existing capability with increased availability to support the FEMA mission. The existing solution provided FEMA with 97% availability; which does not meet the mission requirement of 99.9% uptime.
4. Innovation:
   (a) EaaS is a modernization project which will provide a hybrid cloud based solution.
   Key deliverables are: (1) Migration of FEMA mailboxes to MS Office 365  (2)Migration from BlackBerry & Good to iPhones/iPads running MobileIron as mobile device management. (3)Implementation of derived credentials. 
   (b) Data Centers consolidation & modernization: (1) FEMA has vacated B430 & migrated all applications to B201 or B213. (2)Virtualization/modernizationof manyof the legacy systems will occur during this transition.
5. Operational Performance Measures: Overall, Infrastructure investment is performing on or exceeding target except Cyber Security (CSD). FEMA is currently at 88% for HVA systems & 86% for non-HVA systems & CSD is working on a plan.
6. Risk Analysis: We started to implement the enhanced RMP which will instill a tailored & improved risk management process within the infrastructure program & reduce the likelihood of a risk becoming an issue.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Infrastructure program is in the Mixed life cycle phase. FEMA continues to provide insight into challenges facing the organization through the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) TechStat process. FEMA is incorporating into its governance process their Integrated Project Team (IPT) Charter to remediate its four outstanding TechStat actions. Since last assessment, FEMA has circulated the Integrated Program Team (IPT) Charter and currently awaiting final sign-off.  While the program awaits final sign-off of its IPT Charter, the program’s cost variance is within acceptable OMB threshold. However, the schedule variance is outside threshold range for the Email as a Service (EaaS) project stemming from delays with mailbox migration due to bandwidth issues and project activities were not updated in the source system.  The program is addressing the issues and has adjusted the deployment date for EaaS to late-4QFY17 from 3QFY17. EaaS schedule adjustment is the result of not enough bandwidth to complete the mailbox migration.  FEMA is monitoring risk and ensuring mitigations strategies are appropriate. Even with the program managing their risk, the infrastructure program is carrying a high risk exposure score.  As the program continues to update documentation that addresses their outstanding TechStat actions, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Chief Information Officer (CIO), continues to assess the FEMA Infrastructure program as a Moderately High Risk investment.

Brief Summary: The Non-Disaster (ND) Grants project’s purpose is: establish, implement, operate & maintain (O&M) the system, solution and sustaining infrastructure for an Enterprise-level, unified, coordinated, and automated grants management system supporting the full grants management lifecycle of multiple DHS grants programs. A single project office is chartered to provide governance, technical expertise, training, system development, & O&M effectively executing grants functions in a single automated system (ND Grants). ND Grants is a mixed lifecycle system past ADE-2 performing system enhancements, integration, legacy systems migration into ND Grants, & O&M. Benefits include: a single automated grants management system consolidating multiple fragmented, non-integrated and incompatible grants management processes, lifecycles, grant programs; real-time transactional input, updates and feedback; standardized, structured and searchable data format facilitating data collection, collation, & analytics; sequenced, reliable & complete workflows; automated pending/real-time action notifications; integration with financial, and asset management systems of record and other essential systems (IFMIS, Grants.gov, PARS); and integrated standardized and ad-hoc reporting linking outcome to grant award performance. Project goals and objective align with larger mission delivery goals and objectives of the DHS Strategic Plan, Mission Area 5: Strengthen National Preparedness and Resilience: meeting objectives defined by Goal 5.1: Enhance National Preparedness, Goal 5.2: Mitigate Hazards and Vulnerabilities; Goal 5.3 Ensure Effective Emergency Response; and Goal 5.4 Enable Rapid Recovery.  Project supports mission delivery goals/objectives providing a single information source for oversight, advanced planning, coordination, mgmt & execution of efforts to enhance, sustain, & continue capacity of state/local emergency responders to anticipate & develop proactive strategies and capabilities to prevent, respond to, & recover from potential threats through the strategic selection and tactical deployment and distribution/allocation of preparedness grant funding (approx. $4 B). Beneficiaries are: U.S. citizens/communities; private/nonprofit sectors, faith/community-based organizations; federal, state, local, tribal, & territorial first responders and partners. Customers: Federal PMs, grants assist personnel, State Admin. Agents, & grant applicants/ grantees.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3247 - Goal 5.1: Enhance National Preparedness, 46751 - Enhance Disaster Preparedness and Response
ROI Description:
An initial alternatives analysis was completed in Fiscal Year 2005 where seven existing DHS grants managements systems were evaluated against a set of requirements developed via creation of a grants management value chain.  Subsequent to this initial feasibility study an Analysis of Alternatives (AoA) was completed in August 2006 (and up-dated in December 2007) that determined a scenario entitled: Modified AFG provided the greatest return-on-investment (ROI), Net Present Value (NPV) over the shortest Payback Period (PP) of the alternatives analyzed.  The alternative of choice was forecasted to generated a (24%) ROI. NPV: $4.73 Million; and PP of 3 years.  A second A0A was completed that determined a scenario entitled: Grants Management Integrated Environment (GMIE) provided the greatest return-on-investment (ROI), Net Present Value (NPV) and shortest Payback Period (PP) of the alternatives analyzed.  It generated a (26.12%) ROI. PV Costs Benefit: $7.94 Million; and PP of 6 years compared to the closest alternative the PRISM Scenario that returned a (17.30 %) ROI; PV Costs Benefit: $6.14 Million; and PP of 7 years.  
 
Anticipate internal benefits include: decreased durations to achieve system functionality in the production environment (achieved through the development, modernization, and enhancement of an existing DHS/FEMA GMS Assistance to Firefighters Grants (AFG)); eliminating duplicative design/development and O&M efforts across multiple GMSs (achieved by consolidating GMSs into ND Grants and creating a configuration management process incorporating all stakeholder requirements); streamlined oversight and management (achieved via Charter of the ND Grants Project); improved and complete workflow and processes (achieved in creating a unified, single grants management lifecycle through effective business process management); elimination of significant capital costs necessary for building a system from scratch (achieved through  the development, modernization, and enhancement of an existing DHS/FEMA GMS AFG); decreased incremental costs and consolidated operations and maintenance cost (achieved through migration of systems into the modified AFG environment and closure/disposition of those unneeded systems). External benefits include: users, grant applicants and grantees interface with a single system GMS for all grant applications processes, workflows, and lifecycles experience a common and familiar view for all grant application.
Investment Requirements: This investment had a requirement to PIV enable the system which was completed 2/28/2016.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Only inflationary adjustments are indicated as change from PY to CY.
Operational Analysis Results: ND Grants OA evaluated: Technical; Target EA; Customer Satisfaction; Strategic, Business, and Mission; Financial; Innovation; and Risk Performance. Customer Satisfaction: Completed an extensive customer survey. Data has been collected, analyzed, created findings and developed recommendations. Strategic/Business/Mission: Programmatic goals and objectives: increase efficiencies, improve effectiveness, achieve regulatory compliance; and improve internal control align with the Federal PMA priorities; DHS QHSR, Strategic and IT Plan, and EA Roadmap. Financial: Identified 119 DHS-wide grant management programs for consolidation. Budget guidance limits ability to affect a DHS-wide solution.  Project achieved $570K/yearly cost avoidance. Innovation: Completed analysis for cloud-base technologies, and assessed project for meeting DHS-wide grant management system (GMS) goals.  Issues have been identified that impede ND Grants ability to provide an Enterprise GMS modern and innovative solution.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Non-Disaster Grants (ND Grants) is currently in the Mixed life cycle phase. The program is operating within acceptable OMB variance for cost. However, the program’s schedule variance has been negatively impacted by the project vendor’s inability to deliver on schedule.  The program is taking corrective actions to mitigate schedule delays and is currently in bilateral negotiations with the vendor. The program completed an Acquisition Program Change Request (APCR) change request to report on additional above base funding allocated to the ND Grants investment to accelerate the consolidation of two grants systems, which will achieve cost elimination in FY18. Additionally, a program rebaseline is expected by 3QFY17. In 2QFY17, ND Grants completed an Operational Analysis (OA) covering the following areas: financial performance, customer results, business and strategic analysis, operational performance, innovation, and risks. The OA indicates that ND Grants is not meeting some of its operational performance targets, but the program has implemented corrective actions to bring these numbers back above targets. The OA also indicates that system stability has improved. The program’s Initial end user surveys failed to meet or exceed targets for affirmative responses to the statements, “ND Grants is easy to use.? and “ND Grants makes me more efficient at my job.? Following their Agile methodology, ND Grants released a Minimally Value Product (MVP), which led to the low scores in the survey. Affirmative response rates have improved in subsequent end user surveys and is expected to meet or exceed targets by 4QFY17 survey.  The program continues to monitor its risks and it has a moderate risk exposure score.  Until the program resolves outstanding issues with vendor, The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) downgrades the rating of the ND Grants program to a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary:
The Phoenix Program is an early stage system modernization initiative (Pre ADE-2A) that is set to replace the legacy system investment titled National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) Information Technology Systems & Services (IT S&S).
 
The goal of the Phoenix investment is to process flood insurance policies and claims for 5.3 million property owners, to reduce the impact of flooding on private and public structures, and to drive community recovery after disasters. The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) supports the Write Your Own insurance companies (WYOs), the Direct Servicing Agent (DSA), and Vendors (a group of flood insurance processing services providers to the WYOs). The specific benefits and functions of the NFIP include the establishment of operating policies, designation of eligible communities, creation of auditing specifications, experience determination, rate setting, responsibility for the management, operation, maintenance and quality assurance of the systems and data, marketing, training provision, analysis and reporting to Congress, and provision of financial information to all applicable departments and agencies.  
 
The NFIP is a congressionally mandated program. Phoenix will support DHS Mission 5 (Strengthen National Preparedness and Resilience), FEMA Strategic Priority 4 (Enable Disaster Risk Reduction Nationally), and Federal Insurance and Mitigation Administration (FIMA) Goal 2, Obj. 2.1 (Enhance Credibility/Effective Program Delivery). Phoenix will also support the implementation of critical legislative reforms resulting from the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform and Modernization Act of 2012 and the Homeowners Flood Insurance Affordability Act of 2014.  
 
The NFIP has a stakeholder community consisting of actors within and external to government, due to its unique operating model. NFIP resides within the Federal Insurance & Mitigation Association (FIMA) within the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), and interacts with other FEMA risk analysis and risk reduction initiatives. NFIP governs industry program administrators such as the Direct Servicing Agent (DSA), Write Your Own insurance companies (WYOs), Flood Insurance Processing Services Providers to WYOs (Vendors), and adjusters. The customers and beneficiaries are US citizens that are supported by flood insurance policies.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3247 - Goal 5.1: Enhance National Preparedness
ROI Description: The Phoenix Program is currently progressing through the DHS ALF (Pre-ADE 2A) and has not acquired a system. Therefore, an actual ROI cannot yet be calculated. As a part of the AoA a rough order ROI was calculated over a 10-year period based on forecasted costs. For the selected alternative, the expected 10-year ROI was 204%.
Investment Requirements: See the table below for the list and URL's describing the legislative mandate, published agency strategic plan and Presidential Direction that apply to the Phoenix Program.
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: Any significant changes in budgeting amounts is due to the recent completion of the Life Cycle Cost Estimate in July of 2016.
CIO Evaluation Comments: FEMA’s National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) legacy Information Technology Systems and Services (ITSS), and its modernization effort (known as NFIP Phoenix), are now distinct programs. Each program has submitted a Business Case, and will be assessed separately. This assessment reviews the NFIP Phoenix program, which has entered the Obtain phase of the acquisition life cycle.  The Phoenix program has been designated as an Agile pilot program and has been successfully working with the Agile Integrated Product Team (IPT) at the Component and Department levels.  The program is preparing for its 6-month program review before the ARB, planned for early June.  This ARB is in keeping with the Department’s present intent to have all agile pilot programs appear before the ARB semi-annually.  Phoenix last appeared before the ARB on December 8, 2016, when it achieved ADE-2A/B.  In addition, Phoenix has developed a release roadmap, software development plan, improved risk management effects, cybersecurity assessments part a. and finalized its data migration plan completing four of the eight action items assigned by the December Acquisition Review Board (ARB) and are on schedule to complete the remaining actions items by their suspense dates. The program continues to effectively manage risk and has a moderate risk exposure score.  A development team has been on boarded and is in the discovery phase with design and development to begin soon.  Having recently entered the Obtain phase the Department will continue to monitor and closely work with the Phoenix Program Management Office to ensure the program is making continued progress. The Department of Homeland Security Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses the NFIP IT Phoenix program as a Medium Risk investment.

Brief Summary: The Grants Management Modernization (GMM) goals and objectives align with the QHSR ongoing priority of national preparedness and the whole community as well as strategic priority of strengthening the execution of our missions through public-private partnerships and contributes to the larger mission delivery goals and objectives of the DHS Strategic Plan, Mission Area 5: Strengthen National Preparedness and Resilience: meeting objectives defined by Goal 5.1: Enhance National Preparedness, Goal 5.2: Mitigate Hazards and Vulnerabilities; Goal 5.3 Ensure Effective Emergency Response; & Goal 5.4 Enable Rapid Recovery.  GMM purpose is to: design, implement, & incorporate comprehensive solution-oriented data-centric total grants management architecture for an Enterprise-level common platform supporting the full grants management lifecycle execution of multiple DHS grants programs. The GMM system is in early planning stages and has achieved ADE-1, but is planned as a Level 2 investment once legacy system capabilities can be migrated.  GMM benefits:  a platform consolidating multiple fragmented, non-integrated and incompatible grants management processes, lifecycles, systems and an initially identified 9 mission-critical DHS-wide grant systems & tools for consolidation to a common platform to provide real-time transactional input, standardized, structured & searchable data format facilitating data collection, collation, & analytics; sequenced, reliable & complete workflows; automated pending/real-time action notifications; integration with financial, & asset management systems of record & other essential systems (IFMIS, Grants.gov, PARS); & integrated standardized and ad-hoc reporting linking outcome to performance.  Project supports mission delivery goals/objectives by providing a single information source for oversight, planning, coordination, management & execution & efforts to enhance, sustain, & continue capacity of state/local emergency responders to anticipate & develop proactive strategies & capabilities to prevent, respond to, & recover from potential threats through the strategic selection and tactical deployment and distribution of grant funding (approx $10B/yr since 2013).  Beneficiaries: U.S. citizens/communities; private/nonprofit sectors, faith/community-based organizations; federal, state, local, tribal, & territorial first responders & partners. Customers: Federal PMs, grants assist personnel, State Admin. Agents, & grant applicants/recipients.
Agency Strategic Objectives / Agency Pri: 3247 - Goal 5.1: Enhance National Preparedness, 3248 - Goal 5.2: Mitigate Hazards and Vulnerabilities, 3249 - Goal 5.3: Ensure Effective Emergency Response, 46751 - Enhance Disaster Preparedness and Response
ROI Description: This investment is in early planning stages.  Anticipated benefits of this investment.
Investment Requirements: The 2014 -2015 FEMA IT Resiliency Review and multiple audits and findings, the current grant mgmt. environment has created a challenge to FEMA's ability to operate efficiently and effectively and to adapt to changing policies, business practices, and the rapidly evolving cybersecurity landscape in a cost effective way as defined in Title 2 of the Code of Federal Regulation (CFR) Part 2001, Uniform Administrative Requirements, Cost Principles, and Audit Requirements for Federal Awards. Additionally, the DHS Office of Inspector General (OIG), the Government Accountability Office (GAO), and other organizations have conducted hundreds of audits and about 80 studies between 2009 and 2014 that reveal common deficiencies in the current operation of grants programs.  Findings have shown from OIG audits from 2010 to 2014 that 10 common themes occurred at least 20 times over the five-years analyzed. Ineligible work or costs was the most frequently deficiency occurring in 473 findings over that timeframe.  (FY09 OIG DS-11-01, FY10 OIG DD-11-17, FY11 OIG-12-74, FY 12 OIG-13-90, FY13 OIG-14-102-D, Fy14 OIG SLP14-102). Additionally, the modernization effort is highlighted  in White House Executive Order 13411: Improving Assistance for Disaster Victims, which states that  "it is the policy  of the Federal Government to ensure that individuals who are victims of a terrorist attack, natural disaster, or other incident that is the subject of an emergency or major disaster declaration under the Stafford Act, and who are thereby eligible for financial or other assistance delivered by any department or agency of the executive branch (Federal disaster assistance), have prompt  and efficient access to Federal disaster assistance, as well as information regarding assistance available from  State and local government  and private sector sources." Lastly, the investment supports FEMA’s Strategic Plan by improving the analysis of reoccurring losses across the nation (Mission 5), eliminating duplicative processes (Mission 6), streamlining business processes through a common secure platform (Obj.5.4), standardizing performance and financial reporting with analytics (Obj.5.2).
Explanation of Change to PY or CY Fundin: This is a recently funded investment intended to support the consolidation of multiple grants management systems, programs, processes into a unified common platform which warranted increased funding requests.
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Grants Management Modernization (GMM) recently attained approval for its Acquisition Decision Event (ADE) 2A/B from an Acquisition Review Board (ARB) in May 2017. Achieving ADE 2A/2B moves the program to the Obtain life cycle phase. The ARB assigned the program four action items. These actions include the staffing ramp-up schedule due and received by the Office of Program Accountability and Risk Management (PARM) in July 2017. Two other action items: A review of component-level governance plan and the Acquisition Program Baseline (APB) due to PARM 4QFY17. Final action is returning to ARB by 1QFY18. As a designated member of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Agile Pilot Program, FEMA leadership continues to mature its processes to achieve milestones defined in their approved Department of Homeland Security (DHS) APB. The program has briefed the GMM Technical Working Group and the Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO) Integrated Program Team (IPT) their two proposed Authority to Operate (ATO) boundary options, in addition to its pilot efforts for 1st release by mid-4QF17. No date proposed for the final option decision for the ATO. As the program continues to prioritize activities in the Obtain lifecycle phase, leadership is managing and providing appropriate strategies to mitigate high and low risks. With that said, the program is maintaining a negligible risk exposure score. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) continues to assess FEMA Grants Management Modernization as a Medium Risk investment.

Investment Title: FEMA - FEMA Enterprise Identity Management System (FEIMS)
CIO Evaluation Comments: The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) IT Security program is in the Support life cycle phase. Note: IT Security is the new name for the FEMA Enterprise Identity Management System (FEIMS).  This program is new to the assessment process and not all source system fields are fully populated. The program does not have a risk register or projects listed in the source management system. The necessary program metrics required to complete an assessment for the IT Security program were not fully captured in the source systems and program documentation is being developed by the program. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Chief Information Officer (CIO) assesses FEMA IT Security as a Medium Risk investment.
